fields.title: PhD Defense Mihkel Kama
fields.text:
What is your main research question?
What do the spectra of forming stars tell us about their chemical and physical structure, and about the change of these properties during starbirth?

What is the most important conclusion to be drawn from your research?
When observing emission from chemical species in young stars, it is very important to sample a wide range of atoms and molecules, and to observe multiple spectral lines from each. Such data can reveal the true chemical and physical complexity of star-forming gas clouds in space, even if that complex structure is too small to be spatially visible.

What is the social significance / what are the practical consequences?
A better understanding of how stars and planets form in space is necessary to comprehend the origins of our own Solar System, including the Earth and ourselves. In my thesis, I contributed a part to the modern study of these processes.

Which methodology did you use for your research?
Most of my work is based on spectra of molecular line emission from star-forming gas clouds in space. These spectra were observed with the European Space Agency's Herschel Space Telescope, using the microwave spectrometer HIFI. Numbers were derived from the data by analytical and numerical models, including some using Monte Carlo methods for radiative transfer and excitation calculations.
fields.teaser_text: On Tuesday January 29 at 12:00, Mihkel Kama will defend his thesis titled "Young Intermediate-Mass Stars: from a HIFI spectral survey to the physics of the disk inner rim" in the Agnietenkapel.

fields.title: PhD verdediging Gijs Mulders
fields.text: Protoplanetaire schijven zijn een bijproduct van stervorming, en ook de kraamkamers van planetenstelsels. We treffen deze schijven aan rond jonge sterren in de directe omgeving van de zon, en kunnen die in groot detail bestuderen met telescopen vanaf de aarde en met satellieten vanuit de ruimte. In dit proefschrift heb ik me vooral gericht op het koppelen van deze waarnemingen aan theoriën over planeetvorming en andere fysische processen in protoplanetaire schijven. Mijn belangrijkste conclusies zijn dat de eerste stappen in het planeetvormingsproces onafhankelijk zijn van het type ster waaromheen planeten zich bij vormen, en dat het gat in de schijf rond de ster HD 100546, waarvan vermoed werd dat het veroorzaakt werd door een Jupiter-achtige planeet, waarschijnlijk veroorzaakt wordt door een bruine dwerg, een object dat zich qua massa tussen een planeet en een ster in bevind.
fields.teaser_text: Op vrijdag 8 maart om 10:00 zal Gijs Mulders zijn proefschrift getiteld "Radiative Transfer Models of Protoplanetary Disks: Theory vs. Observations" in de Agnietenkapel verdedigen.

fields.title: PhD Defense Konstantinos  Leventis
fields.text:
Gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) are the most powerful sources of electromagnetic radiation in the universe. They are the result of a catastrophic event, like the collapse of a very massive star or the collision of two compact objects (e.g. neutron stars). The gamma rays we observe originate from shocks within the relativistic outflow that is ejected from the burster. However, as the outflow interacts with the surrounding medium it gives rise to the afterglow radiation, which typically lasts longer and is observed over a broader range of frequencies, compared to the bursts itself.

Modelling the afterglow emission is one of the most powerful methods of probing the nature and physical processes of GRBs and their progenitors. In this Thesis, I explore various phases of the afterglow dynamics and the resulting spectra and light curves. I show that the transition of the outflow to non-relativistic velocities is manifested slowly in the observer's frame and quantify the properties of the transition across the spectrum. This has resulted in a set of flux prescriptions that I have used to accurately infer physical parameters of individual bursts. Beyond late-time behaviour, I have also looked into the early afterglow, for which I have analysed the observational signatures of energy injection into the blast wave, over a prolonged period. This analysis strongly suggests that the reverse shock significantly contributes to, and in some cases even dominates, the emission during the plateau phase of GRB afterglows.
fields.teaser_text: On Thursday February 28 at 14:00, Konstantinos Leventis will defend his thesis titled "The Many Phases of Gamma-Ray Burst Afterglows" in the Agnietenkapel.

fields.title: PhD verdediging Peter Polko
fields.text: Om de overeenkomsten en verschillen tussen systemen met zwarte gaten met de massa van de zon en diegene met massa's die ongeveer een miljoen tot een miljard keer groter zijn, te kunnen gebruiken om meer over deze objecten te weten te komen, moeten we de gerichte uitstromen van plasma die ze produceren, goed begrijpen. Uit waarnemingen blijkt dat ergens in deze uitstroom deeltjes een hogere energie krijgen. Door deze uitstromen te modelleren door vloeistofdynamica met magneetvelden en zwaartekracht, kunnen we deze locatie koppelen aan de eigenschappen rond het zwarte gat. Hierdoor zijn we voor het eerst in staat uit waarnemingen van deze locatie informatie over het zwarte gat te weten te komen.
fields.teaser_text: Op woensdag 3 april om 12:00 zal Peter Polko zijn proefschrift getiteld "Exploring jet properties in magnetohydrodynamics with gravity" in de Agnietenkapel verdedigen.

fields.title: PhD Defense Eva Ratti
fields.text:
Accurate mass measurements of stellar-scale black holes (BHs) and neutron stars (NSs) are challenging to obtain, but important to address a number of astrophysical questions. For example, tracing the currently poorly constrained mass distribution of NSs and BHs can provide constraints to theoretical models about binary evolution. Similarly, measurements of massive NSs can rule out theories about the composition of these objects (which is unknown), as a different composition implies a different value for the maximum possible mass.

A reliable method to measure masses is based on the observation of X-ray binary systems (XRBs), where the NS or BH accretes matter from a companion star. The accretion process is an efficient source of radiation, largely emitted in the X-ray waveband. When the accretion rate is low, it is possible for some XRBs to observe the mass donor star and follow its orbital motion through phase-resolved optical spectroscopy. Under certain conditions, the mass of the binary components can be inferred from those observations based on Kepler's laws.

During my PhD research I performed multi-wavelenght studies of X-ray sources in a low-accretion state, searching for suitable candidates for dynamical mass measurements. For three targets, I performed a complete dynamical study. I found that XRBs can show significant activity and variability even when accreting at a low rate, complicating the observation of the companion star and the estimate of the masses. I also found that variable spectral features from binaries hosting a white dwarf (WD) accretor can at times mimic NS or BH XRBs in a low-accretion state. The dynamical study of one of the new X-ray sources I analyzed revealed an accreting binary system with an extreme ratio between the mass of the donor star and that of the WD accretor. This result was intriguing in the framework of binary evolution theory. By studying simultaneous X-ray and radio observations of a known black hole candidate performed in a low-accretion state, I also found an interesting result regarding the coupling of X-rays and radio emission in XRBs.
fields.teaser_text: On Friday February 15 at 12:00, Eva Ratti will defend her thesis titled "Observations and dynamical studies of X-ray binaries in a low-accretion state" in the Agnietenkapel.

fields.title: Science Colloquium by Nobel laureate Brian Schmidt
fields.text:
The American/Australian astronomer Brian Schmidt will give a colloquium on the accelerating expansion of the universe, which is often associated with the mysterious so-called ‘dark energy’.

For the discovery of this accelerated expansion he received the 2011 Nobel prize in physics, with Saul Perlmutter and Adam Riess. Schmidt is Distinguished Professor at the Australian National University and works at Mount Stromlo Observatory. His scientific interests include observational cosmology, gamma-ray bursts, large surveys, photometry and calibration. He is scientific leader of the Skymapper project and theme leader and executive member of the CAASTRO Centre of Excellence. He is also an expert wine maker.

Schmidt’s colloquium is organized in the framework of the Science Colloquium. The Science Colloquium is a new faculty-wide scientific colloquium for all staff and students of the Faculty of Science. During these colloquia, predominantly international researchers will present a lecture on a topic of wide interest. They will take place on an ad hoc basis and the official language will be English.

fields.title: Eerste sterrenkijkavond bij UvA
fields.text:
Op vrijdag 22 maart organiseert het Sterrenkundig Instituut Anton Pannekoek van de Universiteit van Amsterdam voor de eerste keer een sterrenkijkavond. Deelname aan de avond is gratis.

Programma

De avond begint met een lezing van prof. dr. Carsten Dominik over het onderzoek dat wordt gedaan naar de vorming van planeten. Vervolgens wordt bij helder weer de sterrenhemel waargenomen door verschillende telescopen, waaronder de grootste telescoop van Nederland: de 51-centimeter telescoop. Bij bewolking vinden er rondleidingen door de sterrenkoepels plaats.

Op 22 maart is de planeet Jupiter vanaf het begin van de avond tot middernacht goed zichtbaar. De vier heldere manen van Jupiter - Io, Europa, Ganymedes en Callisto - bevinden zich allemaal aan een kant van Jupiter. De sterrenstelsels M81 en M82 zijn ook de hele avond te zien, net als het prachtige spiraalsterrenstelsel M51. In het noordwesten, nabij het sterrenbeeld Perseus, is Caldwell 14 te zien. Dit object bestaat uit twee open sterrenhopen zich naast elkaar bevinden.

Tijd en Locatie

De sterrenkijkavond vindt plaats van 19.00 uur tot 21.30 uur bij het Sterrenkundig Instituut Anton Pannenkoek, Science Park 904, Amsterdam.

De eerstvolgende sterrenkijkavond is op vrijdag 26 april.

fields.title: PhD Defense Yi-Jung Yang
fields.text:
Black holes are one of the most exotic and fascinating objects in the Universe. A black hole is mathematically defined to be a single point-like region, the so called singularity, where gravity is so strong that anything close enough to it will eventually be dragged across its event horizon (the point of no return) and forever vanish from our view; even light can not escape from such a strong gravitational pull.

In my PhD, I study black holes in different states (i.e. binary stellar-mass black holes in quiescence or outburst). Since black holes do not emit light, in order to study them we can observe them when they are accreting, or interacting with their surrounding materials, which emits radiation in different energies (i.e. in X-ray, radio or optical/UV). Using data taken with Chandra, XMM-Newton, and Swift, we are able to study the physical properties and the accreting mechanisms of these systems. In addition to the black hole X-ray binaries, I also study ultra-luminous X-ray sources (ULXs). ULXs are classified as off-nuclear sources that have X-ray luminosities exceeding 1039 erg/s. These sources can be stellar-mass black holes accreting at super-Eddington rate or the so called intermediate-mass black holes (IMBHs). We find strong evidence of an IMBH in the center of a blue compact dwarf galaxy. This provides us great insights for understanding the processes of black hole growth and galaxy evolution.
fields.teaser_text: On Wednesday October 23 at 10:00,  Yi-Jung Yang will defend her thesis titled "Accreting Black Holes" in the Agnietenkapel.

fields.title: PhD Defense Montserrat Armas Padilla
fields.text: My thesis is focused on the study of very faint X-ray binaries (VFXBs), a sub-group of X-ray binaries that display maximum luminosities of only Lx ~1034-36 erg s-1, several orders of magnitude lower than the ordinary well studied X-ray binaries. Their low X-ray luminosities imply that the mass accretion rates of the VFXTs are a factor of 10-100 less than the mean rates of the brighter systems. Hence, these very faint sources are ideal to study the relatively unexplored low-accretion rate regimes and therefore provide valuable inputs in several accretion-related phenomena, such as accretion physics, binary evolution models and the theory of nuclear burning on the surface of accreting neutron stars.
fields.teaser_text: On Friday November 1 at 10:00,  Montserrat Armas Padilla will defend her thesis titled "Subluminous X-ray binaries" in the Agnietenkapel.

fields.title: PhD Defense Maithili Kalamkar
fields.text: A compact object - a black hole or a neutron star, has extremely strong gravitational force. Compared to Earth, you would weigh more than a billion times as much on a neutron star! A compact object in a binary system can strip the companion star of its outer layers and capture this matter, called as accretion. In the vicinity of the compact object, the dynamical time-scales are less than a few milliseconds; the accreting matter moves in orbits with very high velocities. The study of the emission from this matter provides an excellent probe to study the behaviour of matter under extreme conditions. During my PhD, I studied the accretion phenomena in X-ray binaries using data obtained with X-ray missions such as RXTE and Swift. Study of the spectral and variability properties provides an excellent probe to investigate the structure and geometry of the accretion flow and the origin of variability.
fields.teaser_text: On Friday November 22 at 12:00, Maithili Kalamkar will defend her thesis titled "Probing accretion flow dynamics in X-ray binaries" in the Agnietenkapel.

fields.title: PhD Defense Alexandros Chiotellis
fields.text:
The Type Ia supernova (SN Ia) is a sub-category in the supernova classification scheme. Nowadays, there is a consensus that SNe Ia are the result of thermonuclear explosions of CO white dwarfs which accrete mass from a binary companion. However, despite of decays of research the nature of the donor star, the mass transfer process and the explosion mechanism itself remain unclear.

My dissertation aims to provide new insights into the unknown nature of Type Ia supernova progenitors. Specifically, I simulate the interaction of the supernova ejecta with circumstellar structures, which have been formed through mass outflows of the progenitor system, and I study the traces of such an interaction on the dynamical and emission properties of the resulting supernova and supernova remnant. I apply these models on famous SNe Ia (eg. PTF 2011ke) and historical Ia supernova remnants (e.g Kepler, Tycho, RCW 86), attempting to identify imprints of their progenitors on their observables.
fields.teaser_text: On Monday December 16 at 14:00,  Alexandros Chiotellis will defend his thesis titled "The interaction of Type Ia supernovae with their circumstellar medium" in the Agnietenkapel.

fields.title: PhD Defense Thijs Coenen
fields.text:
The main thrust of my thesis work over the last four-and-something years was the search for radio pulsars using the Low Frequency Array (LOFAR). LOFAR is part of a new generation of radio telescopes leading up to the building of the Square Kilometer Array. LOFAR uses a multitude of inexpensive antennas whose signals are combined digitally to create many sensitive, fully steerable, beams on the sky. As part of LOFAR's commissioning we performed two radio pulsar surveys, the LOFAR Pilot Pulsar Survey (LPPS) and the LOFAR Tied-Array Survey (LOTAS). The first of these surveys produced 65 pulsar re-detections and put an upper limit on the fast radio transients rate, while the second survey re-detected 27 pulsars and discovered 2 new pulsars. These discoveries bode well for future, more sensitive, pulsar surveys using LOFAR.

I furthermore worked on two smaller projects; attempts to detect pulsars as binary companions to subdwarf-B stars and an attempt to detect pulsed radio emission from the nearby pulsar Geminga. We were able to exclude pulsed radio emission from the sdB binary companions to a high degree of certainty. For Geminga we failed to confirm earlier claims of radio detections. Since our LOFAR observation was much more sensitive than earlier observations we conclude that the claimed detections were likely spurious, but leave open the possibility that Geminga is an intermittent radio source that turned off.
fields.teaser_text: On Wednesday November 20 at 10:00, Thijs Coenen will defend his thesis titled "Searching for pulsars with LOFAR" in the Agnietenkapel.

fields.title: PhD Defense Lucas Ellerbroek
fields.text:
In this thesis, the process of star formation is mapped from large to small scales, using the world’s most advanced observatories. Discoveries of several young stars with peculiar environments are reported. Dynamics of circumstellar gas and dust are analyzed in a diverse ensemble of young stars. The history of their formation process, impossible to probe directly, is revealed by spectroscopy. Among the outstanding problems addressed are the origin of jets, the scaling of accretion with stellar mass, and the variability of the accretion process.

The star formation process from large to small scale. First, we describe a typical birth environment: a star cluster. We then zoom in on a number of individual systems in this and other star formation regions. The components which make up these objects are the topics of the other chapters: the disk, jets, and finally the young star itself. Throughout, the direct environment of the star is treated as a crime scene. We use it to derive how the star was formed and which stage of its life (or evolution) it has reached. The goal is to describe the formation and evolution of stars as a function of their mass and their surroundings.
fields.location: Aula - Oude Lutherse Kerk, Singel 411, Amsterdam
fields.teaser_text: On Friday March 14 at 13:00, Lucas Ellerbroek will defend his thesis titled "Star Formation History Written in Spectra" in the Aula of the UvA (the Oude Lutherse Kerk).

fields.title: Magnetism and variability in O stars
fields.text:
Cyclical variability is a fundamental property of O-star winds. The physical origin of this variability is still unknown, but is likely linked to processes occuring close to or at the stellar photosphere. Recently, observational evidence has been found for the presence of (localized) surface magnetic fields in several O-type stars, which may play an important role in producing (co-rotating) large-scale structures in their radiation-driven winds. This conference will address the current developments in this field of research, a central theme in Huib Henrichs' professional career.

For more information see: http://www.astro.uva.nl/ostars/

fields.title: Nederlandse Sterrenkunde Olympiade 2014
fields.text:
De Nederlandse Sterrenkunde Olympiade (NeSO) is een jaarlijkse wedstrijd tussen middelbare scholieren en wordt dit jaar georganiseerd door het Sterrenkundig Instituut 'Anton Pannekoek' van de Universiteit van Amsterdam.

De Olympiade is bedoeld voor alle bovenbouwleerlingen van HAVO en VWO met een interesse in natuurkunde, die het leuk vinden om uitgedaagd te worden. De sterrenkunde houdt zich bezig met de meest extreme objecten in de natuur: van atoom tot sterrenstelsels, van de bijna lege ruimte tussen de sterren tot hoge dichtheden in witte dwergen en neutronensterren, en van ijskoude asteroïden tot  miljarden graden in hete plasma's.  Deelnemers aan de Sterrenkunde Olympiade worden uitgedaagd om zich te verdiepen in deze en andere sterrenkundige onderwerpen.

Meedoen aan de Sterrenkunde Olympiade 2014 is eenvoudig. In de voorronde maak je een aantal meerkeuzevragen en een paar open vragen; deze vragenlijst kun je vrijblijvend downloaden op www.sterrenkundeolympiade.nl. Als je besluit om mee te doen maak je de opgaven en stuur je de antwoorden naar ons op. Registreren is dus niet nodig.

Door het insturen van de antwoorden (uiterlijk 20 mei 2014) maak je kans op een plek in de finale. Wij kijken de ingestuurde antwoorden na en nodigen de beste 15 inzenders uit om voor drie dagen naar Amsterdam te komen. De finalisten volgen van 18 t/m 20 juni aan de Universiteit van Amsterdam colleges over een aantal sterrenkundige onderwerpen. Daarnaast is er natuurlijk tijd voor ontspanning.

Na de colleges volgt een examen met vragen over de onderwerpen die tijdens de colleges zijn behandeld. De Olympiade wordt afgesloten met een feestelijke prijsuitreiking. De hoofdprijs van de Sterrenkunde Olympiade is traditiegetrouw een waarneemreis naar het Roque de los Muchachos Observatory op La Palma (Canarische Eilanden), waar met een professionele telescoop kan worden waargenomen.

Zie voor meer informatie onze website www.sterrenkundeolympiade.nl of onze facebook-pagina (www.facebook.com/sterrenkundeolympiade). We zijn ook te vinden op Twitter (@astrolympiade).

Vragen? Mail ons gerust op info@sterrenkundeolympiade.nl!

fields.title: PhD Defense Salome Dibi
fields.text: Sagittarius A* in our Galactic Center is the closest supermassive black hole and therefore offers incomparable opportunities to study the physical phenomenon around black holes in general. In this thesis I study the physics of the hot accretion flow onto Sagittarius A*. Using numerical simulations I model the black hole system and analyse the effects of the radiative losses on the dynamics and the resulting spectra. I drive my conclusions by comparing with the numerous and accurate multi multiwavelength observational data from the Galactic Center available from different ground based and spaces based observatories. Not only Sagittarius A* is the best studied and observed black hole but it is also an extremely faint one that we have the chance to be able to see, and its size in the sky allows us to probe the event horizon scale. In the second part of my thesis I am studying the behaviour of the plasma localized very close to the event horizon to understand the observed flares. By calculating the particle distribution and the resulting emission I propose a scenario to reproduce the peculiar radio to X-ray variation during flares. Finally I am looking at numerous flare events to better constrain the physics of this mysterious acceleration processes occurring around Sagittarius A* black hole vicinity.
fields.teaser_text: On Tuesday 1 at 10:00, Salome Dibi will defend her thesis titled "Studying MHD and radiative processes in Sagittarius A*" in the Agnietenkapel.

fields.title: Public lecture by prof. dr. Huib Henrichs
fields.text:
To mark the occasion of his retirement, Professor H.F. (Huib) Henrichs of the Anton Pannekoek Institute for Astronomy will give a public lecture on September 16, 2014. You are cordially and on special request by Prof. Henrichs invited to attend this lecture. The lecture will precede a 3-day scientific conference "Magnetism and variability in O stars", a central theme in Henrichs' scientific work, which will take place in the Rode Hoed in Amsterdam.

 

Education plays an important role in the professional career of Huib Henrichs; his enthusiasm and detailed lectures on astronomy have been highly valued by the students, for over 40 years at the UvA, and more recently at the VU. He has been the initiator and driving force behind the observatory at Science Park, the most modern observatory in the Netherlands.

 

The Anton Pannekoek Observatory (APO) of the University of Amsterdam at Science Park has been now operational for five years. It has grown out to be the most advanced optical observatory in the Netherlands. It is primarily meant for students to work under professional-like and convenient conditions. Highlights of the first five years of its operation will be presented, all from student projects. The presentation includes the most prominent color images, as well as exoplanet transit observations, spectra of planets, comets, stars, planetary nebulae, supernovae and distant quasars, up to 12 billion light years away.

The lecture (in English) will be held in room C1.110, Science Park 904, 1098 XH Amsterdam. For directions on how to get to Science Park by public transport or car, please see: http://www.amsterdamsciencepark.nl/location-facilities/directions.

In the attached map of Science Park, the room is situated where the number ‘904’ in the dark green area is indicated. It is located on the ground floor, directly under the two domes.

The lecture will be followed by an optional tour to the domes and a reception.

Please let us know before 8 September if you will attend the lecture and/or the tour to the domes, and/or the reception by e-mail to secr-astro-science@uva.nl or by telephone on 020-5257491.  Please specify the number of people with which you will be attending.

We look forward to welcoming you on this joyous occasion.

fields.title: PhD Defense Sjors Broersen
fields.text:
Supernovae are some of the most energetic events known in the Universe. For a short time they can shine as bright as their entire Galaxy, allowing us to observe them up till very large distances. Supernovae are the result of the explosion of either a white dwarf, or a star with a mass about five times as large as our own Sun. In the explosion, the material from which this progenitor consisted is flung out into the surrounding space, at velocities of thousands of kilometers per second. This material is heated up to millions of degrees, and keeps on glowing for thousands of years. These glowing remains of the explosion are called supernova remnants.

In this thesis we study supernova remnants by looking at the X-ray radiation emitted by the hot ionized gas, called plasma, of which it consists. The particle densities in these plasmas are very low: about 1 atom cm-3, compared to the 1019 atoms cm-3 in the earth atmosphere. Interactions between the different particles are therefore rare and changes in one part of the plasma take a long time to be communicated to the rest of the plasma. The plasma is therefore said to be out of equilibrium. We studied these non-equilibrium effects to learn more about plasma physics at the extreme conditions present in supernova remnants. In addition, we used it to show that two puzzling supernova remnants, RCW 86 and Kepler, exploded in an environment heavily influenced by its progenitor system.
fields.location: Aula - Oude Lutherse Kerk, Singel 411, Amsterdam
fields.teaser_text: On Wednesday September 10 at 13:00, Sjors Broersen will defend his thesis titled "X-ray spectral analysis of non-equilibrium plasmas in supernova remnants" in the Aula of the UvA (the Oude Lutherse Kerk).

fields.title: PhD Defense Irina Thaler
fields.text:
Magnetic fields influence the solar luminosity and could therefore affect the earth’s climate. In this thesis the magnetic field behavior at the solar surface is studied using realistic 3D MHD simulations.

As one of the main contributors to the TSI (total solar irradiance) variation, we assess the brightness contribution of the small-scale magnetic field. While earlier estimates suggest that the small-scale magnetic structures have a small positive brightness contribution in the order of the TSI variation during one solar cycle, we find an overall small negative brightness contribution.

During one solar cycle newly emerged magnetic flux disappears from view again within 10 days. We studied the physics underlying the dispersal of magnetic fields and find that the speed at which flux disappears increases strongly with initial mean flux density, which we suggest to be the key process of flux disappearance within active complexes. The ‘flux canceling’ process, however, seems to depend only mildly on conditions encountered in subsurface layers.

Conspicuous magnetic phenomena like active regions or sunspots have their origin deep down in the solar interior, but it could be that a small part of the magnetic field is produced near the surface by the convective motion itself. To investigate this possibility we carefully performed a number of simulations, but could not give a definite answer to this question.
fields.teaser_text: On Thursday September 11 at 14:00, Irina Thaler will defend her thesis titled "Solar Surface Magnetism: Selected Topics" in the Agnietenkapel.

fields.title: PhD Defense Daniela Huppenkothen
fields.text:
The research in this thesis details ways to characterise and understand variability in short magnetar bursts. Magnetars, neutron stars with exceptionally strong magnetic fields, show variability on many different time scales. Particularly at high X-ray energies, they show bright bursts that are believed to be created by what we call starquakes: a sudden release of energy that triggers global oscillations of the star's solid crust and possibly the interior. These oscillations, observed in the X-ray light curves of the bright giant flares, are of particular interest, because they have to potential to probe the stellar composition and constrain related nuclear physics.

Because standard statistical methods fail when applied to magnetar bursts, the research in this thesis aims at developing new methods to search for and characterise oscillations in the light curves of short magnetar bursts, and at un- derstanding variability in these sources as well as the underlying physical processes in general. With this new methodology, several oscillations were found in short bursts from two different magnetars, indicating that similar processes are active in both the short recurrent bursts and the longer, brighter giant flares. Additionally, a new model was developed for the underlying aperiodic variability, which, for the first time, allows a comparison of the X-ray variability in magnetar bursts with toy models of the underlying physics.
fields.teaser_text: On Tuesday October 14 at 14:00, Daniela Huppenkothen will defend her thesis titled "A New Statistical Toolbox for Studying Variability in Fast Transients" in the Agnietenkapel.

The multiwavelength view of ionized gas in AGN
fields.text: In this talk I'll review the importance of multiwavelength campaigns in studying the absorbing and emitting ionized gas, often observed outflowing at 100-1000 km/s from regions close to the black hole in active galaxies. I will also take as a test case the large multiwavelength campaign carried out by Chandra/XMM-Newton, HST and FUSE on the bright Seyfert 1 galaxy Mrk279.
fields.speaker: Elisa Costantini
fields.teaser_text: I'll review the importance of multiwavelength campaigns in studying the absorbing and emitting ionized gas, often observed outflowing at 100-1000 km/s from regions close to the black hole in active galaxies.

fields.title: Gravitational lensing: studying the dark universe with light rays.
fields.text: All images of the distant universe we observe are distorted by gravitational lensing: the bending of light rays by gravitational fields. I will explain how gravitational lensing can be used to determine cosmological parameters as well as properties of galaxies, and describe how this will be done with the largest of the ESO public imaging surveys, KiDS.
fields.speaker: Koen Kuiken
fields.teaser_text: All images of the distant universe we observe are distorted by gravitational lensing: the bending of light rays by gravitational fields.

fields.title: The Challenges and Rewards of Seeing the Oldest Light
fields.text: The Cosmic Microwave Background Radiation (CMBR) has already provided us with rich and precise information about the early Universe. A major goal of upcoming CMBR experiments is to reveal the subtle signature of inflation in the CMB polarization pattern which requires unprecedented sensitivity and control of systematics. Large detector arrays are required to reach the necessary sensitivity. The talk will introduce the status and goals of the Q/U Imaging ExperimenT (QUIET). We have deployed highly sensitive prototype arrays of HEMT-based receivers in chip packages at 90(40) GHz with 90 (19) detectors in the Atacama Desert in Chile, a later expansion to 1000 detectors is foreseen. With the 2 frequencies and a careful choice of scan regions there is the promise of effectively dealing with astrophysical foregrounds and accessing precious information about the energy scale of inflation at the GUT scale.
fields.speaker: Dorothea Samtleben
fields.teaser_text: The Cosmic Microwave Background Radiation (CMBR) has already provided us with rich and precise information about the early Universe.

fields.title: White dwarf binaries, mergers, and explosions
fields.text: Stars in binaries often have much more exciting lives, deaths, and afterlives than single ones. I will review the especially varied possibilities involving white dwarfs, which include revival and total annihilation. I will focus on type Ia supernova explosions, and discuss the problems with the standard picture in which unstable fusion is ignited in white dwarfs that approach or are made to exceed the Chandrasekhar mass. These problems would be resolved if instead, as I will propose, the ignition occurs more generally when two carbon-oxygen white dwarfs merge. Along the way, I hope to describe the interesting consequences of two cases, where we turned what were thought to be exciting planets and neutron stars into more mundane white dwarfs.
fields.speaker: Marten van Kerkwijk
fields.teaser_text: Stars in binaries often have much more exciting lives, deaths, and afterlives than single ones. I will review the especially varied possibilities involving white dwarfs, which include revival and total annihilation.

fields.title: A New Method to Investigate Extensive Air Showers: Radio Detection
fields.text:
A new method will be presented to measure extensive air showers. When high-energy cosmic rays impinge on the atmosphere of the Earth they induce an avalanche of secondary particles, the extensive air showers. Many particles in air showers are electrons and positrons. They are deflected in the magnetic field of the Earth and produce synchrotron radiation. This radiation is detected in the frequency range from 10 to 100 MHz.

Recent results of pioneering experiments will be presented. An outlook to future large-scale installations will be given, such as the LOFAR telescope or the Pierre Auger Observatory.
fields.speaker: Jörg Hörandel
fields.teaser_text: A new method will be presented to measure extensive air showers.

fields.title: Master colloquium: Super-orbital variability in low-mass X-ray binaries: a systematic soft and hard X-ray study
fields.text: X-rays, observed in low-mass X-ray binaries (LMXB), originate from the accretion disc. I used data from the Rossi X-ray Timing Explorer All- Sky-Monitor (RXTE-ASM: this telescope observes in soft X-rays) and the Swift Burst-Alert Telescope (Swift-BAT: this telescope observes in hard X-rays) to search for periodicities in the emitted X-rays. As the data from the RXTE-ASM and the Swift-BAT are not evenly spaced, I used the Lomb-Scargle method to search for periodicities in the data. I focussed myself on finding super-orbital periods in 27 LMXBs. Super- orbital periods are periods larger than the orbital period of the system. I found new periodicities, which were not reported in other studies, in the transient sources 4U 1608-522, Aql X-1, 4U 1630-472, rapid burster, GRS 1747-312, GX 339-4, EXO 0748+676, Swift J1753.5- 0127, HETE J1900.1-2455, XTE J1550-564 and GRO J1655-40, in the persistent Z sources Sco X-1, Cyg X-2 and GX 17+2, and in the persistent atoll sources GX 354+0, G X 13+1, GX 9+9, GX 3+1, 4U 1820-303, 4U 1636-536, 4U 1735-44 and 4U 1705-440. I also found a new periodicity during the outburst in EXO 0748-676. In a number of sources, the periodicities can not be reported as true periodicities. The periods may be manifestations of red noise as the Lomb-Scargle power increases towards lower frequencies. Because of a time limit, I have not used Monte Carlo simulations to assess the significance of a signal. Therefor I only reported on super-orbital periods which were above the 5-sigma level. The periodicities found in this study, are discussed and compared with previous studies. I also discuss the possible causes for the observed variability in X-rays: e.g. a warped and precession accretion disc, a triple star model, beats between different frequencies.
fields.speaker: Anita Tol
fields.teaser_text: X-rays, observed in low-mass X-ray binaries, originate from the accretion disc. I used data from the Rossi X-ray Timing Explorer All- Sky-Monitor and the Swift Burst-Alert Telescope to search for periodicities in the emitted X-rays.

fields.title: Master colloquium: The bursting behaviour of AX J1745.7-2901
fields.text: In this talk, the X-ray bursting behaviour of the faint, transient, X-ray binary AX J1745.6-2901 is reported. This dipping and eclipsing source was first observed in 1996 by Maeda and collaborators and has shown several periods of activity since then. We have screened all XMM Newton observations in which this source was in the field of view. A total of eight type I X-ray bursts was detected in the 2007 and 2008 observations. The burst behaviour of this source is very peculiar: the burst profiles, durations and recurrence times change dramatically between the different observations. In addition, the 2008 observation shows a ``sudden'' appearance of four bursts after a period where there are no bursts present at all. I discuss the possible nature of the changes in burst properties between the 2007 and 2008 observations in light of the current X-ray burst theory
fields.speaker: Sjors Broersen
fields.teaser_text: In this talk, the X-ray bursting behaviour of the faint, transient, X-ray binary AX J1745.6-2901 is reported. This dipping and eclipsing source was first observed in 1996 by Maeda and collaborators and has shown several periods of activity since then. We have screened all XMM Newton observations in which this source was in the field of view.

fields.title: Master colloquium: SAX J1808.4-3658: An Extremely Cold Accreting Neutron Star
fields.text: Neutron stars provide the only way to study the behavior of matter at extreme densities. Crucial in understanding matter under these conditions are the heating and cooling processes that take place in accreting neutron stars, because the resulting radiation provides the only probe of the neutron star interior. Determining the heating and cooling rates is challenging, because they depend on the long-term average accretion rate heating the neutron star, and the systems cannot be observed for the required period of time. The aim of this project is to put constraints on the long-term accretion rate for the accreting neutron star SAX J1808.4-3658, which has a very low observed accretion rate and thus appears to be very cold. This was done by generating 10 kyr long lightcurves using random variables, and checking these lightcurves for a set of outbursts that match the observations. The analysis of the results shows that the cooling rate is not seriously affected by the uncertainty on the mass accretion history. The conclusion is that SAX J1808.4 is indeed extremely cold and cools down on very short timescales. This requires the presence of exotic processes in the neutron star interior, unless some unknown physical phenomenon makes the source colder than it should be.
fields.speaker: Frank Tramper
fields.teaser_text: Neutron stars provide the only way to study the behavior of matter at extreme densities. Crucial in understanding matter under these conditions are the heating and cooling processes that take place in accreting neutron stars, because the resulting radiation provides the only probe of the neutron star interior.

fields.title: Master colloquium: "Assessing the Impact of UV/X-ray Emission from Accreting Black Holes on the ISM"
fields.text: Physical models of jets and accretion disks seen in X-ray binaries crucially depend on good multi-wavelength data from radio wavelengths to gamma rays.However, observations in the UV are very difficult to obtain, as most known black-hole binaries lie in the galactic plane and are thus heavily obscured by dust and gas which scatter, absorb and reprocess the emission. Fortunately there is a way to indirectly estimate the flux in UV. Since an X-ray binary with its strong short-wavelength emission is an ionizing source, it is expected to create an ionized nebula: an HII region. It is known that in HII regions UV radiation is absorbed and subsequently reemitted in optical, infrared and millimeter continuum as well as line emission. At these wavelengths, observations are possible and in fact numerous. In this colloquium, I present first results from numerical simulations of the environment around black-hole binaries. We developed a physically realistic model for the medium around two galactic X-ray binaries, Cygnus X-1 and GX 339-4, using the photoionization code Cloudy. These enable us to show the effect the medium has on the source spectrum, make predictions for future observational campaigns as well as point out implications for current simulations modeling the physical processes inside black-hole binaries. I will also discuss the potential this work may have for predictions for the first X-ray binaries and the early universe.
fields.speaker: Daniela Huppenkothen
fields.teaser_text: Physical models of jets and accretion disks seen in X-ray binaries crucially depend on good multi-wavelength data from radio wavelengths to gamma rays. However, observations in the UV are very difficult to obtain, as most known black-hole binaries lie in the galactic plane and are thus heavily obscured by dust and gas which scatter, absorb and reprocess the emission.

fields.title: Direct and coronographic Imaging of Extrasolar Planets
fields.text:
The direct imaging of extrasolar planets allows us to investigate
systems with longer orbital periods, test competing planet formation
mechanisms, and to begin investigating their chemical structure and
evolution. Many direct imaging surveys rely on enhanced emission at
the H and K bands to help detect a planet against the nearby glare of
their host stars.

At the MMTO and VLT, we are carrying out surveys for giant planets at
3 to 5 microns, where we are sensitive to lower effective temperature
objects around nearby stars. I will present some of our latest results
using both direct and coronagraphic imaging techniques.
fields.speaker: Matthew Kenworthy
fields.teaser_text:

fields.title: Christmas Colloquium
fields.text:
This year's Christmas colloquium will be given by Sander Bais, who received the Stapenning this year, a special UvA honorary award.

 

Sander Bais is a specialist in phenomena relating to topology, such as magnetic monopoles. In recent years, he has increasingly concentrated on communicating scientific findings to a broad audience, and he will give a very special colloquium for the astronomical institute.
fields.speaker: Sander Bais
fields.teaser_text: This year's Christmas colloquium will be given by Sander Bais, who received the Stapenning this year, a special UvA honorary award.

fields.title: A Closer Look At Type Ia Supernova Progenitors
fields.text: Despite decades of intensive work, the identity of the progenitor systems of Type Ia Supernovae (Ia SNe) still remains obscure. Most past efforts in this field have concentrated on the study of extragalactic SNe, which are too distant to examine in detail. I will describe a series of projects designed to shift the emphasis from distant objects to nearby ones: Type Ia Supernova Remnants and binary White Dwarfs in our own galactic backyard. For Type Ia Supernova Remnants, modern X-ray satellites like Chandra and XMM-Newton have accumulated excellent data sets that can pot strong constraints on the properties of SN Ia progenitors. For binary White Dwarfs, the spectroscopic data base of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey can be used to characterize this poorly known population of potential SN Ia progenitors with an unprecedented level of accuracy.

fields.teaser_text: Despite decades of intensive work, the identity of the progenitor systems of Type Ia Supernovae (Ia SNe) still remains obscure. Most past efforts in this field have concentrated on the study of extragalactic SNe, which are too distant to examine in detail. fields.title: Master colloquium: Exploring the most massive stars beyond the Local Group
fields.text: As part of the X-Shooter science verification, we obtained the first intermediate-resolution spectrum of a massive star candidate in NGC~55, an LMC like galaxy at a distance of ~2.0 Mpc. Based on the morphological analysis of the UBV (300-550~nm) and VIS (550-1000~nm) spectrum and on the modelling of the nebular and atmospheric lines, we investigated the nature and evolutionary status of the central object and its influence on the surrounding interstellar medium.
fields.speaker: Olga Hartoog
fields.teaser_text: As part of the X-Shooter science verification, we obtained the first intermediate-resolution spectrum of a massive star candidate in NGC~55, an LMC like galaxy at a distance of ~2.0 Mpc.

fields.title: Master colloquium: Evaluation of mass loss in the simulation of stellar clusters using a new multiphysics software environment
fields.text:
In this research project stellar evolution and stellar dynamics are combined in the simulation of stellar clusters and binary systems. The numerical approximations are done using a fairly new software framework written in Python. This framework is called AMUSE, an abbreviation of Astrophysical MUltipurpose Software Environment. In contrary to the monolithic approach, where a software package that first covers one astrophysical domain is extended to also cover another domain, AMUSE uses a modular approach. This means that existing packages, which are well-tested within their own domain, can be combined. AMUSE handles the communication and unit conversion between these different modules. The phiGRAPE and Hermite0 direct n-body integrators were combined with a fast, fitting formulae based, stellar evolution program called Single Star Evolution (SSE). The programs currently interact as followed: first a dynamical step is taken, at which the n-body integrator synchronizes all the particles to the same time. This step is then followed by an instant step of stellar evolution: the stellar evolution program sends an updated list of masses, based on the new global time, to the stellar dynamics program.
The following questions were investigated: Is this method accurate? Do decreasing time steps, for mass loss, at some point converge to the same result, and what is the most efficient time step?
fields.speaker: Guillermo Kardolus
fields.teaser_text: In this research project stellar evolution and stellar dynamics are combined in the simulation of stellar clusters and binary systems. The numerical approximations are done using a fairly new software framework written in Python. This framework is called AMUSE, an abbreviation of Astrophysical MUltipurpose Software Environment.

fields.title: The dark and the light:  Black holes, dark halos, and their influence on galaxy evolution
fields.text:
Recent galaxy formation models have demonstrated the that galaxy
evolution is driven by effects in addition to those associated with
star formation and stellar evolution.  In particular, the growth of
the central black hole and the mass of the parent dark halo can
strongly influence the formation of stars and the gas content of
galaxies.  I will review some recent observational studies of the
relation between AGN and their host galaxies and environments, and
will discuss which evolutionary phases and classes of AGN are
responsible for the bulk of the energy input into galaxies.    I will
then outline some recent work on the spatial clustering of
star-forming galaxies selected in the mid-infrared and submm to
constrain the influence of halo mass on different phases of star
formation.
fields.speaker: Ryan Hickox
fields.teaser_text:

evolution is driven by effects in addition to those associated with

fields.title: Modelling and Observing the Gas in Protoplanetary Systems
fields.text:
Numerous enigmas still need to be solved, and open questions to be answered, in the field of protoplanetary disc research and planet formation. Most key processes (turbulence & dust settling, disc flaring, shape of inner rim, radial disc extension etc.) are controlled by the gas rather than by the dust. Thus, we need to observe the gas component, and we need to unify gas and dust disc models to improve our understanding of protoplanetary discs.

The interpretation of gas line observations are intrinsically more difficult, because of the complexity of excitation mechanisms involved. I will present ProDiMo, a radiation thermo-chemical disc code, which captures many aspects of our current understanding of physical and chemical processes in discs. It includes vertical hydrostatic equilibrium, gas phase, UV-photo and X-ray chemistry, gas-grain chemistry, 2D continuum radiative transfer, detailed gas heating/cooling processes, detailed line radiative transfer, and spatial decoupling of gas and dust.

The Herschel open time key programme GASPS is the first large survey of gas in 250 discs around young stars in the critical age range between 1 and 30 Myrs. It uses PACS line scans to detect atomic finestructure lines of [OI] and [CII], and molecular lines of CO, OH and H2O, altogether 450 hours of Herschel observing time. In my talk, I will show how the first results fit into the models, and will discuss what we can learn from
these far-IR emission lines.
fields.speaker: Peter Woitke
fields.teaser_text: Numerous enigmas still need to be solved, and open questions to be answered, in the field of protoplanetary disc research and planet formation.

fields.title: Draft-strategy for NOVA participation E-ELT
fields.text:
As agreed on at last Board meeting I will visit each of the university

fields.title: How gamma-rays can probe the early universe
fields.text: The end of the dark-ages of the universe - the epoch of reionization - is a one of the big open questions in cosmology. Reionization likely started with the formation of the first stars (PopIII stars), which are believed to be hotter and (probably) more massive then the second generation stars. Such massive PopIII stars produce a strong feedback on their environment efficiently enriching their surrounding with heavier elements and thereby paving the way for a second generation of stars. Direct detection of these objects in the early universe is still pending and will be a challenging task for the next generation optical instruments (JWST). An indirect way of probing their properties come through the investigation of the diffuse meta-galactic radiation fields: they contain the integrated emission of all sources through the history of the universe. Objects in the early universe can potentially leave a signature in these radiation fields at infrared wavelengths (extragalactic background light; EBL). Direct measurements of the EBL are difficult but lower limits can be derived from integrated source counts. Upper limits come from the observations of distant sources of very-high energy gamma-rays, which can interact with the low energy photons at IR wavelength via the pair production process effectively leaving an energy dependent attenuation signature in the measured VHE spectra. In this presentation recent constrains on the EBL will be discussed and utilize to investigate the properties of objects in the early universe. In particular, properties of early stars will be investigated and in this context the impact of dark matter on the early star formation (Dark Star phase) will be discussed.
fields.speaker: Martin Raue
fields.teaser_text: The end of the dark-ages of the universe - the epoch of reionization - is a one of the big open questions in cosmology. fields.title: Astrometry Lost and Regained
fields.affiliation: Niels Bohr Institute, Copenhagen University, Denmark
fields.text: Technological and scientific developments during the past century made a new branch of astronomy flourish, i.e. astrophysics, and resulted in our present deep understanding of the whole Universe. But this brought astrometry almost to extinction because it was considered to be dull and old-fashioned, especially by young astronomers. Astrometry is the much older branch of astronomy, in fact 2000 years of age, which performs accurate measurements of positions, motions and distances of stars and other celestial bodies. Astrometric data are of great scientific and practical importance for investigation of celestial phenomena and also for control of telescopes and satellites and for monitoring of Earth rotation. Our main subject is the development during the 20th century which finally made astrometry flourish as an integral part of astronomy through the success of the Hipparcos astrometric satellite, soon to be followed by the even more powerful Gaia mission.
fields.speaker: Erik Hoeg
fields.teaser_text: From a modest experiment in Copenhagen in 1925 to the Hipparcos and Gaia space missions.

fields.title: The Highly Obscured supergiant High Mass X-ray Binaries: a new class discovered by ESA's INTEGRAL satellite
fields.text:
Since its launch in 2002, the gamma-ray plus hard X-ray satellite
INTEGRAL discovered over 500 new X-ray sources. Among these are some
22 new galactic supergiant High Mass X-ray Binaries, three times more
than the 7  such systems known in our galaxy before INTEGRAL. These
newly discovered X-ray sources often are slow X-ray pulsars,
accompanied by O or B-type supergiants. Their orbital periods range
from a few days to over 160 days. For some reason the absorpion of the
soft X-rays by circumstellar matter around these systems is larger
than around the previously known supergiant systems, which is the
reason why they were not discovered by earlier X-ray satellites.
The possible reasons for this high obscuration and for the flaring
behaviour of this new class of X-ray binaries, as well as their
evolutionary status and final fate, will be discussed.
fields.speaker: Ed van den Heuvel
fields.teaser_text: Since its launch in 2002, the gamma-ray plus hard X-ray satellite INTEGRAL discovered over 500 new X-ray sources. Among these are some 22 new galactic supergiant High Mass X-ray Binaries, three times more than the 7  such systems known in our galaxy before INTEGRAL.

fields.title: What's around nearby stars: dust, debris and planets
fields.text: Some 400 nearby stars are known to have orbiting extrasolar planets, and a similar number are known to have orbiting debris, i.e., dust, asteroids and comets. Just as in the Solar System, observations of extrasolar debris disks provide unique information on the structure, formation and evolution of the planetary systems in which they reside. They have even been used to predict the presence of unseen planets that have later been confirmed through direct imaging. As the numbers of systems found to have both extrasolar planets and debris disks grows, the connection between these two phenomena is becoming clearer. In this colloquium I will describe what we have learnt about what's around nearby stars from studies of their debris disks, including results from the recent NASA Spitzer Space Telescope and ESA's currently operating Herschel Space Observatory.
fields.speaker: Mark Wyatt
fields.teaser_text: Some 400 nearby stars are known to have orbiting extrasolar planets, and a similar number are known to have orbiting debris, i.e., dust, asteroids and comets. Just as in the Solar System, observations of extrasolar debris disks provide unique information on the structure, formation and evolution of the planetary systems in which they reside.

fields.title: Master Colloquium - Superspinning black holes: theory and practice
fields.text: Black holes, as described by Einstein's general theory of relativity, can posses angular momentum, but only a limited amount: too much angular momentum and the event horizon of the black holes disappears, giving rise to a naked singularity, i.e. a singularity not hidden behind an event horizon. The cosmic censorship conjecture states this should never happen. Some theories, however, suggest that there may be supersymmetric objects with a spin higher than the relativistic upper bound. We will take a look at iron fluorescence lines, which have been observed in the spectra emitted by black holes. The profiles of these lines can bear a signature of the relativistic effects of the black hole, which may allow us to measure its spin. The line profiles can be calculated using a computer code, which we then use to try and fit a model to the emitted spectrum of the X-ray binary Cygnus X-1.
fields.speaker: Peter van Ham
fields.teaser_text: Black holes, as described by Einstein's general theory of relativity, can posses angular momentum, but only a limited amount: too much angular momentum and the event horizon of the black holes disappears, giving rise to a naked singularity, i.e. a singularity not hidden behind an event horizon.

fields.title: Master Colloquium: Dynamical scattering of planetesimals by a migrating planet
fields.text: A small number of young stellar objects show signs of a halo-like structure of optically thin dust, in addition to a circumstellar disk. This halo or torus is located within a few AU of the star but its origin is not yet understood. One possible explanation is a dynamically excited cloud of planetesimals colliding to eventually form dust. The cause of the dynamical excitation could be one or more planets on perhaps eccentric orbits or a migrating planet. This work investigates a migrating planet dynamically scattering planetesimals as a possible cause. The effect of the migrating planet is studied in two ways; a symplectic integrator is used to simulate the effect on a population of planetesimals, and, analytical estimates on the maximum inclination reached due to dynamical interactions are provided and shown to be in agreement with the simulations. The effect of planetesimals being captured in the migrating planet’s resonances, and as a result having their eccentricities raised, proves to play an pivotal role and is discussed. Collision timescales are calculated for the resulting populations of planetesimals and the size distribution of dust created in their collisions is determined. Estimates of the optical depth of the dust distribution are given and it is shown to be possible to create halo-like dust clouds with optical depths below unity for a large number of configurations. In conclusion, dynamical scattering of planetesimals due to a migrating planet, followed by the grinding down of these planetesimals to dust grains, appears to be a promising explanation for the inferred circumstellar halos.
fields.speaker: Sebastiaan Krijt
fields.teaser_text: A small number of young stellar objects show signs of a halo-like structure of optically thin dust, in addition to a circumstellar disk. This halo or torus is located within a few AU of the star but its origin is not yet understood.

fields.title: Strange star, pion gas, hydrodynamics, nuclear-particle physics & astrophysics
fields.text:
I will briefly review our model for strange stars where quarks have masses varying  with density and chiral symmetry plays an important part.  The pions can couple to quarks unlike the bag model but the coupling decreases with higher density. The quarks are allowed to interact with a potential which has asymptotic freedom and confinement built into it with parameters tested to give right baryon masses and magnetic moments. The model uses the 1/colour as an expansion parameter so that quark loops and non-planar gluon diagrams are suppressed and one can use simple Hartree-Fock like self consistency with a Dirac equation to obtain a mean field.

Then I will move onto viscosity/entropy density bound given by KSS  that  attracted lot of attention recently. On the theoretical side counter examples have been posted - but these are for hypothetical systems as many people have pointed out. Theoretical intuitive ideas from Fouxon, Betschart and Bekenstein (FBB) and Hod have persuaded many like me that the conjectured KSS bound is true. There have been theoretical calculations in different densities and temperatures , T,  in systems like pion gas in simple kinetic  theory with interaction  (Prakash et al., Phys. Rep. C 227 (1993) 321). We  have shown that  the bound is saturated when density dependence is properly utilized. On the exotic side strange matter on the surface of a quark star satisfies the bound at a critical T. Other calculations using Chiral perturbation theory and thermo-field dynamics are also remarkable and will be briefly discussed.

On the observation side from water to liquid helium or nitrogen and even heavy ion experiments have been looked at. I hope the excitement will persist as this is very beautiful and simple physics.

fields.title: No API colloquium (Defense Maciej Serylak), but Paul Groot is at IFTA
fields.text:
Stellar binaries as sources of low-frequency gravitational waves

Ultracompact binaries formed of two stellar remnants are the only known, steady sources of gravitational waves in the low frequency regime that will be covered by the LISA gravitational wave detector. In the talk I will give an introduction into the physics of these ultracompact binaries that consist of two burnt-out cores of stars in orbits smaller than the Earth-Moon system, and orbital periods as short as 5 minutes. An overview will be given of the Galactic population of these systems, our efforts to find and characterize this population and the impact these systems will have on the prospects for LISA.

For more information see: http://www.science.uva.nl/research/itf/theoretical.php
fields.speaker: Paul Groot
fields.teaser_text: Paul Groot speaks at IFTA about stellar binaries as sources of low-frequency gravitational waves.

fields.title: A search for a possible variation of the proton-to-electron mass ratio in the sightline towards J2123-0050
fields.text: We report a strong constraint on the variation of the proton-to-electron mass ratio on a cosmological time scale from the analyses of molecular absorption lines in a quasar spectrum. A possible variation of the proton-to-electron ratio, one of the constants of nature, would directly violate the Einstein's equivalence principle. A high quality, high resolution spectrum with observed molecular absorption lines at z=2.059 towards the sightline of J2123-0050 was observed at VLT using the UVES spectrograph. Using our model, fitting 96 molecular hydrogen transitions, the highest number in such an analysis so far, we constrain the variation relative to the laboratory value. This result will be discussed in the perspective of other findings so far resulting from studies of hydrogen absorption at high redshift.
fields.speaker: Freek van Weerdenburg
fields.teaser_text: We report a strong constraint on the variation of the proton-to-electron mass ratio on a cosmological time scale from the analyses of molecular absorption lines in a quasar spectrum.

fields.title: Weak lensing by large scale structure
fields.text: Intervening structures in the universe give rise to small distortions in the shapes of distant galaxies. By measuring this tiny coherent signal, we can study the mass distribution in the universe directly, without relying  on baryonic tracers. This makes weak lensing by large-scale structures a powerful probe of cosmology. It allows us to differentiate between dark energy models or modifications of the law of gravity. I will review the topic of cosmic shear and discuss how the signal is extracted from the data and present results from recent surveys, most notably the CFHT Legacy Survey and discuss what can be expected in the near future.
fields.speaker: Henk Hoekstra
fields.teaser_text: Intervening structures in the universe give rise to small distortions in the shapes of distant galaxies. By measuring this tiny coherent signal, we can study the mass distribution in the universe directly, without relying  on baryonic tracers.

fields.title: Transiting Exoplanets
fields.text: One of the most exciting discoveries in astronomy in recent years has been the detection of planets orbiting other stars than the sun. Now, fundamental questions can be addressed about the origin and uniqueness of the solar system, and Earth in particular. While the exoplanet population is rapidly being deciphered, and the hunt for rocky Earth-like planets has begun, amazing properties about the atmospheres of the hottest exoplanets are being determined. In Leiden we are building up a strong expertise in ground-based observations - probing exoplanet atmospheres at very high spectral resolution.
fields.speaker: Ignas Snellen
fields.teaser_text: One of the most exciting discoveries in astronomy in recent years has been the detection of planets orbiting other stars than the sun. Now, fundamental questions can be addressed about the origin and uniqueness of the solar system, and Earth in particular.

fields.title: Radio louder and radio quieter microquasars
fields.text: The recently discovered microquasar S26 in NGC 7793 is the most powerful non-nuclear jet source known to date. It suggests that accreting black holes may be jet dominated even at near-Eddington accretion rates. Sources like S26 can be used as a local test for feedback models in quasars. Conversely, other microquasars appear about 30 times fainter in the radio than expected from their X-ray luminosities and accretion rates. I argue that there is now evidence for the existence of radio loud(er) and radio quiet(er) classes of non-nuclear black holes, perhaps similar to the corresponding classes of AGN.
fields.speaker: Roberto Soria
fields.teaser_text: The recently discovered microquasar S26 in NGC 7793 is the most powerful non-nuclear jet source known to date. It suggests that accreting black holes may be jet dominated even at near-Eddington accretion rates.

fields.title: NOVA colloquium: UV tracers of the Hidden Side of Galaxy Evolution
fields.text: The Galaxy Evolution Explorer (GALEX) continues its surveys of the ultraviolet sky. GALEX surveys have supported the following galaxy evolution investigations: calibrating UV as a star formation rate tracer, using wide and deep surveys to measure star formation history, studying the evolution of dust extinction and metallicity, selecting and analyzing galaxies in transitory states, finding local analogs to Lyman Break Galaxies, probing and time-dating star formation in a wide variety of physical regimes. Our continuing mission is focussed on relating star formation history and galaxy evolution paths to the properties of dark matter halos and their assembly history, and on beginning to relate the evolution of galaxies to that of black holes and the intergalactic medium. GALEX has proven that the UV is an ideal band to find and map star formation in low mass, low density objects, and potentially in primordial gas. With future UV missions it may be possible to map emission from the intergalactic and circum-galactic medium, and make a definitive connection between galaxy evolution and the cooling, accretion, heating, and enrichment of gas in the cosmic web.
fields.speaker: Chris Martin
fields.teaser_text: The Galaxy Evolution Explorer (GALEX) continues its surveys of the ultraviolet sky. GALEX surveys have supported the following galaxy evolution investigations: calibrating UV as a star formation rate tracer, using wide and deep surveys to measure star formation history, studying the evolution of dust extinction and metallicity, selecting and analyzing galaxies in transitory states, finding local analogs to Lyman Break Galaxies, probing and time-dating star formation in a wide variety of physical regimes.

fields.title: Black holes and neutron stars in globular clusters
fields.text: I will review the theoretical ideas that caused a prevailing view that there should be no stellar mass black holes in globular clusters.  I will then discuss the observations of extragalactic globular clusters - both determinations of which cluster properties make a cluster most likely to host X-ray sources, and the variety of X-ray sources within those clusters.  I will show evidence for the first few globular clusters which do host stellar mass black holes, and discuss their (sometimes) odd observational appearance.
fields.speaker: Tom Maccarone
fields.teaser_text: I will review the theoretical ideas that caused a prevailing view that there should be no stellar mass black holes in globular clusters.

fields.title: Unraveling the Nature of Hanny's Voorwerp
fields.text: Hanny's Voorwerp is one of the signature discoveries to emerge from the Galaxy Zoo project. This galactic scale nebula was discovered by citizen scientist - Hanny van Arkel - a Dutch school teacher from Heerlen. The nature of the Voorwerp ("Object" in dutch) is currently a topic of some debate. WSRT observations suggest that the nebula is probably associated with material that has been stripped from a galaxy during an encounter with another system. One hypothesis is that the nearby galaxy IC2497 hosts a quasar which irradiated the nebula some 100 million years ago but has subsequently switched off. I will present recent high resolution radio observations of the system, together with the latest X-ray and HST results.
fields.speaker: Mike Garrett
fields.teaser_text: Hanny's Voorwerp is one of the signature discoveries to emerge from the Galaxy Zoo project.  I will present recent high resolution radio observations of the system, together with the latest X-ray and HST results.

fields.title: On the Origin of Gravity
fields.text: Insights black hole physics together with developments in string theory strongly indicate that inertial forces, including the gravitational force, arise from an underlying microscopic description of our universe in which there is no gravity. Starting from first principles we argue that gravity is a reaction force caused by the fact that changes in the positions of material objects influence the phase space volume associated with the microscopic system.  Near event horizons the gravitational (or inertial) force degenerates into a thermodynamic entropic force, and becomes susceptible to thermal fluctuations. Application of these ideas to cosmology leads to surprising new insights into the nature of dark energy and dark matter.
fields.speaker: Erik Verlinde
fields.teaser_text: Starting from first principles we argue that gravity is a reaction force caused by the fact that changes in the positions of material objects influence the phase space volume associated with the microscopic system.

fields.title: X-ray binaries: Miniature scale models of quasars?
fields.text:
Accretion is one of the major sources of energy in the universe and is
thought to play a major role in the evolution of galaxies through
feedback via active galactic nuclei (AGN). I will introduce the
properties of efficient and inefficient accretion flows as well as
their associated jets. I argue that both accretion modes are indeed
realized in nature. The central engines of all accreting sources,
consisting of the compact object, the accretion flow, a corona and a
jet, is basically scale invariant. One of the best template for those
high redshift AGN providing the feedback needed to shape the galaxy
luminosity function will thus be nearby black hole X-ray binaries
accreting near the Eddington limit.
fields.speaker: Elmar Koerding
fields.teaser_text:

fields.title: Direct imaging of protoplanetary disks in scattered light
fields.text: Circumstellar disks around pre-main-sequence stars are believed to be birthplaces of planets, and thus an investigation of disk properties is of primary importance to understand the process of planet building. Direct imaging of such protoplanetary disks provides valuable information on the distribution of disk material that may be linked to the presence of unseen planets. Imaging has been challenging due to small sizes of disks and high contrast ratios relative to the central stars. However, resolving the structure on about 10 AU or less spatial scales is now possible in near-infrared by employing adaptive optics even from the ground. I present the recent effort to directly image protoplanetary disks using the Japanese Subaru telescope, focusing on disks around Herbig Ae stars. The images reveal the considerable diversity in disk structure such as spiral arms, inner holes, and gaps. These features are likely to be caused by evolutionary effects including planet building, as well as stellar multiplicity or initial disk mass. I also show some results of imaging polarimetry which is a powerful technique to detect scattered light and to study dust grains in the upper layers of protoplanetary disks.

fields.title: A Question of Survival: Dust Evolution in the ISM
fields.text: Recent research seems to imply that silicate and carbonaceous dust (including polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon, PAH, materials) may follow different evolutionary pathways in their sojourn through the interstellar medium (ISM) from their birth-sites. For example, it now appears that the carbonaceous dust component may not be as resilient as its ever-present companion, silicate dust. A major and unavoidable conclusion of this is that ‘graphite-like’ materials are probably not going to be able to re-form in the ISM and that they are therefore not a tenable model for the bulk of the interstellar carbon-rich dust. Nevertheless, it seems that some form of carbonaceous dust clearly needs to be reformed in the ISM. This dust is probably some form of hydrogenated amorphous carbon. In this talk I will consider the survivability of dust in the ISM and how that dust must evolve in response to the local conditions. The primary agents that drive dust evolution in the ISM are irradiation by UV photons, and irradiation by ions and electrons in interstellar shock waves and cosmic rays. In an attempt to ‘put it all together’ I will also re-visit the question of the ‘dust lifetime’ in the ISM and whether such a globally-applied concept really has any useful meaning in the sense that it is usually used.
fields.speaker: Anthony Jones
fields.teaser_text: Recent research seems to imply that silicate and carbonaceous dust (including polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon, PAH, materials) may follow different evolutionary pathways in their sojourn through the interstellar medium (ISM) from their birth-sites.

fields.title: Formation and growth of Supermassive Black Holes
fields.text: Supermassive black holes are now known to inhabit the nuclei of most nearby large galaxies. However, many aspects of how these black holes formed, how they grew via mergers and accretion, and how they influence galactic structure, remain unknown. I will review my most recent theoretical work towards the understanding of these problems, before focusing on the question of how we might detect the coalescence of binary black holes in a gas rich environment.
fields.speaker: Elena Rossi
fields.teaser_text: Supermassive black holes are now known to inhabit the nuclei of most nearby large galaxies. I will focus on the question of how we might detect the coalescence of binary black holes in a gas rich environment.

fields.title: Exploring early stars and galaxies with gamma-ray bursts
fields.text:
The earliest stars and proto-galaxies in the Universe are thought to have formed within the first few hundred million years after the Big Bang.  However, these sources are faint and at such distances, immensely challenging to detect
directly.  Gamma-ray bursts, thanks to their immense luminosities, can easily
be seen at very high redshifts, and so offer an alternative route to exploring the early formation of structure in the Universe.  They act as beacons of massive star formation and offer the chance to probe the properties and environments of these early galaxies, and their effects on the intergalactic medium.  GRB 090423, which at redshift 8.2 was the most distant spectroscopically confirmed object at its discovery, opens the door to such studies. I will review what we have learnt from that event and other high redshift GRBs, and consider prospects for the future.
