fields.title: Bayesian Inference from Photometric Surveys
fields.text: With the upcoming survey telescopes just around the corner, the statistical and computational challenges of astronomy are more prominent than ever. I will discuss some of the fundamental issues that are at the core of all photometric analyses. A powerful Bayesian approach is introduced for cross-identifying astronomical sources, which is extendable, e.g., to incorporate models of spectral energy distributions, to accommodate the proper motion of stars, or to match transient events in space and time. Probabilistic inferences open up new possibilities for determining properties of celestial objects based on their photometric observations. Constraints on photometric redshifts and other physical parameters in the more general inversion problem are derived from first principles that also point us toward the next steps.
fields.speaker: Tamas Budavari
fields.teaser_text: With the upcoming survey telescopes just around the corner, the statistical and computational challenges of astronomy are more prominent than ever. I will discuss some of the fundamental issues that are at the core of all photometric analyses.

fields.title: The mid-transit time of Exoplanet XO-2b
fields.text: Timing of eclipsing exoplanets yields important information on their orbital properties. We observed a transit of the exoplanet XO-2b, a ’hot Jupiter’ that orbits a sun-like star with a visual magnitude of V=11.3, and determined the mid-transit time. We performed 272 minutes of white-light photometry with the 35 cm VU telescope, and made a least-squares fit to the observed data with a detailed model. We developed the model to take into account the limb-darkening of the star, the relative size and several orbital parameters of the planet into account. We determined JD = 2454830.4892 ± 0.0015 for the mid-eclipse time, which implies with earlier data a constant orbital period of 2.615859 ± 0.000003 days, which is more accurate than earlier results. New observations will allow an even better determination of the period.
fields.speaker: Felix ter Beek
fields.teaser_text: Timing of eclipsing exoplanets yields important information on their orbital properties. We observed a transit of the exoplanet XO-2b, a ’hot Jupiter’ that orbits a sun-like star with a visual magnitude of V=11.3, and determined the mid-transit time.

fields.title: Staring down the gravity well: how to decode compact object variability
fields.text: Flux variability is ubiquitous in accreting compact objects, from stellar-mass neutron stars and black holes in X-ray binary systems to supermassive black holes in Active Galactic Nuclei. Simple light-travel-time constraints imply that the variability encodes information about the very innermost regions close to the black hole event horizon or neutron star surface, where most of the accretion power in the universe is released and powerful jets - on the largest scales capable of sculpting galaxy clusters - are produced. But how do we decode the variability, to reveal the secrets within? I will discuss my work in solving this problem, using a combination of new techniques and multiwavelength data to show that the variability originates in a turbulent accretion disc. I will then show how we can use this information to map the structure of these most extreme regions of the universe.
fields.speaker: Phil Uttley
fields.teaser_text: Flux variability is ubiquitous in accreting compact objects, from stellar-mass neutron stars and black holes in X-ray binary systems to supermassive black holes in Active Galactic Nuclei.

fields.title: Rapid X-ray variability in black hole low-mass X-ray binaries - recent progress
fields.text: Rapid X-ray variability in low-mass X-ray binaries originates in the poorly understood inner regions of the accretion flow. In this talk I report on recent progress made in the field of rapid X-ray variability in black hole X-ray binaries, both observational and theoretical. I start with a general discussion of accretion states and will show how the various types of variability relate to these accretion states. In particular, transitions between different types of variability may be connected to changes in the jet outflows in these systems. I will end with a discussion of a recently proposed model for the most common type of rapid variability, which is not only seen in black holes, but also in neutron star binaries. This model invokes relativistic precession of the inner accretion disc. I present observational results in support of this model.
fields.speaker: Jeroen Homan
fields.teaser_text: Rapid X-ray variability in low-mass X-ray binaries originates in the poorly understood inner regions of the accretion flow. In this talk I report on recent progress made in the field of rapid X-ray variability in black hole X-ray binaries, both observational and theoretical.

fields.title: Hysteresis: On the connection between Argentinian economy, a rubber band and accretion disks
fields.text: When it is not possible to predict how a dynamical system will evolve unless it is well known how it reached its current state, it is said that the system "has memory", i.e. it is said that it undergoes hysteresis. Although hysteresis effects are most commonly known in magnetic materials, hysteresis phenomena are also widespread in nature, often indicating a non-equilibrium situation associated with a type of transition. As analogy, the term "hysteresis" is sometimes used in other fields, such as psychology, economics, game theory or biology, where it describes a memory, or lagging, effect. In this talk I will (i) summarize the many faces of "hysteresis" that have so far been related to accretion disks in Low-mass X-ray binaries, (ii) show where hysteresis effects might have been overlooked, and (iii) argue how important is the study of these effects as "a whole" to be able to better understand accretion onto compact objects.
fields.speaker: Diego Altamirano
fields.teaser_text: When it is not possible to predict how a dynamical system will evolve unless it is well known how it reached its current state, it is said that the system "has memory", i.e. it is said that it undergoes hysteresis.

fields.title: X-ray binaries and recoiling super-massive black holes
fields.text: Quiescent, eclipsing, neutron star and black hole low-mass X-ray binaries (LMXBs) allow for model independent neutron star and black hole mass measurements from optical phase-resolved spectroscopic measurements. These mass measurements are important for determining the neutron star equation of state and black hole formation scenarios. To search for these eclipsing quiescent LMXBs we have initiated the Galactic Bulge Survey. So far, we have discovered 1234 X-ray sources in Chandra observations of an area of 8.4 square degrees centered on the Galactic Center. For a large number of the X-ray sources we find counterparts on our existing optical images of the field. I will present initial results on this survey. In addition, I will discuss a new tool to constrain the neutron star mass that we recently discovered. The feature is present in the reflection spectrum of two sources that accrete O-rich material. Finally, I will briefly show some initial results of our study to discover recoiling super-massive black holes.
fields.speaker: Peter Jonker
fields.teaser_text: Quiescent, eclipsing, neutron star and black hole low-mass X-ray binaries (LMXBs) allow for model independent neutron star and black hole mass measurements from optical phase-resolved spectroscopic measurements.

fields.title: Master colloquium: Quantitative IR Spectroscopy of Massive Stars
fields.text: Interest in near-IR spectroscopy of massive stars has increased dramatically over the last decades, as it offers the possibility to analyze stars embedded in dusty star forming regions and near the Galactic center. Yet, techniques to determine the properties of massive stars from quantitative near-IR spectroscopy are so far lacking. We present the first analysis of both high resolution optical, and,separately, high resolution VLT/CRIRES near-IR spectra in the J, H, K and L band of nearby dwarf O-type stars. Applying a genetic fitting algorithm approach using state-of-the-art FASTWIND non-LTE atmospheres for stars with stellar winds, we present a first comparison of the stellar and wind properties as derived from these two spectral regimes.
fields.speaker: Arjen Stap
fields.teaser_text: Interest in near-IR spectroscopy of massive stars has increased dramatically over the last decades, as it offers the possibility to analyze stars embedded in dusty star forming regions and near the Galactic center. Yet, techniques to determine the properties of massive stars from quantitative near-IR spectroscopy are so far lacking.

fields.title: Master Colloquium: The Lifetime Problem of Ultra Compact HII regions and its Connection With High-Mass Star Formation
fields.text: Ultra Compact HII regions (UCHIIs) are compact photo-ionised nebulae around newly born massive stars. Observing UCHIIs contributes to the understanding of the physical processes taking place in the molecular environment of these highly embedded and obscured stars and  also provide information on the stellar spectral types. The heated dust around these young massive stars powers bright infrared (IR) counterparts that allow for their identification as UCHIIs throughout the Galaxy. Observations show that the number of Galactic UCHIIs is too large to be consistent with the current high-mass star formation rate if the ionised gas is assumed to expand as described by the standard Strömgren theory of HII regions. This situation became known as the lifetime problem of UCHIIs. I will explain how the lifetime problem depends on the shape of the initial mass function and discuss the consequences of a clustered mode of massive star formation when trying to quantify the extent of the lifetimes of UCHIIs. Furthermore, I will present results from modelling of the infrared spectra of young massive stars embedded in their natal molecular clouds and will compare these with the observations.
fields.speaker: Ricardo Nicolas Caballero
fields.teaser_text: Ultra Compact HII regions (UCHIIs) are compact photo-ionised nebulae around newly born massive stars. Observing UCHIIs contributes to the understanding of the physical processes taking place in the molecular environment of these highly embedded and obscured stars and  also provide information on the stellar spectral types.

fields.title: Superfluid Turbulence in Neutron Stars
fields.text:
Study of neutron stars allows probes of the behavior of matter at
densities and magnetic fields that are unattainable in terrestrial
laboratories. I will show that the superfluid predicted to comprise
most of the neutron star interior could be in a turbulent state, and
then speculate about the observable consequences of this instability.

fields.title: The innermost astronomical unit of protoplanetary disks
fields.affiliation: Max Planck Institut für Astronomie, Heidelberg
fields.text:
Understanding the physical conditions in circumstellar disks is a crucial  step to comprehend how planet form and evolve.  Of particular interest is the first astronomical unit (AU) in which terrestrial-planets form, and angular moment is controled via mass-loss through winds/jets.  To bring direct observational constraints on this region, one needs to use the only available technique that is able to reach the required milli-arcsecond angular resolution: optical interferometry.   

After introducing the basic concepts of optical interferometry, I will present recent observational studies that aim at understanding the morphology of the inner regions in disks. I will show one of the first images of a protoplanetary disk at the sub-AU scale, and discuss the constraints and open questions brought by models of the inner disk in a variety of objects (including transitional disks). I will also present interferometric observations of Hydrogen lines, obtained with the resolution of a few micro-arcseconds, to probe the jet-launching region in an outbursting young star. I will conclude with some general comments regarding the advent of the next generation imaging instruments at the VLTI.

fields.teaser_text: Understanding the physical conditions in circumstellar disks is a crucial  step to comprehend how planet form and evolve.  Of particular interest is the first astronomical unit (AU) in which terrestrial-planets form, and angular moment is controled via mass-loss through winds/jets.

fields.title: X-ray Emission from Single Massive Stars: Constraints on Wind-Shock Physics and Mass-Loss Rates
fields.text: The strong soft X-ray emission from O and early B stars is the result of radiative cooling of these stars' shock-heated winds.  X-ray spectroscopy provides diagnostics of the shock processes in these highly supersonic, radiation-driven winds, mainly via Doppler-broadened emission lines and temperature- and location-sensitive line ratios. Recently, my group has shown that both the X-ray line shapes and the overall broadband spectral energy distribution of the X-rays can also be used as wind mass-loss rate diagnostics.  Furthermore, these X-ray mass-loss rate diagnostics are not sensitive to the optically thin clumping that affects traditional diagnostics, such as H-alpha. Applying these new X-ray spectral diagnostics to several O stars, we find mass-loss rates a factor of three to four below the traditional, unclumped H-alpha values, and consistent with newer H-alpha diagnostics that do take clumping into account.
fields.speaker: David Cohen
fields.teaser_text: The strong soft X-ray emission from O and early B stars is the result of radiative cooling of these stars' shock-heated winds.  X-ray spectroscopy provides diagnostics of the shock processes in these highly supersonic, radiation-driven winds, mainly via Doppler-broadened emission lines and temperature- and location-sensitive line ratios.

fields.title: Gamma ray pulsars: towards a high energy census of the Milky Way
fields.text: The Large Area Telescope on the Fermi satellite sees gamma-ray pulsations from about a hundred pulsars: the largest class of GeV sources in the Milky Way. By tallying their properties -- radio loud versus quiet, young versus old, intensity versus spindown rate, and so on -- we test emission models and population syntheses, and from there, better understand pulsar roles in the Galaxy. I will describe the current gamma-ray pulsar sample, explain some of the observational difficulties, and how we are addressing them. I will also mention some Pulsar Wind Nebulae seen with Fermi, and thus how pulsars are related to cosmic ray acceleration sites.
fields.speaker: David A. Smith
fields.teaser_text: The Large Area Telescope on the Fermi satellite sees gamma-ray pulsations from about a hundred pulsars: the largest class of GeV sources in the Milky Way. I will describe the current gamma-ray pulsar sample, explain some of the observational difficulties, and how we are addressing them.

fields.title: Close-in Planets: From Hot Jupiters to Super Mercuries
fields.text: The closest-in planets, with periods as short as 10 hours, are now a well-established population, thanks to Doppler and transit surveys. They present a number of challenges: how did they form and achieve their tight orbits, and how do they evolve and survive in the face of intense irradiation from their parent stars? I review their possible origins, including in situ accretion; disk-driven migration; and eccentricity excitation and tidal capture. I also discuss the problem of why hot Jupiters are so distended, and its possible solution in Ohmic dissipation. I conclude by describing how close-in planets lose mass via thermal winds driven by stellar heating. The curious case of Kepler Input Catalog 12557548 --- which may represent the first example of a geologically active, Mercury-sized planet in its final death throes --- is presented.
fields.speaker: Eugene Chiang, NOVA colloquium
fields.teaser_text: The closest-in planets, with periods as short as 10 hours, are now a well-established population, thanks to Doppler and transit surveys. They present a number of challenges: how did they form and achieve their tight orbits, and how do they evolve and survive in the face of intense irradiation from their parent stars?

fields.title: How do Most Planets Form?
fields.text:
Traditionally, there have been two main competing theories of planet
formation: Core accretion, in which planets form sequentially through
accumulation of a solid core followed by accretion of gas onto the core,
and disk instability, in which planets form directly through gravitational
collapse in a gaseous disk. In this talk, I will show that by combining
direct imaging data with the body of observations from radial velocity and
transits that have been taken over the past decade, the issue of which
mechanism is the main mode of planet formation can be quantitatively
addressed for the first time; and that most likely, the vast majority of
exoplanets form by core accretion. While these arguments can now be made
on a population basis, the formation history of individual planetary
systems remains a challenging issue. I will discuss some such individual
systems based on the (often conflicting) indications of how they might
have formed, and point out ways of resolving these uncertainties in the
future.
fields.speaker: NOVA colloquium: Markus Janson

fields.title: Probing the close vicinity of black holes in (polarized) X-ray light
fields.text: The mass flows in the immediate proximity of supermassive black holes are not well understood. It is clear that accretion and ejection occur simultaneously in active galactic nuclei (AGN), but a coherent picture of the accretion and ejection geometry and dynamics remains to be established. I give a brief introduction to AGN and I summarize the observational picture of accretion and ejection flows as it appears in the X-ray range. With increasing sensitivity of future X-ray detectors, data analysis requires accurate radiative transfer modeling as a function of photon energy (spectroscopy), of time (variability) and possibly of space (imaging). In addition to this, it is useful to include polarization as X-ray polarimetry has become technically feasible and will be included in future space observatories. Thereby, it is possible to include two more observables: the direction and the percentage of polarization. In black hole physics, the observation of polarized radiation allows for important insights because it is connected to fundamental emission and (relativistic) radiative transfer processes. The modeling techniques I present are applied to nearby, bright Seyfert galaxies and to related stellar mass black holes in X-ray binaries. The applications allow us to put constraints on the geometry and on the physics of AGN outflows (e.g. NGC 3783, NGC 1068) as well as on the innermost regions of the accretion disk and on the angular momentum of black holes (e.g. MCG-6-30-15, GRS 1915+105).
fields.speaker: René Goosmann
fields.teaser_text: The mass flows in the immediate proximity of supermassive black holes are not well understood. fields.title: Building & testing a physical model for the spectral timing properties of back hole binaries
fields.text: It has been known for over 20 years that the X-ray emission from black hole binaries displays quasi-periodic oscillations (QPOs) plus broad band variability. Although these power spectral features are very well studied, there is still no consensus in the literature as to their physical origin. I describe a model that associates the QPO with relativistic precession of the inner regions of the accretion flow and the broad band noise with propagating fluctuations in mass accretion rate. I describe how these two ingredients can be combined to make a physical model for the power spectrum which has the capability to also explain the observed spectral timing properties. I then go on to describe how we may soon be able to use the phase behaviour of the QPO to provide an unambiguous test for the model.
fields.speaker: Adam Ingram
fields.teaser_text: It has been known for over 20 years that the X-ray emission from black hole binaries displays quasi-periodic oscillations (QPOs) plus broad band variability. I describe a model that associates the QPO with relativistic precession of the inner regions of the accretion flow and the broad band noise with propagating fluctuations in mass accretion rate.

fields.title: A Galaxy-Wide Census of Massive Star Formation
fields.text: The Red MSX Source Survey was a project designed to identify and study the properties of all the young massive stars in our Galaxy. I will outline the details of the survey, and show how we can use the basic statistic to constrain models as to how massive stars form. In addition, I will discuss in detail the properties of the sources as revealed through near infrared and mm spectroscopy.
fields.speaker: Stuart Lumsden
fields.teaser_text: The Red MSX Source Survey was a project designed to identify and study the properties of all the young massive stars in our Galaxy. I will outline the details of the survey, and show how we can use the basic statistic to constrain models as to how massive stars form.

fields.title: Star clusters as links between stellar and galactic astrophysics
fields.text: Several nearby star-forming galaxies host young star clusters with masses well above 100,000 Msun. Unlike most Milky Way open clusters, these clusters are rich enough that the post-main sequence phases are well populated even at young ages, making such clusters attractive laboratories to study the evolution of massive stars. The challenge is that the degree of stellar crowding is extremely high, but it is nevertheless possible to extract photometry of individual stars in several such clusters and compare with stellar evolutionary models. We have recently carried out such an analysis for a number of massive star clusters, using HST imaging. We find that the observed colour-magnitude diagrams are often poorly matched by models based on single canonical stellar isochrones. Possible explanations for this include age spreads within the clusters or effects of binary stellar evolution. The suggestion of age spreads is particularly interesting in view of the detection of multiple stellar populations in ancient globular clusters, and possibly even in intermediate-age clusters in the Magellanic Clouds. I will critically examine the case for age spreads in star clusters and discuss some of its implications.
fields.speaker: Søren Larsen
fields.teaser_text: Several nearby star-forming galaxies host young star clusters with masses well above 100,000 Msun. Unlike most Milky Way open clusters, these clusters are rich enough that the post-main sequence phases are well populated even at young ages, making such clusters attractive laboratories to study the evolution of massive stars.

fields.title: Structure and variability of the planet-forming regions in the disc around HD100546 probed with VLTI/MIDI
fields.text:
I will discuss the advantages and challenges of the modelling of
mid-infrared interferometric observations of circumstellar discs.
In particular, I present VLTI observations of a bright Herbig Be
star, HD100546. Many signs suggest that this disc hosts one or
more planets, namely a gas and dust gap, spiral structure seen in
scattered light imaging, Hale-Bopp-like mineralogy. Our mid-infrared
interferometric VLTI/MIDI observations probe the disc brightness
distribution in the regions from 0.2 to about 20AU where the putative
planets may open gaps and cause resonant clumping of disc material.
Our data show the presence of disc material both close to the dust
sublimation radius (consistent with prior VLTI/AMBER data) and
beyond the outer edge of the disc gap, located at about 13~AU
(also revealed with VLT/CRIRES and NACO instruments). We detect
up to 50% variability in the correlated interferometric fluxes,
and their shapes, measured on identical 40m baselines one year
apart. This variability can be explained either by changes in
the thickness and location of the inner rim, changes in the dust
properties at the rim, or by disc asymmetry in the inner few AU.
The observed flux changes are too subtle to be detected with a
single UT telescope (a few percent of the total disc flux),
stressing the need for interferometric monitoring.
fields.speaker: Olja Panic
fields.teaser_text:

fields.title: Supernova remnants and the origin of Galactic Cosmic Rays
fields.text:
The cosmic-ray spectrum observed on Earth has an energy distribution that is nearly a power law with index 2.7. Some subtle features, notably around ~3x10^15 eV ("the knee") and ~3x10^18 eV ("the ankle"), give clues about the origin of cosmic rays. On general grounds it is assumed that cosmic rays up to "the ankle" must be of Galactic origin, and above 3x10^18 must be extra-Galactic. One idea that "the knee" signifies the typical maximum energy that protons are accelerated to in Galactic sources.

On energetic grounds supernova remnants are thought to be the dominant sources of Galactic cosmic rays. In the last 15 years considerable progress has been made in understanding cosmic-ray acceleration in supernova remnants. I will present the results obtained using X-ray and optical telescopes, which indicate that supernova remnants accelerate cosmic rays efficiently, helped by efficient magnetic field amplification. But there are still uncertainties regarding the overall cosmic ray energy content of supernova remnants and the maximum energies that they can accelerate cosmic rays to. I will discuss these uncertainties in the context of multi-messenger astronomy.
fields.speaker: Jacco Vink
fields.teaser_text: I will present the results obtained using X-ray and optical telescopes, which indicate that supernova remnants accelerate cosmic rays efficiently, helped by efficient magnetic field amplification.

fields.title: Christmas colloquium: Astronomy sheds light on climate change: the common fourth dimension
fields.text:
Present-day climate, environments and biodiversity developed on anthropogenic to astronomical time-scales. How current conditions do relate to the full spectrum of variety along the Earth’s geological time-scale is part of the answer to the question how vulnerable our environment is for human disturbance.

In this talk is shown how changes in the Earth’s orbit around the Sun serves as an astronomical clock to tune long records of observations that document past climatic, environmental and biodiversity change.
fields.speaker: Henry Hooghiemstra
fields.teaser_text: In this talk is shown how changes in the Earth’s orbit around the Sun serves as an astronomical clock to tune long records of observations that document past climatic, environmental and biodiversity change.

fields.title: The Most Massive Stars
fields.text: Locating the most massive stars and measuring their masses is key to understanding the formation and nature of massive stars in general.  This is best done by using the least model-dependent technique, i.e. Kepler’s laws (combined with techniques to extract the orbital inclination) for binary systems that contain very luminous stars on or near the main sequence, where interaction effects are not (yet) important.  In the local Universe, it appears that the potentially most massive, main-sequence stars are the most luminous hydrogen-rich WR stars of type WN5-7ha, which are even more luminous than, and probably at least as hot as, the recently recognized hottest main-sequence stars of type O2.  WN5-7ha stars exhibit strong, broad WR-like emission lines because of their high luminosity, not because of their compactness and high ratio of L/M as classical He-burning WR stars.  It is probably no coincidence that the currently most massive star measured this way (using the VLT) is the primary in NGC3603/A1, an eclipsing binary system containing two WN6ha stars of 114 and 84 solar masses.  Other WN5-7ha stars are being measured currently and I will report on the overall results, with an update on single-star masses and implications for stellar evolution.
fields.speaker: Tony Moffat
fields.teaser_text: Locating the most massive stars and measuring their masses is key to understanding the formation and nature of massive stars in general.  This is best done by using the least model-dependent technique, i.e. Kepler’s laws (combined with techniques to extract the orbital inclination) for binary systems that contain very luminous stars on or near the main sequence, where interaction effects are not (yet) important.

fields.title: The Discovery of Giant Gamma-ray Bubbles in the Milky Way
fields.text: Data from the Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope reveal two large gamma-ray bubbles, extending ~50 degrees above and below the Galactic center, with a width of ~40 degrees in longitude. The gamma-ray emission associated with these bubbles (known as the Fermi Bubbles) has a significantly harder spectrum (dN/dE ~ E^{−2}) than the inverse Compton emission from cosmic ray electrons in the Galactic disk, or the gamma-rays produced by decay of pions from proton-ISM collisions. There is no significant difference in the gamma-ray luminosity or spectrum between the north and south bubbles. The bubbles are spatially correlated with the hard-spectrum microwave excess known as the WMAP haze; the edges of the bubbles also line up with features in the ROSAT X-ray maps in the band of 1.5 keV. These Galactic gamma-ray bubbles are probably ongoing shocks (instead of a stable structure), and were most likely created by some large episode of energy injection in the Galactic center, such as past accretion events onto the central massive black hole Sgr A*, or a nuclear starburst in the last ~10 Myr. The study of the origin and evolution of the bubbles has the potential to improve our understanding of recent energetic events towards the inner Galaxy and the high-latitude cosmic ray population. Furthermore, we have recently identified a gamma-ray cocoon feature within the southern bubble, with a jet-like feature along the cocoon’s axis of symmetry, and another directly opposite the Galactic center in the north. If confirmed, these jets are the first resolved gamma-ray jets ever seen.
fields.speaker: Meng Su
fields.teaser_text: Data from the Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope reveal two large gamma-ray bubbles. The gamma-ray emission associated with these bubbles (known as the Fermi Bubbles) has a significantly harder spectrum than the inverse Compton emission from cosmic ray electrons in the Galactic disk, or the gamma-rays produced by decay of pions from proton-ISM collisions.

fields.title: Finding the dark matter
fields.text: One of the principal goals of Gaia and surveys like it is to infer the density map and formation history of the Milky Way.  I present a few toy problems in which we use phase-space information for a snapshot of tracer particles to infer the matter density within the system. All known methods for performing this inference make multiple assumptions that are known to be false for the Galaxy, and few have made proper use of the observational noise model. I will express some optimism for methods that make use of cold phase-space structures and other kinds of rare but informative tracers.
fields.speaker: David Hogg, NOVA colloquium
fields.teaser_text: One of the principal goals of Gaia and surveys like it is to infer the density map and formation history of the Milky Way.  I present a few toy problems in which we use phase-space information for a snapshot of tracer particles to infer the matter density within the system.

fields.title: 'Protoplanetary' discs around evolved binary stars
fields.text: In this talk I will show that disc formation is not only important for young stellar objects, but also a common by-product of binary evolution. I will present a sample of evolved binary post-AGB stars, surrounded by stable Keplerian discs. The origin and evolution of this disc is still unknown, but appears to play a lead role in the further evolution of the entire binary system. Thanks to the release of the Spitzer SAGE survey, we now also find a large sample of similar evolved disc sources in the LMC. By combining a wide range in observational data and techniques, like photometry, interferometry, radial velocity monitoring and spectroscopy, we study in detail the binary nature of the central stars, as well as the geometry and mineralogy of their circumbinary discs. Our spectral analysis and SED modelling shows that, both in geometry and chemistry, these discs are very similar to the protoplanetary discs seen around young stars. The discs are all oyxgen rich and highly crystalline, and the observed high submillimetre fluxes possibly point to very efficient grain growth. Except for a few atypical sources, where PAHs and buckyballs are seen, no carbon-rich material is observed. The submillimetre fluxes show that cm-sized grains are present, or that the discs are optically thick.
fields.speaker: Clio Gielen
fields.teaser_text: In this talk I will show that disc formation is not only important for young stellar objects, but also a common by-product of binary evolution. I will present a sample of evolved binary post-AGB stars, surrounded by stable Keplerian discs.

fields.title: A panchromatic overview of accreting binary systems
fields.text: In the past decade, several considerable achievements have been reached in the field of Galactic accreting binary systems, especially in light of the extreme variability of their relativistic jets. Althought their phenomenology is now rather well established, their emission and contribution to the total energy budget of microquasars is still the subject of active debates.  I will present the most relevant observations concerning our understanding of relativistic jets in accreting systems, discussing in particular some open issues. I will also highlight some recent results concerning the broadband emission of black holes binaries and  the nature of ultra/hyper luminous X-ray sources.
fields.speaker: Stephane Corbel
fields.teaser_text: In the past decade, several considerable achievements have been reached in the field of Galactic accreting binary systems, especially in light of the extreme variability of their relativistic jets. I will present the most relevant observations concerning our understanding of relativistic jets in accreting systems, discussing in particular some open issues.

fields.title: Estimating gas content in galaxies from optical spectroscopy - gas masses for 200k galaxies in the SDSS
fields.text: Despite its crucial importance for galaxy evolution, the gaseous phase in galaxies is much less well known than the stellar content. Determining gas content in galaxies has long been either time-consuming and limited to nearby galaxies, at least for HI, or using fitting functions such as the Schmidt-Kennicutt relation which might not be applicable in many regimes. Here we present a new technique to determine gas content in galaxies using rest-frame optical emission line spectra. We show, by comparing to nearby galaxies with extensive multi-wavelength data, that the method can give unbiased total column densities of gas for a wide range of environments. We apply this to the extensive database of galaxy spectra from the SDSS and provide an inventory of gas in galaxies and the depletion time of gas across a wide range of stellar masses.
fields.speaker: Jarle Brinchmann
fields.teaser_text: Despite its crucial importance for galaxy evolution, the gaseous phase in galaxies is much less well known than the stellar content.  Here we present a new technique to determine gas content in galaxies using rest-frame optical emission line spectra.

fields.title: A Hierarchical Approach to Understanding Exoplanetary Atmospheres: from 1D Models to 3D Simulations
fields.text: The astronomical state of the art has advanced to the point where we are now able to characterize the atmospheres of exoplanets, including the measurement of thermal phase curves and wind speeds.  These discoveries legitimize and motivate the theoretical investigation of the dynamical and radiative properties of exoplanetary atmospheres.  In this colloquium, I will describe how exoplanetary atmospheres reside in a circulation regime which is unprecedented in the Solar System, implying that traditional views of planetary atmospheres may not directly transfer over, although a multi-disciplinary approach drawing from astrophysics/astronomy, atmospheric/climate science and planetary science remains essential.  I will argue that the road towards full understanding requires the construction of a hierarchy of theoretical models, from 1D toy models to 3D simulations, as has been described by climate scientists.  Finally, I will discuss several applications of these models towards deepening our understanding of hot Jovian atmospheres.
fields.speaker: Dr. Kevin Heng
fields.teaser_text: The astronomical state of the art has advanced to the point where we are now able to characterize the atmospheres of exoplanets, including the measurement of thermal phase curves and wind speeds.  These discoveries legitimize and motivate the theoretical investigation of the dynamical and radiative properties of exoplanetary atmospheres.

fields.title: Galactic Cosmic Rays: From Earth to Sources
fields.text:
For nearly 100 years we have known that cosmic rays come from outer space, yet proof of their origin, as well as a comprehensive understanding of their acceleration, remains elusive. Direct detection of high energy (up to 10^15eV), charged nuclei with experiments such as the balloon-born, antarctic Trans-Iron Galactic Element Recorder (TIGER) have provided insight into these mysteries through measurements of cosmic ray abundances. The abundance of these rare elements with respect to certain intrinsic properties suggests that cosmic rays include a component of massive star ejecta. SuperTIGER, currently under construction with ~6x the collecting area of TIGER, will build on this understanding of CR origins with an antarctic flight scheduled for 2012-13.

Supernovae and their remnants (SNe & SNRs), often occurring at the end of a massive star's life or in an environment including massive star material, are one of the most likely candidates for sources accelerating galactic comic ray nuclei up to the requisite high energies. The Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope Large Area Detector (Fermi LAT) has improved our understanding of such sources by widening the window of observable energies and thus into potential sources' energetic processes. In combination with multiwavelength observations, we are now better able to constrain particle populations (often hadron-dominated at GeV energies) and environmental conditions, such as the magnetic field strength. The SNR CTB 37A is one such source which could contribute to the observed galactic cosmic rays. By assembling populations of SNRs, we will be able to more definitively define their contribution to the observed galactic cosmic rays, as well as better understand SNRs themselves. Such multimessenger studies will thus illuminate the long-standing cosmic ray mysteries, shedding light on potential sources, acceleration mechanisms, and cosmic ray propagation.
fields.speaker: Terri Brandt
fields.teaser_text: For nearly 100 years we have known that cosmic rays come from outer space, yet proof of their origin, as well as a comprehensive understanding of their acceleration, remains elusive. Direct detection of high energy (up to 10^15eV), charged nuclei with experiments such as the balloon-born, antarctic Trans-Iron Galactic Element Recorder (TIGER) have provided insight into these mysteries through measurements of cosmic ray abundances.

fields.title: Development of DESHIMA: An On-chip Submillimeter-wave 3D Spectrograph Based on an Integrated Filterbank
fields.text: Recent advances in submillimeter wave sensors have revealed the existence of an important population of very luminous but highly obscured galaxies in the early universe. The distribution of these so-called submillimeter galaxies (SMGs) across a wide range of redshifts is of great importance for studies of the cosmic history of star- and galaxy-formation, and the evolution of the cosmic large scale structure. While submillimeter cameras produce number counts of SMGs, they cannot determine their redshifts, which are necessary to convert number counts into a cosmic star formation history. In order to quickly determine the redshift of SMGs directly from atomic/molecular lines in the submillimeter window, we are developing a medium-resolution imaging spectrograph DESHIMA (Delft SRON High-redshift Mapper). The distinguishing feature in the target performance of DESHIMA is the broad instantaneous bandwidth (320-950 GHz) and the 3D imaging capability with 9 pixels. The key technology is the integrated filterbank (IFB), which is a combination of 8000 microwave kinetic inductance detectors (MKIDs) and a superconducting submillimeter wave filterbank, both integrated onto a single chip, making the instrument compact, light-weight and considerably easy to build. In the talk I will give an overview of the astronomical agenda, the concept of the IFB, and the current status of the development of DESHIMA.
fields.speaker: Akira Endo
fields.teaser_text: Recent advances in submillimeter wave sensors have revealed the existence of an important population of very luminous but highly obscured galaxies in the early universe. The distribution of these so-called submillimeter galaxies (SMGs) across a wide range of redshifts is of great importance for studies of the cosmic history of star- and galaxy-formation, and the evolution of the cosmic large scale structure.

fields.title: X-ray binaries in galaxies, star-formation and the problem of SNIa progenitors
fields.affiliation: Max Plank Institute for Astrophysics, Garching
fields.text: The X-ray appearance of majority of normal galaxies is determined by radiation from accreting neutron stars and black holes in X-ray binaries. Chandra and XMM-Newton observations revealed that their populations scale with the star-formation rate and stellar mass of the host galaxy. Thus, the X-ray luminosity of a star-forming galaxy can be used as a star-formation rate proxy. The numbers of high-mass X-ray binaries observed in star-forming galaxies indicate the rather high probability for a massive star to become an accretion powered X-ray source once upon its lifetime. This explains the unexpectedly high contribution of accreting compact objects of stellar mass to the Cosmic X-ray background, ~7-10%. Underneath bright X-ray binaries, unresolved emission is present in all types of galaxies, which is partly due to unresolved faint compact sources, including accreting white dwarfs. The luminosity of unresolved emission  can be used to place an upper limit on the total rate of mass accumulation by white dwarfs via accretion and to discriminate between various scenarios of progenitors of type Ia supernovae. It is demonstrated that white dwarfs accreting from a donor star in a binary system and detonating at the Chandrasekhar limit can account for no more than a few per cent of type Ia supernovae observed in old stellar populations. The majority of snIa in elliptical galaxies must be due to coalescence of white dwarfs or their explosions at sub-Chandrasekhar masses.
fields.speaker: Marat Gilfanov
fields.teaser_text: The X-ray appearance of majority of normal galaxies is determined by radiation from accreting neutron stars and black holes in X-ray binaries. Chandra and XMM-Newton observations revealed that their populations scale with the star-formation rate and stellar mass of the host galaxy. Thus, the X-ray luminosity of a star-forming galaxy can be used as a star-formation rate proxy.

fields.title: The Origin of the IMF
fields.text: Star-forming environments vary by orders of magnitude in density, pressure, metallicity, and other properties, yet the initial mass function (IMF) of the stars they produce remains stubbornly unchanged. Explaining the origin and universality of the IMF is one of the oldest problems in theoretical astrophysics, but in the last few years theoretical advances in understanding how gas fragments, together with algorithmic advances that have allowed simulations to include improved physics such as radiative transfer, have produced significant progress. I describe these advances, and lay out the beginnings of a theoretical model capable of explaining the IMF.
fields.speaker: Mark Krumholz
fields.teaser_text: Star-forming environments vary by orders of magnitude in density, pressure, metallicity, and other properties, yet the initial mass function (IMF) of the stars they produce remains stubbornly unchanged. Explaining the origin and universality of the IMF is one of the oldest problems  in theoretical astrophysics.

fields.title: Characterizing Exoplanets
fields.text: On-going searches for extrasolar planets, despite certain limitations in sensitivity, have already revealed a remarkable diversity of worlds, from close-in super-Earths to far out super-Jupiters, and challenged our preconceptions many times over. Meanwhile, comparative studies of exoplanet physical properties have begun in earnest: planets caught in transit and those imaged directly are best suited for detailed characterization, especially of their atmospheres. I will discuss recent results and future prospects, including the possibility of extending these techniques to lower-mass planets.
fields.speaker: Ray Jayawardhana
fields.teaser_text: On-going searches for extrasolar planets, despite certain limitations in sensitivity, have already revealed a remarkable diversity of worlds, from close-in super-Earths to far out super-Jupiters, and challenged our preconceptions many times over.

fields.title: Planet Formation: First steps from first principles
fields.text: The theoretical understanding of planet formation - which was developed based on largely indirect evidence from Solar System observations - has been revolutionized by the detection of extrasolar planetary systems. I will discuss what we know about the early evolution of planetary systems in light of current discoveries, focusing on new predictions for the diversity of terrestrial planets and their relation to debris disks. At earlier epochs, the fundamental open question is how the first macroscopic bodies are assembled from dust within protoplanetary disks. I will present results from a new generation of numerical simulations that aim to model disk turbulence from first principles, and discuss how the models can be validated from forthcoming ALMA observations.
fields.speaker: Phil Armitage
fields.teaser_text: The theoretical understanding of planet formation has been revolutionized by the detection of extrasolar planetary systems. I will discuss what we know about the early evolution of planetary systems in light of current discoveries.

fields.title: Exoplanet atmospheres and the search for extraterrestrial life
fields.text: One of the most exciting discoveries in astronomy in recent years has been the detection of planets orbiting stars other than the sun. Now, fundamental questions can be addressed about the origin and uniqueness of the solar system, and Earth in particular.  While the exoplanet population is rapidly being deciphered, and the hunt for rocky Earth-like planets has begun, the first sketchy properties of the hottest planet atmospheres are being determined using planet transits.  I will show the unique capabilities of large ground-based telescopes and instrumentation that lift this research to the next level, and outline a path towards using these techniques to search for possible bio-signatures from extraterrestrial life.
fields.speaker: Ignas Snellen
fields.teaser_text: One of the most exciting discoveries in astronomy in recent years has been the detection of planets orbiting stars other than the sun. Now, fundamental questions can be addressed about the origin and uniqueness of the solar system, and Earth in particular.

fields.title: The Life Cycle of Matter in the Magellanic Clouds:  Insights from
fields.text:
The life cycle of baryonic matter in a galaxy is driven by the exchange of material between the interstellar medium (ISM) and stars,  which are the agents of galaxy evolution. Dust is present at these key transition phases of matter: in the ISM, in the circumstellar environments of newly forming stars and in stellar ejecta of dying stars. The Spitzer and Herschel wavelengths  provide a sensitive probe of circumstellar and interstellar dust and hence, allows us to study the physical processes of the ISM, the formation of new stars and the injection of mass by evolved stars and their relationships on a galaxy-wide scale. Due to their proximity, well constrained viewing angle, multi-wavelength information, and measured tidal interactions with the Milky Way (MW), the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) and  Small Magellanic Cloud (SMC) are uniquely suited for surveying the agents of  galaxy evolution (SAGE), the ISM and stars.

In this talk, I will present some key results from the Spitzer  SAGE and Herschel HERITAGE surveys including measurements of ISM mass estimates from dust emission, discoveries of thousands of young stellar object candidates, and precise measurements of dust mass loss rates  from entire populations of evolved stars and w the mass budgets of these galaxies. I will end with a brief forward look to the  future prospects with the James Webb Space Telescope Mission.
fields.speaker: Margaret Meixner
fields.teaser_text: The life cycle of baryonic matter in a galaxy is driven by the exchange of material between the interstellar medium (ISM) and stars,  which are the agents of galaxy evolution. The Spitzer and Herschel wavelengths  provide a sensitive probe of circumstellar and interstellar dust and hence, allows us to study the physical processes of the ISM, the formation of new stars and the injection of mass by evolved stars and their relationships on a galaxy-wide scale.

fields.title: Zooming in on emerging planetary systems
fields.text: The last 15 years have presented us with an amazing breakthrough in the study of the origin of planetary systems. On the one hand, observations and theoretical models of protoplanetary disks have given us a very detailed view on the objects which are planet factories. On the other hand, radial velocity studies and recently the Corot and Kepler missions are presenting us with a complex picture on what mature planetary systems look like. I will present ways in which we have studied the physical processes in protoplanetary disks and show how this allows us to zoom in to the innermost regions of disks where planetary systems first will appear. I will outline how we will use both observational and theoretical tools to advance our understanding of these regions and to witness the emergence of planetary systems.
fields.speaker: Carsten Dominik
fields.teaser_text: The last 15 years have presented us with an amazing breakthrough in the study of the origin of planetary systems. On the one hand, observations and theoretical models of protoplanetary disks have given us a very detailed view on the objects which are planet factories. On the other hand, radial velocity studies and recently the Corot and Kepler missions are presenting us with a complex picture on what mature planetary systems look like.

fields.title: Predictions for the distribution of planetary radii and luminosities
fields.text: The last few years have seen a tremendous increase of observational data regarding the properties of extrasolar planets. High precision radial velocity and photometric transit observations have yielded large datasets of planetary masses and radii. Other techniques like direct imaging also start to contribute important information. Bringing all these different dataset into one coherent picture is challenging, as each technique constrains a different aspect of the planetary formation and evolution process. I will present planetary population synthesis as a fruitful method in this situation as it allows direct comparisons with the full wealth of the observational data. For the population synthesis, a planetary formation model is used which is based on the core accretion paradigm. By varying the initial conditions of the model, planetary populations are synthesized. Recently, we have extended this formation model into a self-consistently coupled formation and evolution model. With this it is now possible to compare a synthetic and the actual observed planetary population in all major characteristics, as we now also get the radius and luminosity of each planet. As an application, I will show comparisons with data from the KEPLER satellite concerning the synthetic and observed radius distribution and the planetary mass-radius relationship. I will finally make predictions for the luminosity distribution of massive planets for future direct imaging searches.
fields.speaker: Christoph Mordasini
fields.teaser_text: The last few years have seen a tremendous increase of observational data regarding the properties of extrasolar planets. High precision radial velocity and photometric transit observations have yielded large datasets of planetary masses and radii. Other techniques like direct imaging also start to contribute important information.

fields.title: The multiphase extraplanar medium in spiral galaxies
fields.text: The continuing evolution of galaxies is linked with their connection to the external environment. Through mergers, interactions, and accretion, the structure and contents of galaxies' interstellar media can be strongly altered. The extraplanar region in spiral galaxies is the interface between the star-forming disk and the environment. The structure and kinematics of the baryonic material in this interface region are vital clues to the relative importance of various processes, such as cold gas accretion and galactic fountains, in determining the history of galaxies. The strength and morphology of the magnetic fields in these regions may also be crucial to understanding the connection to the intergalactic medium. In this talk, I will describe results from two surveys that are shedding light on these issues: the recently completed WSRT Hydrogen Accretion in LOcal GAlaxieS (HALOGAS) Survey, and the WSRT-SINGS Survey. HALOGAS is the first systematic investigation of cold gas accretion in nearby spiral galaxies. It consists of deep (120 hours) WSRT observations of 22 edge-on and moderately-inclined nearby galaxies, and reveals the presence of kinematically lagging extraplanar gas, and counterparts to the Milky Way’s high velocity clouds. The WSRT-SINGS Survey provides high-quality polarimetric data for a partially overlapping galaxy sample (derived from SINGS), and has led to a common model of the magnetic field morphology in spiral galaxies. I will conclude the talk by describing directions for future work in both areas, to be pursued with upcoming telescopes such as LOFAR, as well as the Square Kilometre Array.
fields.speaker: George Heald
fields.teaser_text: The continuing evolution of galaxies is linked with their connection to the external environment. Through mergers, interactions, and accretion, the structure and contents of galaxies' interstellar media can be strongly altered.

fields.title: Swift UV and X-ray observations of small bodies in the solar system
fields.text:
Swift is a space borne observatory initially designed for rapid follow-up of gamma-ray bursts. It is equipped with co-aligned gamma-ray, X-ray, and UV telescopes, and can quickly slew between targets, allowing for rapid response observations and monitoring campaigns.

In the past five years, we have used Swift to study numerous small bodies in the solar system. I will give an overview of our results, ranging from UV grism spectroscopy of comets and asteroids, UV imaging of the impact on Asteroid (596) Scheila, and how Swift’s multi-wavelength capabilities were used to study the interaction between Comet C/2007 N3 (Lulin) and the solar wind
fields.speaker: Dennis Bodewits
fields.teaser_text: In the past five years, we have used Swift to study numerous small bodies in the solar system. I will give an overview of our results, ranging from UV grism spectroscopy of comets and asteroids, and how Swift’s multi-wavelength capabilities were used to study the interaction between a comet and the solar wind.

fields.title: Milky Way Structure and the Initial Conditions for High-Mass Star Formation
fields.text: Galactic plane surveys allow us to study the structure of the Milky Way as a whole system. I will present recent result from the submm continuum survey ATLASGAL investigating the coldest and densest gas and dust components of the Milky Way. With this survey we can identify spiral arm structures, investigate the available gas reservoir from the Galactic Center to regions located further out, or study the scale height of the dense gas. Furthermore, far-infrared Herschel data allow us to investigate the physical conditions at the onset of high-mass star formation. I will present recent results from the guaranteed time key project EPOS (the Early Phases of Star Formation).
fields.speaker: Henrik Beuther
fields.teaser_text: Galactic plane surveys allow us to study the structure of the Milky Way as a whole system. I will present recent result from the submm continuum survey ATLASGAL investigating the coldest and densest gas and dust components of the Milky Way.

fields.title: Models for the multi-wavelength emission of black hole binaries
fields.text: I will discuss emission processes in the corona and jets of black holes in X-ray binary systems. The nature of the hard X-ray emitting plasma in black hole accretion flows (the so-called corona) is indeed a matter of controversy. I will show how a detailed modelling of radiation processes in this relativistic plasma can be compared to observations to constrain the physical properties of the corona and discriminate between the different dynamical corona models. Then, I will present an internal shock model for the radio to infrared emission of the steady compact jets that are commonly observed in these sources. This model not only reproduces the observed spectral energy distribution of these jets but also naturally predicts a strong multi-wavelength variability that resembles the observed one.
fields.speaker: Julien Malzac
fields.teaser_text: I will discuss emission processes in the corona and jets of black holes in X-ray binary systems. The nature of the hard X-ray emitting plasma in black hole accretion flows (the so-called corona) is indeed a matter of controversy.

fields.title: Radio emission from Low-Mass Young Stellar Objects
fields.text: Compact radio emission provides a reliable method for the detection of low luminosity young stellar objects (YSOs), and is particularly useful for detecting the earliest stages of protostellar evolution where the source itself may still be heavily embedded in its natal dust envelope. For such Class 0 and Class I objects the dominant radio emission mechanism is expected to be free-free, however unlike massive YSOs the way in which this radio emission is produced remains a subject of debate. As larger samples of radio YSOs become available the relationship between the radio luminosity of the Class 0/I population and their wider global properties is now being clarified. Furthermore, the broader scientific applications of such samples are also becoming increasingly apparent. These improved constraints on the nature of the radio emission from YSOs are now contributing to our understanding of not only the evolutionary physics of protostars themselves but also their wider impact on their surroundings. I will discuss the physics of the radio emission, the emerging relationship between this emission and other properties of YSOs and some of the potential applications for studies exploiting this emission.
fields.speaker: Anna Scaife
fields.teaser_text: Compact radio emission provides a reliable method for the detection of low luminosity young stellar objects (YSOs), and is particularly useful for detecting the earliest stages of protostellar evolution where the source itself may still be heavily embedded in its natal dust envelope.  I will discuss the physics of the radio emission, the emerging relationship between this emission and other properties of YSOs and some of the potential applications for studies exploiting this emission.

fields.title: Solar forcing of climate change; past, present and future
fields.text: Was climate change during the 20th century anthropogenic, or did temperatures increase mainly because of increased solar activity? Climate has never been stable. Botanical and zoological remains and stable isotopes in peat deposits, lake sediments, marine deposits and stalagmites are important sources of information about natural climate change in the past. Major climate shifts during the last 11,000 years (Holocene period) co-occurred with fluctuations of the cosmogenic isotopes that were caused by changes of the solar wind. Variations in solar activity were a major driving factor behind Holocene climate oscillations. Reconstructions of lake level changes in west-central Europe show major hydrological changes in response to Holocene climate cooling phases linked to changing solar activity. The transition from the dry-warm Subboreal to the cool-moist Subatlantic around 850 BC - as reflected in peat deposits - was caused by a considerable decline of solar activity. The effects of that climate shift for (a) Bronze Age people in the Netherlands and (b) the expanding Scythian culture in dry southern Siberian areas will be discussed. The hypersensitivity of the climate system to relatively small changes in solar activity points to the existence of amplification mechanisms in the atmosphere. The lack of accurate knowledge about such mechanisms hampers balanced evaluation and modeling of future climate. The deep and long minimum at the transition from solar cycle 23 to cycle 24 and the low maximum of cycle 24 may be a signal for climate cooling in the near future and will allow a better quantification of anthropogenic and natural climate change. The role of the sun is probably underestimated in climate models.
fields.speaker: Bas van Geel
fields.teaser_text: Was climate change during the 20th century anthropogenic, or did temperatures increase mainly because of increased solar activity? Climate has never been stable. Botanical and zoological remains and stable isotopes in peat deposits, lake sediments, marine deposits and stalagmites are important sources of information about natural climate change in the past.  Variations in solar activity were a major driving factor behind Holocene climate oscillations.

fields.title: Bridging the Gap Between Stellar Mass and Supermassive Black Holes
fields.text: While it is widely accepted that most (perhaps all) galaxies host a supermassive black hole in their centres, how these black holes form is not understood. One theory proposes that they are formed from the mergers of intermediate mass black holes with masses in the range of ～100 – 100,000 times the mass of the Sun. However, observational evidence for the existence of black holes in this mass range has until recently been lacking. The best candidates are the class of ultraluminous X-ray sources, which are extragalactic X-ray sources that are located outside the nuclei of their host galaxies with X-ray luminosities that exceed the theoretical Eddington limit for a stellar mass black hole but are below those of supermassive black holes. The Eddington limit is a function of the black hole mass, and so these luminosities have been interpreted as evidence for intermediate mass black holes. However, the bulk of ultraluminous X-ray sources have luminosities low enough that they can be explained via mild super-Eddington accretion or beamed emission. The brightest of these objects – the “hyperluminous” X-ray sources – have luminosities above 1E41 erg/s that cannot be easily explained without intermediate mass black holes.  Here I will describe the discovery and follow-up multi-wavelength observing campaign targeting ESO 243-49 HLX-1, the most luminous ULX currently known and the strongest candidate intermediate mass black hole with an estimated mass of 10,000 Msun. I will also present the results of a recent search for intermediate mass black holes in the nuclei of low mass dwarf galaxies, and outline future possibilities regarding hunting for intermediate mass black holes with the upcoming ASKAP radio and eROSITA X-ray sky surveys.
fields.speaker: Sean Farrell
fields.teaser_text: While it is widely accepted that most (perhaps all) galaxies host a supermassive black hole in their centres, how these black holes form is not understood. One theory proposes that they are formed from the mergers of intermediate mass black holes with masses in the range of ～100 – 100,000 times the mass of the Sun. However, observational evidence for the existence of black holes in this mass range has until recently been lacking.

fields.title: New Results from Planck (GRAPPA/API)
fields.text: The Planck Collaboration has released an ensemble of intensity-based results on cosmology and data (maps and catalogues) from 15.5 months of observation. I will review the major findings of this first analysis of the Planck data as conducted by the Planck Collaboration with a particular focus on the clusters of galaxies and the Sunyaev-Zeldovich effect.
fields.speaker: Nabila Aghanim
fields.teaser_text: Learn all about a new detailed map of the baby Universe!

fields.title: Poynting dominated outflows in astrophysics
fields.text: The primary observational fact that emerged from studies of a large class of astrophysical objects (pulsars, active galactic nuclei, gamma-ray bursts, galactic X-ray sources) is the ubiquitous occurrence of highly relativistic outflows. A promising model for that is magnetohydrodynamic acceleration by rotating, twisted magnetic fields. The basic idea is that the rotation of the central compact source (neutron star, black hole, accretion disk) winds up the magnetic field lines thus generating the outward directed Poynting flux. Due to low baryon contamination, the flow could be accelerated to relativistic velocities. In my talk, I discuss the basic properties of such electromagnetic outflows. I am going to concentrate on the physical mechanisms responsible for the transformation of the electromagnetic energy into the plasma energy. In particular, I will discuss the role of the confining medium in collimating the outflow as well as the intimate connection between the collimation and acceleration. The astrophysical implications of the theory of magnetically driven jets will also be described.
fields.speaker: Yuri Lyubarsky
fields.teaser_text: The primary observational fact that emerged from studies of a large class of astrophysical objects (pulsars, active galactic nuclei, gamma-ray bursts, galactic X-ray sources) is the ubiquitous occurrence of highly relativistic outflows. A promising model for that is magnetohydrodynamic acceleration by rotating, twisted magnetic fields.

fields.title: Hunting down the sources of LIGO's gravitational waves (GRAPPA/API)
fields.affiliation: Max Planck Institute for Gravitational Physics
fields.text: We expect the first detections by the ground-based gravitational wave detector network (LIGO, VIRGO), after the upgrades currently in progress, to happen between 2016 and 2018. The first events are likely to be coalescences of compact binaries of neutron stars or black holes. I will review the current activities of the collaboration to get ready for this: hardware upgrades, the data analysis preparation, data release policy, and agreements with telescope consortia for follow-up observations. Then I will examine the kind of detective work that will be needed in order to localise the events to specific galaxies (using follow-up observations across the electromagnetic spectrum) and what the scientific return can be expected to be. Finally I will preview longer-term developments now in train, such as the new detectors in Japan and India, and what impact they will have on gravitational wave astronomy.
fields.speaker: Bernard Schutz
fields.teaser_text: We expect the first detections by the ground-based gravitational wave detector network (LIGO, VIRGO), after the upgrades currently in progress, to happen between 2016 and 2018. The first events are likely to be coalescences of compact binaries of neutron stars or black holes.

fields.title: Revealing bow shocks around young and old stars in the far-infrared with Herschel
fields.text: When stars plough at supersonic speeds through space the interaction between their stellar winds and the surrounding medium can give rise to spectacular looking bow shocks. Though the basic physics are the same, the sizes and shapes of these bow shocks can vary drastically for different types of stars or different conditions of the ISM. Even binarity or internal stellar processes can be decisive in shaping the observed interaction regions. In this talk I will focus on recent Herschel and WISE observations of bow shocks around both young hot stars and old cool stars.
fields.speaker: Nick Cox
fields.teaser_text: When stars plough at supersonic speeds through space the interaction between their stellar winds and the surrounding medium can give rise to spectacular looking bow shocks. Though the basic physics are the same, the sizes and shapes of these bow shocks can vary drastically for different types of stars or different conditions of the ISM.

fields.title: Reconstructing the complex formation history of high-mass star-forming regions
fields.text: Massive stars are typically observed to form in clustered environments, with morphologies ranging from very dense, centrally concentrated starburst clusters to loose associations. These associations and clusters are morphologically and dynamically different. It is not clear if these differences arise from different initial conditions in the star formation process or environmental effects, like triggered star formation. We have started a large observational campaign to derive the star formation history of several massive star formation complexes in order to reconstruct the star formation mechanisms. I will demonstrate that near-infrared spectroscopy and photometry using LBT and VLT, combined with a large suite of multi-wavelength observations allow us to obtain a detailed picture of the stellar clusters and their stellar populations. Different stellar populations are found in many embedded clusters, suggesting that the star formation history is much more complex than a single star formation event. Based on LBT multi-object spectroscopy of the massive stellar content of W3 Main I will present strong evidence for an age spread where the oldest massive star formed 2-3 Myrs ago while some other massive stars are still in their formation process.
fields.speaker: Arjan Bik
fields.teaser_text: Massive stars are typically observed to form in clustered environments, with morphologies ranging from very dense, centrally concentrated starburst clusters to loose associations. These associations and clusters are morphologically and dynamically different. It is not clear if these differences arise from different initial conditions in the star formation process or environmental effects, like triggered star formation.

fields.title: MeerKAT and radio transients: the ThunderKAT Large Survey Project
fields.text: MeerKAT is South Africa's SKA precursor telescope. It will consist of 64 13.5-m offset Gregorian radio dishes, and will form part of the SKA Phase 1 mid-frequency array. MeerKAT is currently under construction and is expected to start full scientific operations in 2016. Ten large survey projects (LSP) have been defined on MeerKAT, collectively taking up 70% of the available time during the first five years of scientific operation. One of the MeerKAT LSPs, ThunderKAT, is focussed on the study of radio transients and relates to understanding accretion processes and accretion-related outflow in compact binaries (accreting black holes, neutron stars and white dwarfs), supernovae and gamma-ray bursts. I will present details of the ThunderKAT project, with a particular emphasis on the commensal nature of the search for transients and its associated comprehensive multi-wavelength programme. I will show preliminary results of KAT-7 observations of radio transients obtained during the science commissioning phase of KAT-7.
fields.speaker: Patrick Woudt
fields.teaser_text: MeerKAT is South Africa's SKA precursor telescope.  Ten large survey projects (LSP) have been defined on MeerKAT, collectively taking up 70% of the available time during the first five years of scientific operation. One of the MeerKAT LSPs, ThunderKAT, is focussed on the study of radio transients and relates to understanding accretion processes and accretion-related outflow in compact binaries (accreting black holes, neutron stars and white dwarfs), supernovae and gamma-ray bursts.

fields.title: Searching for the identity of the dark matter in our backyard (GRAPPA/API)
fields.text: The LCDM cosmological model accounts for an impressive array of data on the large-scale structure of the universe, from scales of a few megaparsecs to a few gigaparsecs. On submegaparsec scales, however, the model cannot be tested with the same degree of rigour as on larger scales where microwave background radiation data and measures of galaxy clustering provide clean and well-understood diagnostics. Yet, it is precisely on these small scales that the nature of the dark matter manifests itself most clearly. I will discuss theoretical predictions for the small-scale structure of the universe which appear to be discrepant with recent kinematical data for satellite galaxies of the Milky Way. Possible solutions range from the relatively mundane - that the mass of our galaxy is smaller than is often thought - through exotic baryonic processes to the more radical assumption that the dark matter is not what the standard theory assumes.
fields.speaker: Carlos Frenk
fields.teaser_text:
The LCDM cosmological model accounts for an impressive array of data on the large-scale structure of the universe, from scales of a few megaparsecs to a few gigaparsecs. On submegaparsec scales, however, the model cannot be tested with the same degree of rigour as on larger scales where microwave background radiation data and measures of galaxy clustering provide clean 
and well-understood diagnostics.

fields.title: Particle Acceleration by Shocks (GRAPPA/API)
fields.text: Diffusive shock acceleration is the most likely explanation for many occurrences of energetic particles on scales ranging from the heliosphere to clusters of galaxies and with energies ranging from MeV to EeV.  Remarkable progress has been made in the past decade in confronting theory with observation.  We are increasingly able to make firm statements about how, where, when and to what energies particles are accelerated.  However, some of the biggest questions remain unanswered.
fields.speaker: Tony Bell
fields.teaser_text: Hear all about astrophysical particle acceleration from the person who is one of the founding fathers of Fermi shock acceleration theory.

fields.title: Exploring dark matter through the curvature of space-time (GRAPPA/API)
fields.text: Dark matter is thought to compose most of the gravitating mass of the Universe, even though it has never directly been detected directly and its properties remain ill understood. Gravitational lensing, i.e. the (apparent) bending of light caused by curved-space time, provides a unique way to make the distribution of dark-matter structure visible in the Universe, even in cases where no radiation-emitting baryons are present in these structures. I will present a number of very recent and exciting results that shed light on the distribution of dark matter in and around galaxies and shortly discus the consequences of our findings for the understanding of the properties of dark matter.
fields.speaker: Leon Koopmans
fields.teaser_text: I will present a number of very recent and exciting results that shed light on the distribution of dark matter in and around galaxies and shortly discus the consequences of our findings for the understanding of the properties of dark matter.

fields.title: Christmas colloquium: 25 years of Skepsis - Garbage collector or conscience?
fields.text:
Skepsis is one of the many organisations that have made skepticism about astrology, alien contacts and acupuncture their business - and that's just the letter A. Scientists often don't pay attention to 'garbage', but someone has to do it. That's what Skepsis has been doing for 25 years now.

Jan Willem Nienhuys is a former mathematician and secretary of the Dutch Foundation Skepsis.
fields.speaker: Jan Willem Nienhuys
fields.teaser_text: Skepsis is one of the many organisations that have made skepticism about astrology, alien contacts and acupuncture their business - and that's just the letter A.

fields.title: Powering of cool filaments in the cores of galaxy clusters
fields.text:
Cool-core clusters often possess a network of bright gaseous filaments,
observed in radio, IR, optical and X-ray bands. We propose that these
filaments are powered by the reconnection of the magnetic field in the
wakes of buoyant bubbles. AGN-inflated bubbles of relativistic plasma rise
buoyantly in the cluster atmosphere, stretching and amplifying the field
in the wake. The field lines in the wake have opposite directions and are
forced together as the bubble motion stretches the filament. This setup
bears strong similarity to the coronal loops on the Sun or the Earth
magneto-tail. The reconnection process naturally explains both the
required level of local dissipation rate in filaments and the overall
luminosity of filaments. The original source of power for the filaments is
the potential energy of buoyant bubbles, inflated by the central AGN.
fields.speaker: Eugene Churazov
fields.teaser_text: Eugene Churazov is one of the most versatile astrophysicist around, working both as theorist and on data analysis. In the colloquium will tells us all about the importance of magnetic fields in cool core clusters of galaxies.

fields.title: API/GRAPPA colloquium: The Death of Massive Stars
fields.text: Core-collapse supernovae from massive stars are among the most energetic events in the universe. They liberate a mass-energy equivalent of ~15% of a solar mass in the collapse of their progenitor star's core. The majority (~99%) of this energy is carried away by neutrinos, while (~1%) is transferred to the kinetic energy of the explosive outflow. A smaller, yet still tremendous amount of energy is emitted in electromagnetic and gravitational waves. I review our current understanding of core collapse and its range of outcomes. I present and discuss recent results from detailed two- and three-dimensional simulations on the roles of hydrodynamic instabilities in the pre-explosion phase and the development of globally asymmetric explosions. These new computational models also yield deeper insights into the signature of core-collapse supernovae in neutrinos and gravitational waves.
