I outline how their observation from the next nearby core collapse event can shed light on properties of the progenitor and the dynamics and thermodynamics of the supernova engine.
fields.speaker: Christian Ott
fields.teaser_text: Core-collapse supernovae from massive stars are among the most energetic events in the universe. I will discuss recent results from detailed  simulations on the roles of hydrodynamic instabilities in the pre-explosion phase and the development of globally asymmetric explosions.

fields.title: Highly magnetic neutron stars: bewildering astrophysical laboratories and cosmological tools
fields.text: Anomalous X-ray Pulsars and Soft Gamma-Ray Repeaters (SGRs) are young neutron stars characterized by high X-ray quiescent luminosities, outbursts, and, in the case of SGRs, sporadic giant flares. They are believed to be magnetars, that is neutron stars powered by ultra-strong magnetic fields. However, the diversity of their behaviours, and, especially, the observation of magnetar-like bursts from 'low-field' neutron stars, has been a theoretical puzzle. In the first part of the talk, I will discuss results of long-term MHD simulations which, by following the evolution of magnetic stresses within the neutron star crust, have allowed to relate the observed magnetar phenomenology to the physical properties of the neutron stars, and in particular to their age and magnetic field strength and topology. The dichotomy of 'high-B' field pulsars versus magnetars is naturally explained, and occasional outbursts from old, low B-field neutron stars are predicted. In the second part of the talk, I will discuss how observations of highly magnetized neutron stars can be handy tools in the cosmological domain, and in particular as a way to set constraints on the hypothetical particle 'axion'.
fields.speaker: Rosalba Perna
fields.teaser_text: Anomalous X-ray Pulsars and Soft Gamma-Ray Repeaters (SGRs) are young neutron stars characterized by high X-ray quiescent luminosities, outbursts, and, in the case of SGRs, sporadic giant flares.  They are believed to be magnetars, that is neutron stars powered by ultra-strong magnetic fields.

fields.title: Water in space: from interstellar clouds to planet-forming disks
fields.text:
Water is a key molecule in the physics and chemistry of regions in which new stars and planets are born. In the 'Water in Star-forming Regions with Herschel' (WISH) Key Program, we are obtaining a comprehensive set of gaseous water data toward a large sample of well-characterized protostars, covering a wide range of masses and luminosities -from the lowest to the highest mass protostars-, as well as evolutionary stages -from the earliest stages represented by pre-stellar cores to the late stages represented by the pre-main sequence stars surrounded only by disks. The data elucidate the physical processes responsible for the warm gas, probe dynamical processes associated with forming stars and planets (outflow, infall, expansion), test basic gas-phase and gas-grain chemical processes, and reveal the chemical evolution of water and the oxygen-reservoir into planet-forming disks. New insight into the origin of the water in oceans on Earth comes from observations of deuterated water. Future prospects for the Atacama Large Millimeter Array (ALMA) are discussed as well.

This talk is presented on behalf of the entire WISH team. More details can be found on the website of WISH.
fields.speaker: Ewine van Dishoeck
fields.teaser_text: Water is a key molecule in the physics and chemistry of regions in which new stars and planets are born. In the 'Water in Star-forming Regions with Herschel' (WISH) Key Program, we are obtaining a comprehensive set of gaseous water data toward a large sample of well-characterized protostars, covering a wide range of masses and luminosities.

fields.title: Über-massive black holes
fields.text: All massive galaxies likely have supermassive black holes at their centers, and the masses of the black holes are known to correlate with properties of the host galaxy.  A spectroscopic survey of 700 nearby galaxies revealed several disky galaxies with extremely high velocity dispersions (>375 km/s) and at the same time shockingly small sizes and low luminosities. These systems all appear to have extremely big black hole masses. This shows that the black holes in these systems did not co-evolve with its host galaxy, which is in stark conflict with the popular co-evolution picture of black hole and host.
fields.speaker: Remco van den Bosch
fields.teaser_text: All massive galaxies likely have supermassive black holes at their centers, and the masses of the black holes are known to correlate with properties of the host galaxy.  A spectroscopic survey of 700 nearby galaxies revealed several disky galaxies with extremely high velocity dispersions and at the same time shockingly small sizes and low luminosities.

fields.title: The Green Valley is a Red Herring: How, When and Why Galaxies Quench
fields.text: Galaxies are broadly split into those forming stars on the main sequence, and those which are quiescent. The physical processes by which galaxies quench their star formation remain poorly understood. I will review the properties of galaxies and attempt to track their evolutionary trajectories as they migrate from the blue cloud of star forming galaxies to the red sequence of quiescent galaxies via the 'green valley', the population of galaxies that exists in-between. I will discuss how star formation quenching might proceed and how both active galactic nucleus feedback and large scale structure might influence it.
fields.speaker: Kevin Schawinski
fields.teaser_text: Galaxies are broadly split into those forming stars on the main sequence, and those which are quiescent. The physical processes by which galaxies quench their star formation remain poorly understood.

fields.title: Gravitational Waves and the spin-down of young pulsars
fields.text: The rotation frequencies of young pulsars are systematically below their theoretical Kepler limit. R-modes have been suggested as a possible explanation for this observation. With the help of semi-analytic expressions that make it possible to assess the uncertainties of the r-mode scenario due to the underlying microphysics, we perform a quantitative analysis of the spin-down and the emitted gravitational waves of young pulsars. We find that the frequency to which r-modes spin down a young neutron star as well as the characteristic gravitational wave strain amplitude are extremely insensitive both to the microscopic details and the saturation amplitude. Comparing our result to astrophysical data, we show that for a range of saturation amplitudes r-modes provide a viable spindown scenario and that all observed young pulsars are very likely already outside of the r-mode instability region.
fields.speaker: Kai Schwenzer
fields.teaser_text: The rotation frequencies of young pulsars are systematically below their theoretical Kepler limit. R-modes have been suggested as a possible explanation for this observation. With the help of semi-analytic expressions  we perform a quantitative analysis of the spin-down and the emitted gravitational waves of young pulsars.

fields.title: The Galactic population of very high energy gamma-ray sources (GRAPPA/API)
fields.text: The last few years have witnessed a revolution in very high gamma-ray astronomy (VHE; E>100 GeV) driven largely by a new generation of Cherenkov telescopes. These new facilities, namely H.E.S.S. and the new 28-meter-sized mirror H.E.S.S. 2, MAGIC and its upgrade MAGIC 2, Veritas and CANGAROO were designed to increase the flux sensitivity in the energy regime of hundreds of GeV, expanding the observed energy range from 100 (50) GeV to multi-TeV, and fostered as a result a period of rapid growth in our understanding of the Non-Thermal Universe. As a result of this fast development the number of new VHE Galactic sources detected has increased from a few in the early 90's to nearly 50 Galactic sources nowadays. A review of the most relevant Galactic VHE results will be discussed, emphasizing the most important discoveries, including supernova remnants, pulsars and their winds, binary systems and yet not-identified sources, unveiled by the H.E.S.S. Galactic Plane Survey.
fields.speaker: Emma de Oña Wilhelmi
fields.teaser_text: Find out all about TeV gamma-ray sources in the Galaxy.

fields.title: How to kill a giant molecular cloud
fields.text: What controls the life expectancy of a giant molecular cloud is a hotly debated subject. One view is that supernovae blow away the surrounding gas. Other opinions suggest this mechanism occurs too late, and earlier feedback is responsible for cloud destruction. This talk presents results from a high resolution (< 10pc) numerical simulation of a global Milky-way type galaxy which includes thermal feedback. We follow the evolution of the GMCs as they interact in the disc, form stars and undergo supernovae-type thermal energy injection. At the end, we postulate which of the events occurring in their lifetime dominates their evolution.
fields.speaker: Elizabeth Tasker
fields.teaser_text: What controls the life expectancy of a giant molecular cloud is a hotly debated subject. One view is that supernovae blow away the surrounding gas. Other opinions suggest this mechanism occurs too late, and earlier feedback is responsible for cloud destruction.

fields.title: Evidence for Asymmetric Distribution of Circumstellar Material around Type Ia Supernovae
fields.text: We have studied the properties of low-velocity material in the line of sight toward nearby Type Ia supernovae (SNe Ia) that have measured late phase nebular velocity shifts (v_neb), thought to be an environment-independent observable. We found that the distribution of equivalent widths of narrow blended Na I D1 and D2 and Ca II H and K absorption lines differs significantly between those SNe Ia with negative and positive v_neb, with generally stronger absorption for SNe Ia with v_neb >= 0. A similar result had been found previously for the distribution of colors of SNe Ia, which was interpreted as a dependence of the temperature of the ejecta with viewing angle. Our work suggests that (1) a significant part of these differences in color should be attributed to extinction, (2) this extinction is caused by an asymmetric distribution of circumstellar material (CSM), and (3) the CSM absorption is generally stronger on the side of the ejecta opposite to where the ignition occurs. Since it is difficult to explain (3) via any known physical processes that occur before explosion, we argue that the asymmetry of the CSM is originated after explosion by a stronger ionizing flux on the side of the ejecta where ignition occurs, probably due to a stronger shock breakout and/or more exposed radioactive material on one side of the ejecta. This result has important implications for both progenitor and explosion models.
fields.speaker: Francisco Förster
fields.teaser_text: We have studied the properties of low-velocity material in the line of sight toward nearby Type Ia supernovae (SNe Ia) that have measured late phase nebular velocity shifts (v_neb), thought to be an environment-independent observable.

fields.title: Herschel observations of EXtra-Ordinary Sources: Exploring the Molecular Universe with Broad-Band Spectroscopy (NOVA colloquium)
fields.text: I will present the results from a Herschel guaranteed time key program (HEXOS) which obtained complete spectra, from ~158 to 610 microns with R~100,000 and down to 60 microns with R ~1000, of template objects in the Milky Way. Our targets are (1) Orion KL and Sagittarius B2 North, two luminous star forming hot molecular cores that are the richest organic factories in our galaxy, and Orion S, a less luminous counterpart, (2) the Orion Bar, the closest and best characterized photodissociation region (PDR) where dense molecular gas is exposed to energetic stellar radiation, and (3) Sagittarius B2 Middle, the strongest submillimeter continuum source in the galaxy that provides a candle to explore diverse regions between the Sun and the galactic center. The plethora of data available in the Herchel spectra presents significant challenges for analysis. I will discuss the techniques applied to model the entire spectrum at once; in Orion KL alone we model the emission from over 60 species and detect > 20,000 molecular lines. I will then highlight how these results give clues to organic formation, hint at hidden sources of luminosity, characterize the gas thermal balance in galactic templates for hot cores, shocks, and PDRs, and directly constrain the formation rate of one of the most important ion-molecule reactions chains in the Universe.
fields.speaker: Ted Bergin
fields.teaser_text: I will present the results from a Herschel guaranteed time key program (HEXOS) which obtained complete spectra of template objects in the Milky Way. The plethora of data available in the Herchel spectra presents significant challenges for analysis.

fields.title: AGN in the light of stellar mass black holes
fields.text: I will review what we know of the accretion flow in stellar mass black hole binaries, then compare these to AGN to highlight the differences as well as the similarlies which are seen.
fields.speaker: Chris Done
fields.teaser_text: I will review what we know of the accretion flow in stellar mass black hole binaries, then compare these to AGN to highlight the differences as well as the similarlies which are seen.

fields.title: The 511 keV emission from positron annihilation in the Milky Way
fields.text:
The first gamma-ray line originating from outside the solar system that was ever detected is the 511 keV emission from positron annihilation in the Galaxy. Despite 30 years of intense theoretical and observational investigation, the main sources of positrons have not been identified up to now. In the 2000's, the SPI instrument aboard ESA's INTEGRAL gamma-ray observatory allowed scientists to measure that emission across the entire Galaxy, revealing that the bulge/disk luminosity ratio is larger than observed in any other wavelength. This mapping prompted a number of novel explanations, including rather ``exotic'' ones (e.g. dark matter annihilation). However, conventional astrophysical sources, like type Ia supernovae, microquasars or X-ray binaries, are still plausible candidates for a large fraction of the observed total 511 keV emission of the bulge.

I shall review the spectral and imaging properties of the observed 511 keV emission and I shall critically discuss candidate positron sources and models of positron propagation in the Galaxy.
fields.speaker: Nikolas Prantzos
fields.teaser_text: The first   gamma-ray line originating from outside the solar system that was ever detected is the 511 keV   emission from positron annihilation in the Galaxy. I shall review the spectral and imaging properties  of the observed 511 keV  emission and I shall critically discuss  candidate positron sources.

fields.title: Searching for pulsars in nearby galaxies
fields.text: I will present some of the results of two recent surveys of pulsars in which I have been participating. The first is a search for pulsars and fast radio transients undertaken with the Westerbork Synthesis Radio Telescope at 328 MHz in M31 while the second is a survey of pulsars and fast radio transients I am conducting in the satellite galaxies of the Milky Way. I will review what we can learn from these searches and how in principle, we can use pulsars to gain some insights on the dark matter content of the dwarf satellite galaxies of the Milky Way.
fields.speaker: Eduardo Rubio-Herrera
fields.teaser_text: I will present some of the results of two recent surveys of pulsars in which I have been participating. The first is a search for pulsars and fast radio transients undertaken with the Westerbork Synthesis Radio Telescope at 328 MHz in M31 while the second is a survey of pulsars and fast radio transients I am conducting in the satellite galaxies of the Milky Way.

fields.title: Magnetars: New stars, New Physics
fields.affiliation: Jamia Millia Islamia University, New Delhi
fields.text: I will talk on a a model for magnetars soniin which the strong interaction creates a spin aligned magnetic core at birth. The consequent magnetic field is screened by the surrounding sonin,p,e plasma. Ambipolar diffusion transports the magnetic field to the crust. The field then cleaves the crust powering the radiative activity of  the magnetar.
fields.speaker: Vikram Soni
fields.teaser_text: I will talk on a a model for magnetars soniin which the strong interaction creates a spin aligned magnetic core at birth.

fields.title: In search of the birthcocoons of planets
fields.text: Planet formation suffers from a fundamental problem called the "fragmentation and drift barrier". I will explain, using simple physical principles, what this barrier is and why it is such a difficult barrier to overcome. I will show that "pressure traps" can trap particles in localized regions in the disk and may thereby help overcome this barrier. Finally I will show that recent millimeter observations of protoplanetary disks may in fact already be showing evidence for these pressure traps, and that ALMA is the tool to verify this.
fields.speaker: Kees Dullemond
fields.teaser_text: Planet formation suffers from a fundamental problem called the "fragmentation and drift barrier". I will explain, using simple physical principles, what this barrier is and why it is such a difficult barrier to overcome.

fields.title: Small dust particles in the Solar System and beyond
fields.text: Small dust particles are present in a wide variety of scenarios ranging from the Earth atmosphere to other planetary and cometary atmospheres in the Solar system, interplanetary medium, reflection nebulae, atmospheres of brown dwarfs, etc.  By analyzing the solar light scattered by those particles we can retrieve valuable information about their physical properties (shape, size, and composition) as well as their location within a certain atmosphere. The main purpose of this talk is to show how experimental data of intensity and polarization of the scattered light of different dust analogues can be used to shed some light on the nature of dust particles in the Solar System and beyond.
fields.speaker: Olga Muñoz
fields.teaser_text: Small dust particles are present in a wide variety of scenarios ranging from the Earth atmosphere to other planetary and cometary atmospheres in the Solar system.  By analyzing the solar light scattered by those particles we can retrieve valuable information about their physical properties as well as their location within a certain atmosphere.

fields.title: Pinpointing pulsars in 3D
fields.text: The potential of Very Long Baseline Interferometry (VLBI) observations has increased steadily in recent years, to the point where it is now possible to accurately localise compact mJy objects - in 3D - at distances of 10 kpc. With current instrumentation, most of the known Galactic radio pulsar population is already accessible to precision mapping. I will present results from recent and ongoing VLBI programs showing how astrometric observations of both individual pulsars and pulsar ensembles can be used to provide information about stellar evolution, fundamental physics and the ISM. I will also examine how techniques which have until now been used in primarily in pulsar astrometry might give considerable benefits for other targets such as X-ray binaries.
fields.speaker: Adam Deller
fields.teaser_text: The potential of Very Long Baseline Interferometry (VLBI) observations has increased steadily in recent years, to the point where it is now possible to accurately localise compact mJy objects at distances of 10 kpc.

fields.title: The search for AM CVn systems with the Palomar Transient Factory
fields.text: I will discuss the Palomar Transient Factory (PTF), particularly its capabilities for detection of variable objects, and my own search for outbursting AM CVn systems - rare, ultra-compact binaries. The PTF uses the Palomar 48" Schmidt telescope to image 7 sq. deg. of the sky to R~20.6 in one exposure, with up to 1,800 sq. deg. covered per night. With a typical cadence of 2-3 days, the PTF has proven to be an effective tool for variable star study. As part of my work, I have implemented relative photometry calibration to achieve errors of 6-8 mmag at the bright end. The availability of this rich data set has allowed us to select several hundred sources showing distinct outbursts. I will present the results of our follow-up spectroscopic survey, which has yielded several hundred new CVs and 7 new AM CVn systems - 20% of the known systems. We are now using these systems, together with period information obtained from phase-resolved spectroscopy, to test current AM CVn system population models.
fields.speaker: David Levitan
fields.teaser_text: I will discuss the Palomar Transient Factory (PTF), particularly its capabilities for detection of variable objects, and my own search for outbursting AM CVn systems - rare, ultra-compact binaries. The PTF uses the Palomar 48" Schmidt telescope to image 7 sq. deg. of the sky to R~20.6 in one exposure, with up to 1,800 sq. deg. covered per night.  The availability of this rich data set has allowed us to select several hundred sources showing distinct outbursts.

fields.title: Imaging a Black Hole Shadow with the Event Horizon Telescope
fields.text: In 1973, Jim Bardeen calculated that a black hole should cast a shadow more than twice the size of its event horizon, and imaging the immediate surroundings of a black hole has been a goal of astrophysics ever since. Ongoing very long baseline interferometry observations at millimeter wavelengths are realizing this goal by using radio dishes across the world to form an Event Horizon Telescope. These observations will allow the precise study of accretion & outflows and will probe general relativity in the strong field regime. The two most promising targets are the Galactic center black hole candidate, Sagittarius A*, and M87, known for its kiloparsec-scale jet; and event horizon scale structure has been detected in both sources. Maximizing the science return on the observations requires detailed theoretical modeling of the accretion flows in both sources, and this problem is especially well suited to contemporary numerical simulations. I will discuss black hole images, light curves, and spectra calculated from simulations and their comparison with current data. The models are in excellent agreement with observations, and already constrain the properties of the black hole and its accretion flow. The black hole shadow may be accessible within the next 5-10 years, and its detection would constitute the first direct evidence for an event horizon in the Universe.
fields.speaker: Jason Dexter
fields.teaser_text: In 1973, Jim Bardeen calculated that a black hole should cast a shadow more than twice the size of its event horizon, and imaging the immediate surroundings of a black hole has been a goal of astrophysics ever since. Ongoing very long baseline interferometry observations at millimeter wavelengths are realizing this goal by using radio dishes across the world to form an Event Horizon Telescope.

fields.title: MSc colloquium:  Mode changing and drifting subpulses in two exciting pulsars: B1822-09 and B0826-34
fields.text: We have investigated a set of pulsars to analyze their emission mechanism, specifically their mode changing and drifting behavior. Our main goal was to find rotation times of the emission features around the magnetic pole. Pulsars B0826-34 and B1822-09 were chosen for their interesting mode-changing behavior: PSR B1822-09 is a pulsar with two distinct modes, with subpulse-drift in one mode. We especially looked at the transitions from one mode to the other, and find a modulation that could be the "carousel" rotation time for B1822-09's Quiet mode. Pulsar PSR B0826-34 shows two distinct modes plus nulling and drifting in two directions. In this source we the shortest ever burst of strong-mode emission; and we find that the weak mode of pulsar B0826-34, which was first believed to be a phase of nulling, actually has sporadic, spiky emission.
fields.speaker: Raoul Ermans
fields.teaser_text: We have investigated a set of pulsars to analyze their emission mechanism, specifically their mode changing and drifting behavior. Our main goal was to find rotation times of the emission features around the magnetic pole.

fields.title: Dissecting the Galactic Halo (NOVA Colloquium)
fields.text: Larger structures in the Universe are thought to form hierarchically from the mergers of many smaller structures. This talk will present three topics that exploit this nature to learn about the Galaxy: (i) results form a survey of clouds of stellar debris; (ii) a method to combine Spitzer and Gaia data to measure the potential of the Milky Way; and (iii) prospects for recovering Galactic accretion history from abundance-space studies.
fields.speaker: Kathryn Johnston
fields.teaser_text: Larger structures in the Universe are thought to form hierarchically from the mergers of many smaller structures. This talk will present three topics that exploit this nature to learn about the Galaxy.

fields.title: A few things I picked up along the way
fields.text: Adventures with Classical Cepheids and RR Lyrae Stars in the Magellanic Clouds and the Milky Way.
fields.speaker: Jan Lub
fields.teaser_text: Adventures with Classical Cepheids and RR Lyrae Stars in the Magellanic Clouds and the Milky Way.

fields.title: The first billion years of galaxy formation
fields.text: Understanding when the first galaxies form and how they evolve into the population of the present day universe is one of the most exciting and challenging questions of modern astronomical research. Ultradeep imaging surveys with the Hubble Space Telescope and Spitzer Space Telescope are now revealing thousands of galaxies in the very distant universe with redshifts of 4 and greater, up to and including z~10.  However, fundamental questions remain: when did the earliest galaxies form? What determines galaxy growth? What are the descendants of these earliest galaxies? I will provide an overview of recent results, focusing on galaxy properties in the first billion years, and speculate on what we might learn with next-generation facilities such as ALMA, JWST, and 20 40m class telescopes.
fields.speaker: Ivo Labbe
fields.teaser_text: Understanding when the first galaxies form and how they evolve into the population of the present day universe is one of the most exciting and challenging questions of modern astronomical research.  Ultradeep imaging surveys are now revealing thousands of galaxies in the very distant universe with redshifts of 4 and greater.

fields.title: Here Be Dragons:  The Dynamic Radio Sky (NOVA Colloquium)
fields.text: Radio variability probes a wide range of astrophysical phenomena from the solar system to the early Universe including black holes, neutron stars, gravitational wave sources, tidal disruption events, and relativistic shocks from collapsing stars. Radio follow-up of events discovered at optical, X-ray, and gamma-ray wavelengths demonstrates a rich phenomenology but we lack a systematic and sensitive view of radio variability. Our efforts in recent years with the Very Large Array (VLA) and the Allen Telescope Array (ATA) have provided the beginnings of an unbiased exploration on time scales from milliseconds to decades. Powered by development of unique digital instrumentation, new algorithms, and new survey strategies, our surveys have defined the shape of next generation radio telescopes and surveys. In particular, these surveys are shaping our understanding of radio supernovae, tidal disruption events, and gravitational-wave sources. Planned surveys with newly commissioned national facilities such as the Expanded Very Large Array (EVLA), LOFAR, the Australian SKA Pathfinder (ASKAP), and the South African MeerKAT telescopes coupled with the development of new instrumentation will extend our reach into new parameter space.
fields.speaker: Geoff Bower
fields.teaser_text: Radio variability probes a wide range of astrophysical phenomena from the solar system to the early Universe including black holes, neutron stars, gravitational wave sources, tidal disruption events, and relativistic shocks from collapsing stars. Our efforts with the Very Large Array and the Allen Telescope Array have provided the beginnings of an unbiased exploration on time scales from milliseconds to decades.

fields.title: Beyond X-ray timing: fast multi-wavelength variability from the vicinity of compact objects
fields.text: The study of X-ray variability in X-ray binaries has represented - and still is - one of the most powerful tools to study the accretion ﬂow in the vicinity of compact objects. A wealth of multi-wavelength campaigns during the last decade has shown that significant emission at shorter wavelengths than X-rays can be detected from the same inner regions studied through X-ray timing. At the same time, the advent of new instrumentation has made possible to extend high time resolution astronomy to such wavelengths, in particular optical and infrared. This is now opening new exciting windows, allowing the study of multi-wavelength fast variable emission from X-ray binaries, and ultimately offering a more complete picture of what happens in the vicinity of black holes and neutron stars. This field is at its dawn, but it is already showing its large potential. I will review the state of the art, the available optical and infrared instruments, and show how having an X-ray timing satellite flying in the near future will be crucial to fully harness the great potential of these techniques.
fields.speaker: Piergiorgio Casella
fields.teaser_text: The study of X-ray variability in X-ray binaries has represented - and still is - one of the most powerful tools to study the accretion ﬂow in the vicinity of compact objects. A wealth of multi-wavelength campaigns during the last decade has shown that significant emission at shorter wavelengths than X-rays can be detected from the same inner regions studied through X-ray timing.

fields.title: The Radiation-Driven Magneto-Acoustic Instability
fields.text: Any astrophysical environment that is moderately optically thick, stably-stratified, and threaded by a magnetic field can become unstable to the Radiation-Driven Magneto-Acoustic Instability (RMI). Examples of these environments are the radiative envelopes of massive stars, or the sub-photospheric layers of black hole accretion disks and protoneutron stars. The RMI generates persistent density, radiative flux, and magnetic field fluctuations by destabilizing compressible (magnetosonic) MHD waves. I will discuss results of radiation-magnetohydrodynamic simulations that probe the non-linear development of the RMI for weak radiation pressure and magnetic fields, with implications for the variability of massive stars with magnetized radiative envelopes and neutrino emission from protoneutron stars.
fields.speaker: Rodrigo Fernandez
fields.teaser_text: Any astrophysical environment that is moderately optically thick, stably-stratified, and threaded by a magnetic field can become unstable to the Radiation-Driven Magneto-Acoustic Instability (RMI).  I will discuss results of radiation-magnetohydrodynamic simulations that probe the non-linear development of the RMI for weak radiation pressure and magnetic fields.

fields.title: Ionized and Molecular Gas Dynamics in High-Mass Star Forming Regions
fields.text: High mass stars are key drivers of the evolution of galaxies and lead to the creation of all heavy elements in the universe. While the life and death of high mass stars is well constrained, their formation remains one of the few basic processes in our Galaxy yet to be explained.  There are models which are able to describe the formation of stars as massive as about 30 M_sun, but beyond that, the mechanisms responsible for overcoming the radiation pressure from the star, and the ionisation feedback within the forming HII region are not clear.  To study the processes involved in forming the most massive stars requires understanding the gas dynamics on both sides of the ionisation boundary.  In my talk, I will show some preliminary studies of the relationship between the gas dynamics in these two gas populations, and why these observational studies are about to get a lot more interesting.
fields.speaker: Pamela Klaassen
fields.teaser_text: High mass stars are key drivers of the evolution of galaxies and lead to the creation of all heavy elements in the universe. While the life and death of high mass stars is well constrained, their formation remains one of the few basic processes in our Galaxy yet to be explained.

fields.title: AGN disc winds: interpreting the X-ray spectra of accreting  super-massive black holes
fields.text: One of the exciting discoveries made with the current generation of X-ray observatories was the identification of highly blue-shifted, narrow absorption lines in the spectra of some active galactic nuclei. These features imply the presence of fast, highly ionized outflows that were previously unknown. This is of considerable interest since AGN outflows are a possible feedback mechanism by which growing super-massive black holes can influence their host galaxies. The origin and launching mechanism for such outflows remains unclear but they may be associated with winds blown off the accretion flow/accretion disc. I will discuss the theoretical motivation behind disk wind models, focusing on AGN line-driven winds whose properties are relatively well-characterized by numerical simulations. I will discuss results of our theoretical multi-dimensional radiative transfer simulations that provide detailed synthetic spectra for plausible wind geometries. This will include both the absorption features (including highly blue-shifted absorption lines) and broad emission features that are predicted in the wind models. By comparing these results to observations we can asses how well the theory of line-driven disk winds can account for observed spectral features.
fields.speaker: Stuart Sim
fields.teaser_text: One of the exciting discoveries made with the current generation of X-ray observatories was the identification of highly blue-shifted, narrow absorption lines in the spectra of some active galactic nuclei. These features imply the presence of fast, highly ionized outflows that were previously unknown. This is of considerable interest since AGN outflows are a possible feedback mechanism by which growing super-massive black holes can influence their host galaxies.

fields.title: Cosmic rays and energetic particles: when they hit they leave a trace (GRAPPA/API)
fields.affiliation: Institute de Planétologie et d'Astrophysique de Grenoble
fields.text:
Cosmic Rays (CR) permeate our Galaxy, largely contributing to shape the InterStellar Medium (ISM) and star formation, as they are responsible of the ionisation of the molecular gas. Since decades, the CR origin has been attributed to the explosions of SuperNovae (SN), based on energetic arguments. In the last years, the theory has gained observational ground, thanks to new observations that indirectly probe the presence of CR: gamma-rays observations and enhanced ionisation in molecular clouds near to SN remnants (SNR). This presentation focuses on the latter.
I will present old and new methods to probe the presence of <100 GeV CR, and their application. I will present observations that allow us to measure the ionisation rate in galactic molecular clouds close to SNR, but also in some star formation regions, and the peculiar chemistry induced by an enhanced flux of CR.
fields.speaker: Cecilia Ceccarelli
fields.teaser_text: This colloquium brings together low energy astrophysics (molecules) and astroparticle physics (cosmic rays)!

fields.title: Anton Pannekoek's research on the structure of the universe
fields.affiliation: Institute for History and Foundations of Science, Utrecht University
fields.text: Anton Pannekoek was a man of many talents. He was a pioneer of Dutch astronomy and astrophysics, a well respected historian of astronomy, and one of the main figures of the international socialist movement. Pannekoek maintained that his scientific work was strictly separated from his socialist philosophy. However, when we focus on his `epistemic virtues’, i.e. the norms by which he believed one could come to knowledge, a more unified picture may emerge. I will illustrate this point by addressing Pannekoek’s innovative methods for researching the structure of the galaxy.
fields.speaker: Chao Kang Tai
fields.teaser_text: Anton Pannekoek was a man of many talents. He was a pioneer of Dutch astronomy and astrophysics, a well respected historian of astronomy, and one of the main figures of the international socialist movement.

fields.title: Radio Polarimetry and the Magnetic Universe (NOVA colloquium)
fields.text: A remarkable discovery made by 20th century astronomers was that the Universe is threaded with magnetic fields. Furthermore, these magnetic fields typically do not have a random, tangled, morphology, but are surprisingly organised and coherent. However, the processes that create and then sustain this large-scale magnetism are not yet understood. I will present innovative new observations of radio polarisation and Faraday rotation, and will explain how these data sets provide a unique view of magnetic fields in interstellar gas, in the Milky Way, and in distant galaxies. These experiments pave the way to the opening of the full magnetic Universe with the next generation of radio telescopes, culminating in the Square Kilometre Array.
fields.speaker: Bryan Gaensler
fields.teaser_text: A remarkable discovery made by 20th century astronomers was that the Universe is threaded with magnetic fields. Furthermore, these magnetic fields typically do not have a random, tangled, morphology, but are surprisingly organised and coherent.

fields.title: Protoplanetary Disks: aiming to understand their structure and evolution (NOVA colloquium)
fields.text: Disks around young stars are irradiated accretion disks. As such, they are accreting mass onto the star, and the rate of this process constrains their structure and evolution. Studies of low mass populations with ages from 1 to 10 Myr indicate that disks evolve decreasing their mass accretion rates and masses as their dust grows and settles, until photoevaporation sets in, when the mass accretion rate is sufficiently low.  However, some disks develop inner clearings and gaps early. These are the transitional and pre-transitional disks and planet formation is the best explanation for their existence, as indicated by their accretion rates and masses. I will review our work in determining accretion luminosities and mass accretion rates and in applying these determinations to calculate the structure of disks and their evolution.
fields.speaker: Nuria Calvet
fields.teaser_text: Disks around young stars are irradiated accretion disks. As such, they are accreting mass onto the star, and the rate of this process constrains their structure and evolution.

fields.title: The quenching of star formation throughout the cosmic epochs (NOVA colloquium)
fields.text: Over the entire life of the Universe only 4% of the baryons have been converted into stars, while gravitational collapse and gas cooling would predict that locally about 80% of the baryons should be in stars. Hence, rather than understanding how stars have formed throughout the cosmic times, it is actually more important to understand why stars have not formed. To keep the star formation efficiency low, most models of galaxy evolution invoke some form of negative feedback. In low mass galaxies most of the feedback is thought to be associated with outflows generated by SNe and/or radiation pressure. In massive galaxies an additional source of energetic feedback is required to quench star formation and to prevent these galaxies from overgrowing. Most models suggest that this additional feedback is ascribed to the nuclear accreting black holes reaching quasar-like luminosities, which should generate massive outflows cleaning the host galaxies of its gas content, hence quenching star formation. Energy injection into the intergalactic medium through radio jets should also prevent cooling of gas onto the galaxy, hence preventing additional star formation.  While on the theoretical front multiple quenching scenarios have been proposed in the past, direct observational evidence of star formation quenching and negative feedback in galaxies has been obtained only recently. I will review such observational evidences both locally and in the distant Universe. I will show that, while some of the theoretical expectations have been nicely confirmed by observations, some unexpected observational results are in tension with theoretical predictions, posing new challenges for our understanding of galaxy formation throughout the cosmic epochs. I will discuss the prospects of tackling outstanding open questions in this field by means of future observing facilities.
fields.speaker: Roberto Maiolino
fields.teaser_text: Over the entire life of the Universe only 4% of the baryons have been converted into stars, while gravitational collapse and gas cooling would predict that locally about 80% of the baryons should be in stars. Hence, rather than understanding how stars have formed throughout the cosmic times, it is actually more important to understand why stars have not formed.

fields.title: Solving the Mystery of Weak Emission Line Quasars at High Redshift
fields.text: Since strong and broad emission lines are a hallmark of quasar spectra, the recent discovery of luminous, high redshift quasars with strong blue continua but extremely weak or undetectable emission lines is puzzling. I will present a step-by-step overview of multiwavelength observations that provided insights into the nature of these remarkable sources. In particular, I will show that the weakness of their emission lines is unlikely to be due to line absorption, dust obscuration, gravitational lensing or microlensing effects, or relativistic beaming. Finally, I will describe an observational and theoretical effort required to distinguish between several scenarios that have been proposed to explain the weakness of the emission lines in these sources. Solving the mystery about this rare class of quasars will shed light on emission-line formation and the accretion process in all active galactic nuclei.
fields.speaker: Ohad Shemmer
fields.teaser_text: Since strong and broad emission lines are a hallmark of quasar spectra, the recent discovery of luminous, high redshift quasars with strong blue continua but extremely weak or undetectable emission lines is puzzling.   Solving the mystery about this rare class of quasars will shed light on emission-line formation and the accretion process in all active galactic nuclei.

fields.title: Zooming in on Dark Matter and Quasar Emission Regions through Gravitational Lensing
fields.text: Under favorable conditions, the light from a distant quasar (an actively accreting supermassive black hole) can be gravitationally lensed by an intervening galaxy to produce four images of the quasar. I will discuss an innovative technique of analyzing these quadruply-lensed quasars in optical and X-ray emission that, for the first time, is able to resolve the structure of the accretion disk around the black hole. I will present X-ray observations of more than a dozen lensed quasars recorded with the Chandra X-ray Observatory as well as corresponding optical data obtained with either the Hubble Space Telescope or ground-based telescopes. The X-ray and optical observations together provide a micro-arcsecond probe of the quasar, an angular resolution far beyond the reach of current and future telescopes. Emphasis will be on the anomalies between the observed flux ratios and the predictions of lensing models, which allow us to determine the size of the optical emitting regions of the quasars. I will also discuss how we are using these same flux ratio anomalies to determine the amount of dark matter in the lensing galaxies.
fields.speaker: Dave Pooley
fields.teaser_text: Under favorable conditions, the light from a distant quasar  can be gravitationally lensed by an intervening galaxy to produce four images of the quasar.  I will discuss an innovative technique of analyzing these quadruply-lensed quasars in optical and X-ray emission that, for the first time, is able to resolve the structure of the accretion disk around the black hole.

fields.title: How Galaxies Become Red: Insights from Cosmological Hydrodynamic Simulations
fields.text: New results based on an analysis of ultra-high resolution (114 pc/h) adaptive mesh refinement cosmological hydrodynamic simulations will be presented. In this talk we focus on the physics on how galaxies migrate from the Blue Cloud to the Red Sequence, by tracing genealogically more than 3000 galaxies from z=6 to z=0.6. Environment quenching is found to play the domimant role in driving the vast majority of galaxies into the red sequence; the environment that drives galaxies red is broadly correlated with regions of high gas temperature, pressure, entropy or matter overdensity. Two physical processes are found to be most important. Initially, ram-pressure stripping, effectively, disconnects a galaxy from its circumgalactic cold gas supply, with its effectiveness depending strongly on internal properties of galaxies being stripped, causing large variations in the stripping time at a given environment. Cold gas starvation in the high-entropy, cooling-deficient environment then guards against further significant  star formation in cold-gas-stripped galaxies. At a given satellite stellar mass, the radius of the ``quenching sphere" in units of the virial radius of the quenching system increases with increasing mass of the quenching system, although the majority of quenching occurs within $2-3$ virial radii of the quenching system.
fields.speaker: Renyue Cen
fields.teaser_text: New results based on an analysis of ultra-high resolution (114 pc/h) adaptive mesh refinement cosmological hydrodynamic simulations will be presented. In this talk we focus on the physics on how galaxies migrate from the Blue Cloud to the Red Sequence, by tracing genealogically more than 3000 galaxies from z=6 to z=0.6.

fields.title: What Can You Do with Seven Thousand White Dwarfs in the Globular Cluster 47 Tucanae?
fields.text: Using HST observations of the globular cluster 47 Tucanae over the past seven years (including some amazing WFC3 and ACS images over the past year), we have built an unrivalled stellar sample including nearly 7,000 white dwarfs. I will introduce white dwarf cooling, discuss the rationale behind our observations, and argue how these amazing white dwarfs probe questions ranging from axion physics and the age of the Universe to stellar evolution and the dynamics of stellar systems.
fields.speaker: Jeremy Heyl
fields.teaser_text: Using HST observations of the globular cluster 47 Tucanae over the past seven years (including some amazing WFC3 and ACS images over the past year), we have built an unrivalled stellar sample including nearly 7,000 white dwarfs.

fields.title: The fine structure of the Cepheid metallicity gradient in the Galactic thin disk
fields.text: We present new results concerning the metallicity gradient of the Galactic thin disk using homogeneous and accurate iron and alpha-element measurements of classical Cepheids. We found evidence of a steady increase in iron abundance when approaching the innermost regions of the disk together with an increase in the spread in the outer disk. The metallicity is super-solar and approaches 0.4 dex for R_G~5.5 kpc, while it is significantly more metal-poor -0.6 dex in the outer disk (R_G~15 kpc). Moreover, alpha-elements show similar abundance gradients similar to iron. We also mention that inner disk Cepheids are systematically more metal-rich than young stars located either along the Galactic Bar or in the Nuclear Bulge ([Fe/H]~0). Thus suggesting that the above regions have had different chemical enrichment histories. Finally, we briefly discuss the transition between the inner disk and the Galactic bulge.
fields.speaker: Giuseppe Bono
fields.teaser_text: We present new results concerning the metallicity gradient of the Galactic thin disk using homogeneous and accurate iron and alpha-element measurements of classical Cepheids. We found evidence of a steady increase in iron abundance when approaching the innermost regions of the disk together with an increase in the spread in the outer disk.

fields.title: Detecting gravitational waves with pulsar timing: what to do about  the ISM!
fields.text: Collaborations on three continents are using highest precision radio pulsar timing to detect and then study gravitational waves (GW) from orbiting supermassive black holes. I will discuss the basic physics involved in detecting GWs with wavelengths around a light year and review the status of the international efforts. To achieve this goal, several time-variable interstellar medium delays must be corrected to sub-microsecond accuracy, and I will discuss the state of the art in doing so.
fields.speaker: Dan Stinebring
fields.teaser_text: Collaborations on three continents are using highest precision radio pulsar timing to detect and then study gravitational waves (GW) from orbiting supermassive black holes. I will discuss the basic physics involved in detecting GWs with wavelengths around a light year and review the status of the international efforts.

fields.title: Black holes in X-ray binaries
fields.text: In the past 40 years, X-ray astronomy has led to the discovery of stellar-mass black holes, mostly in transient X-ray binaries. While new black holes are routinely detected by X-ray satellites, optical/NIR techniques are needed to measure their masses. I will summarize the progress made in the search and characterization of stellar-mass black holes in the Milky Way with a focus on the two latest discoveries: a black hole binary seen at very high-inclination and the first black hole fed by a Be star.
fields.speaker: Jorge Casares
fields.teaser_text: I will summarize the progress made in the search and characterization of stellar-mass black holes in the Milky Way with a focus on the two latest discoveries: a black hole binary seen at very high-inclination and the first black hole fed by a Be star.

fields.title: Booms, Burps & Bangs: The Dynamic Universe
fields.text: That occasionally new sources ("Stella Nova") would pop up in the heavens was noted more than a thousand years ago. The earnest study of cosmic explosions began in earnest less than a hundred years ago.  Over time astronomers have come to appreciate the central role of supernovae in synthesizing new elements (and making life as we know possible).  The Palomar Transient Factory (PTF), an innovative 2-telescope system, was designed to explicitly to chart the transient sky with a particular focus on events which lie in the nova-supernova gap.  PTF can find an extragalactic transient every 20 minutes and a Galactic (strong) variable every 10 minutes.  The results so far: classification of 2000 supernovae, identification of an emerging class of ultra-luminous supernovae, the earliest discovery of a Ia supernovae, discovery of luminous red novae, the most comprehensive UV spectroscopy of Ia supernovae, discovery low energy budget supernovae, clarification of sub-classes of core collapse and thermo-nuclear explosions, mapping of the systematics of core collapse supernovae, identification of a trove of eclipsing binaries and the curious AM CVns.
fields.speaker: Shri Kulkarni
fields.teaser_text: That occasionally new sources ("Stella Nova") would pop up in the heavens was noted more than a thousand years ago.  The Palomar Transient Factory (PTF), an innovative 2-telescope system, was designed to explicitly to chart the transient sky with a particular focus on events which lie in the nova-supernova gap.  PTF can find an extragalactic transient every 20 minutes and a Galactic (strong) variable every 10 minutes.

fields.title: Probing the extragalactic background light with high energy sources (GRAPPA/API)
fields.text:
The light emitted by stars throughout the history of the Universe, and partly reprocessed by dust, is encoded in the intensity of the extragalactic background light (EBL). Knowledge of the EBL is important for understanding the nature of star formation and galaxy evolution. Direct measurements of the EBL are difficult due to the intense zodiacal light and the Galactic foreground emission. High-energy gamma rays may interact with photons of the EBL and generate positron-electron pairs. This introduces an attenuation feature in the spectra of distant gamma-ray sources such as blazars and gamma-ray bursts that has been used in the past to set upper limits on the opacity of the Universe and the energy density of the EBL.

Thanks to the permanently improving capabilities of the modern high energy astrophysics experiments the number of extragalactic high energy sources emitting >10GeV photons has dramatically increased, enabling a statistical treatment of the problem. I will discuss the current standing on this topic. In particular, I will report on and discuss the first detections of absorption features seen in the combined spectra of a sample of gamma-ray blazars detected by the Fermi-LAT out to a redshift of z~1.6, and in the combined spectra of blazars in the local universe (z<0.2) detected by the H.E.S.S.-experiment. The combined results point to a minimal level of EBL in a wide energy range, consistent with the observed star formation rate and with low-opacity EBL models. The prospects for a refined measurement of the EBL by this indirect method extending to higher redshifts will also be discussed.
fields.speaker: Anita Reimer
fields.teaser_text:
The light emitted by stars throughout the history of the Universe, and partly reprocessed by dust, is encoded in the intensity of the extragalactic background light.
Learn how you can use gamma-rays to probe the extra-galactic, infrared background light.

fields.title: Probing the AGN Central Engine Through Variability
fields.text: Current and future time-domain surveys will provide, for the first time, well-sampled multi-wavelength lightcurves for massive numbers of AGN and other variables. These lightcurves will provide a valuable resource for studying accretion physics and the demographics of variability-selected AGN, leading to many new discoveries. In this talk I will discuss tools that I have developed for quantifying the variability in AGN, and present new flexible models for characterizing the variability of many types of stochastically-varying objects. I will show that these tools recover the well-known scaling of AGN variability properties with black hole mass, and also present trends between AGN optical variability and black hole mass and luminosity. I will conclude with a discussion of potential future directions and applications in the era of Pan-STARRS and LSST.
fields.speaker: Brandon Kelly
fields.teaser_text: Current and future time-domain surveys will provide, for the first time, well-sampled multi-wavelength lightcurves for massive numbers of AGN and other variables. These lightcurves will provide a valuable resource for studying accretion physics and the demographics of variability-selected AGN, leading to many new discoveries.

fields.title: Problems with giant impact models for the formation of the Moon - and a radical solution
fields.affiliation: VU, Faculty of Earth and Life Sciences
fields.text:
Lunar science has reinvented itself over the past decade, thanks to a combination of new lunar missions from both traditional and new space-faring nations, improved analyses of Apollo-era lunar samples, and more detailed experimental and numerical studies of the Moon ranging from the dust and plasma at its surface to its metallic core. As a result, many classic models of lunar properties and lunar evolution have been challenged - including the virtually universally accepted model of the formation of the Moon. 

Recent analyses of the chemical composition of lunar samples show a remarkable similarity with analyses of silicate rocks from the Earth. The list of elements and isotopic systems that suggest that the Moon is essentially a piece of the silicate Earth is long and growing. This similarity is entirely inconsistent with classic versions of the giant impact model of Moon formation, which predict that over half the Moon should consist of impactor rather than terrestrial materials. In this talk I will discuss a radical alternative model for Moon formation that explains these observations (De Meijer et al. 2013, Chemical Geology) and compare it with improved versions of the giant impact model (Canup 2012; Cuk and Stewart 2012, both Science).
fields.speaker: Wim van Westrenen
fields.teaser_text: Lunar science has reinvented itself over the past decade, thanks to a combination of new lunar missions from both traditional and new space-faring nations. As a result, many classic models of lunar properties and lunar evolution have been challenged - including the virtually universally accepted model of the formation of the Moon.

fields.title: The formation and evolution of clusters of galaxies  (GRAPPA/API)
fields.text:
Galaxy clusters are unique laboratories to study some of the most fundamental questions in astrophysics, related to the formation and evolution of galaxies, the physics of particle acceleration, the generation of magnetic fields, the growth of large-scale structure, and cosmology.

We will present radio, optical and X-ray observations of diffuse radio emission from the Toothbrush and Sausage clusters that will delineate how cluster merger shocks accelerate particles to relativistic speeds and shape the evolution of cluster galaxies. The ancestors of local galaxy clusters (`proto-clusters’) are powerful laboratories for tracing the emergence of large scale structure and studying the evolution of galaxies in dense environments. It are these structures that at z < 2 virialise into massive X-ray emitting clusters. We will present radio and Herschel observations of protoclusters that characterise their properties.
fields.speaker: Huub Röttgering
fields.teaser_text: Galaxy clusters are unique laboratories to study some of the most fundamental questions in astrophysics, related to the formation and evolution of galaxies, the physics of particle acceleration, the generation of magnetic fields, the growth of large-scale structure, and cosmology.

fields.title: Babylonian Mathematical Astronomy - Number Crunching in Antiquity
fields.text: Near 400 BCE the earliest known form of mathematical astronomy was invented in Babylonia. This new technique enabled the astronomers to predict times, positions and other quantities of the Moon and the planets with mathematical algorithms. The translation and analysis of Babylonian astronomical tablets is an ongoing project carried out by Assyriologists and historians of astronomy. I begin this talk by introducing the activities and methods of Babylonian astronomy. I will then present some new findings about the astronomical algorithms and a newly discovered class of mathematical tables probably computed by astronomers. I conclude by discussing the possible purpose and applications of Babylonian astronomy.
fields.speaker: Mathieu Ossendrijver
fields.teaser_text: In this colloquium we go back to the dawn of Astronomy.

fields.title: A gas cloud on its way toward the Galactic Center black hole Sgr A*
fields.text: In 2011, we discovered a compact gas cloud (”G2”) with roughly 3 Earth masses that is falling on a near-radial orbit toward the massive black hole in the Galactic Center. The orbit is well constrained and pericenter passage is predicted for early 2014. Our data beautifully show that G2 gets tidally sheared apart due to the massive black hole's force. During the next months, we expect that in addition to the tidal effects, hydrodynamics get important, when G2 collides with the hot ambient gas around Sgr A*. Simulations show that ultimately, the cloud’s material will fall into the massive black hole. Predictions for the accretion rate and luminosity evolution, however, are very difficult due to the many unknowns. Nevertheless, this might be a unique opportunity in the next years to observe how gas feeds a massive black hole in a galactic nucleus.
fields.speaker: Stefan Gillessen
fields.teaser_text: In 2011, we discovered a compact gas cloud (”G2”) with roughly 3 Earth masses that is falling on a near-radial orbit toward the massive black hole in the Galactic Center. The orbit is well constrained and pericenter passage is predicted for early 2014.

fields.title: The X-ray view of the Central degree of the Galaxy
fields.text: X-rays offer the extraordinary opportunity to study a variety of different emission components in the Galactic centre region and their complex interplay. At the Milky Way centre sits Sgr A*, the weakest (in terms of Eddington ratio) supermassive black hole known. However, traces of "glorious" past active periods can be found in the surrounding medium. We will review the current understanding of Sgr A*'s past activity (e.g. through X-ray reflection) presenting also new X-ray mosaics (including over 100 XMM-Newton observations pointed within 1 degree of Sgr A*). We will then discuss the nature of several soft X-ray extended features in the vicinity of Sgr A*, including the 20-pc scale bipolar lobes, a super bubble candidate, the soft emission peaking around G0.11-0.11 as well as several features having considerable extents in Galactic latitude, suggesting the presence of hot plasma overlying the Central Molecular Zone.
fields.speaker: Gabriele Ponti
fields.teaser_text: X-rays offer the extraordinary opportunity to study a variety of different emission components in the Galactic centre region and their complex interplay.  At the Milky Way centre sits Sgr A*, the weakest  supermassive black hole known. However, traces of past active periods can be found in the surrounding medium.

fields.title: Ultraluminous X-ray sources: the most extreme accretors?
fields.text: Observational studies of ultraluminous X-ray sources (ULXs) have advanced greatly in the past 15 years, with a plethora of new X-ray data that have been supported by multi-wavelength studies across the EM spectrum.  Yet, despite this, we still have no definitive identification of the objects that power this energetic phenomenon.  In this talk I will discuss the observational and theoretical constraints on their nature, and in particular focus on recent work in which we examine the detailed X-ray emission characteristics of ULXs.  I will argue that these results are best interpreted in the framework of super-Eddington accretion, making ULXs the most extreme accretion rate environments in the local Universe, and a good template for the processes that rapidly built supermassive black holes at high redshift.
fields.speaker: Tim Roberts
fields.teaser_text: Observational studies of ultraluminous X-ray sources (ULXs) have advanced greatly in the past 15 years, with a plethora of new X-ray data that have been supported by multi-wavelength studies across the EM spectrum.  Yet, despite this, we still have no definitive identification of the objects that power this energetic phenomenon.

fields.title: The EAGLE Universe
fields.text:
The EAGLE (Evolution and Assembly of Galaxies and their Environments) project is a suite of hydrodynamic simulations of the Universe. The simulations take into account the full range of baryonic physics, including metal dependent gas cooling, star formation, supernovae and black hole formation. The resolution of the simulations is sufficient to resolve the onset of the Jeans instability in galactic disks, allowing us to study the formation of individual galaxies in detail. At the same time the largest calculation simulates a volume that is 100 Mpc on each side, exploring the full range of galaxy environments from the isolated dwarves to rich galaxy clusters.

A key philosophy of the simulations has been to use the simplest possible sub-grid models for star formation, black hole accretion and feedback from supernovae and AGN. Efficient feedback is achieved without hydrodynamic decoupling of particles. The small number of parameters in these models are calibrated by requiring that the simulations match key observed properties of local galaxies. Having set the parameters using the local Universe, I will show that the simulations reproduce the observed evolution of galaxy properties extremely well. The resulting universe provides us with deep insight into the formation of galaxies and black holes. In particular, we can use the simulations to understand the relationship between local galaxies and their progenitors at higher redshift and to understand the role of interactions between galaxies and the AGN that they host. I will present an overview of some of the most important results from the project.
fields.speaker: Richard Bower
fields.teaser_text: The EAGLE (Evolution and Assembly of Galaxies and their Environments) project is a suite of hydrodynamic simulations of the Universe. The simulations take into account the full range of baryonic physics, including metal dependent gas cooling, star formation, supernovae and black hole formation.

fields.title: A paradigm shift in understanding Gamma-ray bursts
fields.text: Since the launch of Fermi in 2008, a prime focus had been given to understanding the physical origin of the prompt emission from gamma-ray bursts (GRBs), which holds the key to understanding of their nature. While the problem is still far from being solved, in recent years we are witnessing a "paradigm shift", as the existence of thermal component (on top the non-thermal emission) becomes evident. I will describe the latest result and the recent theoretical breakthroughs in understanding how the naively expected "Planck" spectrum can be broadened and resemble the observed spectra. I will discuss some novel effects and theoretical ideas relevant for the study of many astronomical objects.
fields.speaker: Asaf Pe'er
fields.teaser_text: Since the launch of Fermi in 2008, a prime focus had been given to understanding the physical origin of the prompt emission from gamma-ray bursts (GRBs), which holds the key to understanding of their nature.

fields.title: Language and Non-Verbal Cognition in Bilinguals (Christmas Colloquium)
fields.text: Quite a few studies suggest that bilinguals use their two languages differently from the way monolinguals use language. This shows from “accents” in all domains of language, for instance, in phonology, grammar and semantics, and in both of the bilinguals’ two languages. In addition, there is evidence to suggest that particular aspects of non-verbal cognition differ between monolinguals and bilinguals. In my talk I will review a number of studies that support these claims and present possible causes of the observed differences.
fields.speaker: Annette de Groot
fields.teaser_text: Quite a few studies suggest that bilinguals use their two languages differently from the way monolinguals use language.

fields.title: Nature or Nurture :  neutron stars in Be/X-ray binaries in the Small Magellanic Cloud
fields.text:
Over the last 20 years it has become very clear that there exists a substantial population of High Mass X-ray Binaries in the SMC. This population could be greater in number than in the entire Milky Way population, even though the SMC is only ~1% of the mass of the MW. The origin of this population lies in the tidal interactions between the two Magellanic Clouds, which gave rise to a large population of massive stars, many evolving into HMXB systems.

Because this population is an extremely “clean" sample – all at the same distance and with a low interstellar extinction – it means we have an extremely valuable laboratory for exploring many aspects of astrophysics. Specifically we can study accretion physics, SN kicks, spin period distribution, XRB population studies and determine the magnetic field of many neutron stars. In this talk I will concentrate on the global properties of this amazing group of objects so conveniently located for multi-wavelength studies.
fields.speaker: Malcolm Coe
fields.teaser_text: Over the last 20 years it has become very clear that there exists a substantial population of High Mass X-ray Binaries in the SMC. This population could be greater in number than in the entire Milky Way population, even though the SMC is only ~1% of the mass of the MW.

fields.title: The Instability of Astrophysics Witnessed in the Twentieth Century (API/GRAPPA)
fields.text: Progress in astrophysics entails instabilities, some of which are beneficial in leading to unanticipated advances. Often these come about through the import of new tools developed in other sciences or for industry or the military.  Other instabilities, however, can be harmful and lead to setbacks.  The history of 20th century astronomy is replete with examples of both types, some of which I will recount.  One source of instability is astronomy’s inability, sometimes for decades at a time, to systematically pursue discoveries of rare events.  Such delays inject levels of uncertainty in our observational discipline that the experimental sciences seldom encounter.   Partial remedies for this difficulty may already be available.  Other instabilities arise as the complexity of the various disciplines constituting our field increases, the tools and vocabularies used by the disciplines begin to diverge, and misunderstandings arise to threaten a coherent, unified view of the Universe.   As historical examples show misinformation then cascades throughout astrophysics, with consequences akin to those of major failures of electrical power grids or financial meltdowns.  I will outline ways to retain beneficial instabilities while more readily thwarting damaging intrusions.
fields.speaker: Martin Harwit
fields.teaser_text: Progress in astrophysics entails instabilities, some of which are beneficial in leading to unanticipated advances. Often these come about through the import of new tools developed in other sciences or for industry or the military.  Other instabilities, however, can be harmful and lead to setbacks.

fields.title: Swings between accretion and rotation power in binary millisecond pulsars
fields.text: Neutron stars in low mass X-ray binaries can be spun-up to millisecond rotational periods by accreting matter transferred by the companion star. When the rate of mass transfer decreases at the end of this Gyr-long X-ray bright phase, a radio pulsar powered by the rotation of the neutron star magnetic field turns on. Recently, the evolutionary link between these two classes of sources was finally proven by the discovery of the first millisecond pulsar observed to swing between accretion (X-ray bright) and rotation-powered (radio bright) pulsar behaviour. This source is the prototype of a new class of transitional systems that perform rapid state transitions in response to variations of the rate of mass in-flow. Observations of this and similar systems indicate that transitions to the accretion phase not only involve bright X-ray outbursts, but also a fainter intermediate accretion state, possibly caused by centrifugal inhibition of the matter in-fall.  Prospects of finding more sources of this newly established class will be also discussed.
fields.speaker: Alessandro Papitto
fields.teaser_text: Neutron stars in low mass X-ray binaries can be spun-up to millisecond rotational periods by accreting matter transferred by the companion star. When the rate of mass transfer decreases at the end of this Gyr-long X-ray bright phase, a radio pulsar powered by the rotation of the neutron star magnetic field turns on.

fields.title: Communicating the Heisenberg relations: Niels Bohr and the forgotten Einstein-Rupp Experiments
fields.text: In 1926, Albert Einstein collaborated with Emil Rupp on a set of experiments that were to probe the wave versus particle nature of light. The experiments have now been forgotten, even though their history is quite surprising: after it was established that Rupp had committed fraud, they have been eradicated from the collective memory of the physics community. Niels Bohr is one of the physicists who was closely following the development of these experiments, and proposed his own interpretation of them to Einstein using Heisenberg's new relations; yet, he would not mention them in his later recollections of discussions with Einstein. In this talk, I will discuss the Einstein-Rupp experiments, their role in the discussions between Bohr and Einstein, and finally offer an analysis of the collective amnesia.
fields.speaker: Jeroen van Dongen
fields.teaser_text: In 1926, Albert Einstein collaborated with Emil Rupp on a set of experiments that were to probe the wave versus particle nature of light. The experiments have now been forgotten, even though their history is quite surprising.

fields.title: Unlocking Secrets of Pulsars with the Fermi Gamma-Ray Telescope (NOVA colloquium)
fields.text: Of the several thousand rotation-powered pulsars that have been discovered by radio telescopes over the past forty years, only a handful were known to emit gamma-ray pulsations before the launch in June, 2008 of the Fermi Gamma-Ray Space Telescope. After almost six years of operation, over 140 gamma-ray pulsars have been detected and several new populations have been discovered. Millisecond pulsars have been confirmed as powerful sources of gamma-ray emission, and a whole population of these objects is seen with Fermi both in the Galactic plane and in globular clusters. Fermi has thus revolutionized the study of pulsars and allowed us to peer deeper into the inner workings of this incredibly efficient natural accelerator. These discoveries, together with recent progress in global simulation of pulsar magnetospheres, are changing our models of pulsar particle acceleration, cascade pair production and high-energy emission.
fields.speaker: Alice Harding
fields.teaser_text: Of the several thousand rotation-powered pulsars that have been discovered by radio telescopes over the past forty years, only a handful were known to emit gamma-ray pulsations before the launch in June, 2008 of the Fermi Gamma-Ray Space Telescope.

fields.title: The Dark Energy Survey and Beyond (API/GRAPPA)
fields.text: After reviewing the status of the cosmological model post Planck and other surveys, the talk will focus on the international Dark Energy Survey (DES). DES observations are already underway, aiming to map 200 million galaxies which will be used via multiple methods (galaxy clustering, clusters, weak lensing) and thousands of supernovae type Ia. These will be used to quantify the enigmatic Dark Energy and alternative models. Early DES science results will be presented.  Other science goals (e.g. neutrino mass) and future surveys (e.g. DESI, Euclid, LSST) will also be discussed.
fields.speaker: Ofer Lahav
fields.teaser_text: This talk will focus on the international Dark Energy Survey (DES).

fields.title: The Sunyaev-Zel'dovich effect: from fundamental astro-physics to cosmology
fields.speaker: Sergio Colafrancesco

fields.title: The Bardeen-Petterson Effect in MHD, or, How Twisted Disks Straighten Out
fields.text: Accretion disks occur in a wide variety of astrophysical contexts, from planet formation to accretion onto black holes. For simplicity, they are generally imagined as thin and flat. However, whenever the disk's angular momentum is oblique to the angular momentum of the central object(s), a torque causes rings within the disk to precess, twisting and warping it. Because the torque weakens rapidly with increasing radius, it has long been thought that some unspecified "friction" will end up bringing the inner portions of such disks into alignment, while the outer parts remain in their original orientation. Nearly all previous work on this topic has assumed that such a disk's internal stresses can be described by an isotropic viscosity, even though it has been known for more than four decades that fluid viscosity is far too weak to be significant, and for two decades that accretion stresses are actually due to anisotropic MHD turbulence. In this talk I'll report on the first work showing how twisted disks align when their mechanics are described only in terms of real forces, including MHD turbulence. The results have interesting implications for the evolution of misaligned disks in systems spanning the range from binary protostars to merging supermassive black holes.
fields.speaker: Julian Krolik
fields.teaser_text: Accretion disks occur in a wide variety of astrophysical contexts, from planet formation to accretion onto black holes.  For simplicity, they are generally imagined as thin and flat.  However, whenever the disk's angular momentum is oblique to the angular momentum of the central object(s), a torque causes rings within the disk to precess, twisting and warping it.

fields.title: Unravelling the Explosion Mechanism of Massive Stars --- Supernova Models Confronting Observations (GRAPPA/API)
fields.text: When a massive star reaches the end of its life, the core of the star collapses to a neutron star or black hole while the outer stellar layers are expelled in a supernova explosion. These cosmic catastrophies are not only among the most spectacular celestial phenomena, they are also responsible for the production and dissemination of a major part of the heavy elements in the universe. A better understanding of the role of supernovae in astrophysics and as laboratories for nuclear and particle physics at extreme conditions requires the solution of one of the most long-standing problems of stellar physics: What is the mechanism that initiates and powers the explosion of stars? Increasingly sophisticated numerical models provide growing support that the energy deposition by neutrinos radiated from the hot, newly formed neutron star and aided by violent hydrodynamic mass motions is the driving agency of the explosion. In this talk I will review recent successes of theoretical modeling and new questions arising as simulations currently push forward to meet the grand computational challenges of the third spatial dimension. I will also discuss possibilities to confront the theoretical picture with observational tests and constraints.
fields.speaker: Thomas Janka
fields.teaser_text: Learn about state of the art computer simulations of core collapse supernovae.

fields.title: From Clouds to Planets: Stories from Herschel
fields.text: Infrared spectroscopy of newly forming star and planetary systems in molecular clouds in our neighbourhood provides a window into the formation of our solar system.
