Protostars represent a key phase in that star formation history -- after the collapse of a single core within a molecular cloud, tracing the assembly of the key materials (gas, ice, and dust) available for planet formation as the system contracts and irradiates its contents, prior to the complete unveiling of the system with the dispersal of the remaining envelope, perhaps in violent outburst. The Herschel Space Observatory used its infrared eyes to view systems still cloaked in their envelopes and surrounding cloud, probing key diagnostics - in particular, rotational and rovibrational emission lines of CO, OH, and water vapor, forbidden atomic/ionic emission lines, as well as dust emission. Our Herschel programs probe a diverse sample of nearby protostars, to answer the key question: what mechanism controls the material available at the time of planet formation?  In particular, we highlight results from rare episodic eruptors with dramatically raised accretion rates, known as "FU Orionis objects", demonstrating that the formation of a star and planetary system is not a smooth process but a slow trickle punctuated by violent floods of activity.

fields.title: Molecular hydrogen in Crab Nebula filaments (NOVA colloquium)
fields.text: Some filaments in the Crab Nebula contain large amount of dust while others have very strong emission from molecular hydrogen. The optical / NIR spectrum is very similar to those of filaments found in cool-core galaxy clusters. Both environments have an anomalous optical spectrum with strong low ionization lines never seen in photoionized clouds. The NIR spectrum has molecular hydrogen lines that are far stronger than H I recombination lines and indicating excitation temperatures around 3000 K. In both environments the warm molecular gas is surrounded by a bath of extremely hot T> 107 K, gas in rough pressure equilibrium. I will discuss what these spectra reveal about conditions in the filaments and the origin of the emission.

fields.teaser_text: Some filaments in the Crab Nebula contain large amount of dust while others have very strong emission from molecular hydrogen. fields.title: But wait!  There's more!: A Wealth of Science from Millisecond Pulsars (NOVA colloquium)
fields.text: Pulsars are some of astrophysics' most exotic objects. We currently know of about 2300 pulsars in our Galaxy, but a small subset of them, the millisecond pulsars (MSPs), are truly remarkable. These systems are notoriously hard to detect, yet their numbers have more than doubled in the past 4 years via surveys using the world's most sensitive telescopes. Specialized "timing" observations of these new systems as well as much improved monitoring of previously known MSPs are providing fantastic results. Some examples include unusual aspects of binary and stellar astrophysics, the nature of matter at supra-nuclear densities, and the direct detection of gravitational waves, possibly within the next 5 years.

fields.title: New Frontiers in Exoplanetary Science
fields.text:
The field of exoplanetology has recently transitioned from the investigation of individual objects to statistical studies. However, answers to key questions in exoplanetary science come not only from the statistics of discovery surveys, but also from the detailed characterisation of individual systems. I argue that the study of exoplanet atmospheres and their diversity is the next step in leveraging their detections. This is because a planet's atmosphere provides a fossil record of its primordial origins and controls its fate, size and appearance. The study of exoplanet atmospheres thus is crucial to answer fundamental questions in planetary formation and exoplanetary physics.

In this context, I present new results from ongoing comparative exoplanetology programs that aim to characterise planetary systems transiting nearby stars through the observations of their atmospheres. This is achieved by combining ground- and space-based multi-wavelength observations secured over wide spectral regions. The results on the atmospheric composition and physical properties provide insights into the formation and evolution of planetary systems and enhance our understanding of our own Solar System's formation. Finally, I also present strategies for probing rocky exoplanet atmospheres orbiting in the habitable zone of their parent stars, and for searching for bio-signatures with future facilities.
fields.speaker: Jean-Michel Désert
fields.teaser_text: The field  of exoplanetology has recently transitioned from the investigation of  individual objects to statistical studies. However, answers to key  questions in exoplanetary science come not only from the statistics of  discovery surveys, but also from the detailed characterisation of  individual systems.

fields.title: Towards the characterization of Earth analogues
fields.text:
Exoplanet characterization is a rapidly evolving field and each new discovery serves to highlight the stunning diversity of planetary systems. Many exoplanets have no analogue within our solar system, ranging from the massive super Earths to the extremely hot Jupiters. Unraveling the underlying cause of this diversity is key to understanding how our solar system and planet Earth came to be, and if such systems are common. Moreover, by characterizing these extreme systems today, we are making crucial advancements in the observational and analytical techniques that will need to directly characterize Earth-like planets in the future.

In this talk, I will present some of the most exciting and recent developments in exoplanet characterization, including the discovery of water and carbon monoxide in hot Jupiters, and the measurement of exoplanet rotation periods. These discoveries are connected by the use of ground-based high-resolution spectroscopy, and I will advocate that this novel technique is a front-runner in the hunt for biomarkers in Earth-like planets with the Extremely Large Telescopes. I will also discuss the challenges we face in exoplanet characterization, particularly with respect to the presence of clouds and the influence of the host star. Finally, I will show how measurements of an exoplanet’s atmospheric composition and rotation period have the potential to reveal how and where the planet formed in its protoplanetary disk.
fields.speaker: Jayne Birkby
fields.teaser_text: Exoplanet characterization is a  rapidly evolving field and each new discovery serves to highlight the  stunning diversity of planetary systems. Many exoplanets have no  analogue within our solar system, ranging from the massive super Earths  to the extremely hot Jupiters.

fields.title: From forming gas giants to exo-Earths: Opportunities in high-contrast exoplanet imaging
fields.text:
Spatially resolving and directly detecting photons from an exoplanet allows us to derive physical and chemical properties of the planet and its atmosphere. For gas giant planets, this information can help constrain their formation process and evolution, which are at least in part poorly understood. For low-mass planets, one can directly search for biological signatures their atmospheric spectra, which is the ultimate goal for exoplanet science.

In this talk I will present the current state of high-contrast imaging of exoplanets, describe the challenges this technique is confronted with and show how some of them can be overcome. I will conclude with outlining exciting opportunities that are coming up with the current installation of dedicated high-contrast exoplanet imaging instruments and show that within the next 15 years it is likely that the first image of an exo-Earth will be taken.
fields.speaker: Sascha Quanz
fields.teaser_text: Spatially  resolving and directly detecting photons from an exoplanet allows us to  derive physical and chemical properties of the planet and its  atmosphere. For gas giant planets, this information can help constrain  their formation process and evolution.

fields.title: Exploring and exploiting the diversity of exoplanetary systems
fields.text:
From the first discoveries and over nearly 20 years of search, we have uncovered that exoplanets present a wide variety in every parameter we can measure. This notably implies that our Solar system did not participate in the dominant planet formation and evolution mechanism in the Galaxy. Understanding this diversity remains one of the main drivers behind the search for other worlds. Exploiting some key observable properties of what at principle appeared like exotic systems, can enhance our exploration of how varied planets are. Certain exoplanet properties can also significantly improve ours odds of finding planets suitable for atmospheric characterisation.

I will present results using the Rossiter-McLaughlin effect, showing that many gas giants do not occupy orbits coplanar with their star. Building on that knowledge I will explore how inclined planets behave when orbiting close binary stars and reveal that many of them could be found transiting within the Kepler data with interesting consequences on the rates of occurrence and on our capacity to study their atmospheres.

Then, I will describe how expanding planet discoveries to very low mass stars and brown dwarfs is essential if we want to obtain the capacity to study habitable environments within the next decade.

fields.title: Observing the Build-up of Galaxies in the Early Universe with Hubble and Spitzer
fields.text: Over the last few years, enormous progress has been made in the study of galaxies in the first two billion years thanks to the incredible capabilities of the Hubble and Spitzer Space Telescopes. Already, more than 800 probable galaxies are known at redshifts above z~6, and now the current frontier is at z~10, with 7 plausible galaxy identifications to date. Deriving physical properties for these distant galaxies is also an important frontier, and progress has been impressive even as early as z~7-8. Amazingly, current data sets are allowing us to construct a detailed picture of how galaxies both form and evolve, as they change in color, mass, size, and luminosity. In this colloquium, I capture some of the highlights and describe the prospects for further advances.

fields.title: Shock Waves in Galaxy Clusters
fields.text: The intracluster medium is an extreme plasma that cannot be studied in terrestrial laboratories. Its thermal state is largely set by shocks that occur during virialisation and cluster mergers. Shocks are also a site for particle acceleration. Observations in the X-ray and radio band are beginning to tell us more about the physics of these shocks - however, the results from recent observations have raised a number of fundamental questions. I will present recent observations that challenge our current understanding of shocks in clusters. New ways of studying them, especially in the context of LOFAR, are discussed.
fields.speaker: Marcus Brüggen

fields.title: Coevolution (or not) of supermassive black holes and host galaxies (NOVA colloquium)
fields.text: Supermassive black holes (SMBH) have been found in 85 galaxies by dynamical modeling of spatially resolved kinematics. The Hubble Space Telescope revolutionized SMBH research by advancing the subject from its proof-of-concept phase into quantitative studies of SMBH demographics. Most influential was the discovery of a tight correlation between black hole mass and the velocity dispersion of the bulge component of the host galaxy. Together with similar correlations with bulge luminosity and mass, this led to the widespread belief that SMBHs and bulges coevolve by regulating each other’s growth. Conclusions based on one set of correlations dominated work on SMBH for more than a decade. New results are now replacing this simple story with a richer and more plausible picture in which SMBHs correlate differently with different galaxy components. We use this progress to refine our understanding of SMBH-galaxy coevolution and the different regimes of black hole feedback which may or may not affect it.

fields.title: The Crab pulsar and its nebula: Surprises in gamma-rays (API/GRAPPA)
fields.text: The Crab nebula and its pulsar (referred to together as “Crab”) have historically played a central role in astrophysics. True to their legacy, several unique discoveries have been made recently. The Crab was found to emit gamma-ray pulsations up to energies of 400 GeV, beyond what was previously expected from pulsars. Strong gamma-ray flares, of durations of a few days were discovered from within the nebula, while the source was previously expected to be stable in flux on these time scales. In this presentation I will review these intriguing and suggestive developments. I will give an overview of the observational properties of the Crab and our current theoretical understanding of this system.

fields.title: Scaling laws for dark matter halos of late-type and dwarf spheroidal galaxies (GRAPPA/API)
fields.text: Published mass models fitted to kinematic data are used to study the systematic properties of dark matter (DM) halos in late type dwarf spheroidal (dSph) galaxies. Combining these data, we find that DM halos satisfy scaling laws analogous to the fundamental plane relations for elliptical galaxies. Halos in less luminous galaxies have smaller core radii, higher central densities, and smaller central velocity dispersions. The scaling laws provide new constraints on the nature of DM and on galaxy evolution. For example, the high DM densities in the dSph companions of our Galaxy imply that they are real galaxies formed from primordial density fluctuations, not tidal fragments. We further conclude that the DM particle velocity dispersion is larger than the velocity dispersions of the stars in dSph galaxies and therefore that these almost-dark dwarfs are more massive than we thought. This helps to solve two of the major problems with our picture of galaxy formation by hierarchical clustering of cold dark matter. The slopes of the DM parameter correlations also provide a measure on galactic mass scales of the slope of the power spectrum of primordial density fluctuations which is consistent with the theory of cold DM.

fields.title: Kinematic Properties of High Redshift Absorption Systems in AMR Simulations of Galaxy Formation
fields.text: Damped Lyman-alpha absorber systems (DLAs) are thought to be one of the best probes of structure formation in the early universe. DLAs are defined as systems with neutral hydrogen column densities N(HI) > 2E+20 cm-2. They are the dominant neutral-gas reservoir for star formation at high redshifts, and thus could help us uncover the mystery of the progenitors of present-day galaxies. For many years, there has been a debate on the nature of galaxies causing damped Ly-alpha absorption at high redshifts. One idea is that DLAs are small proto-galactic clumps formed in the process of hierarchical structure formation. Another idea is that DLAs can be best explained with rapidly rotating, large, cold disks of galaxies. To test these ideas, we used high-resolution AMR (adaptive mesh refinement) hydrodynamics simulations to study kinematic properties and column density distributions of DLAs at redshift z = 3. Our simulations are based on standard cold dark matter cosmology (LCDM), and include ionizing UV radiative transfer and star formation/feedback which we believe are the necessary ingredients to solve the low velocity-width problem commonly seen in previous numerical simulations. In this talk, I will also introduce another type of cosmological simulations SPH (smooth particle hydrodynamics) and briefly discuss the differences between AMR and SPH.

fields.title: Dissecting Supernova Remnants: The Morphology of 3C58
fields.text:
NOTE: this talk (and the pizzas) will be 30 minutes later than usual

Abstract:
Supernova remnants (SNRs) are one of the final stages of stellar
evolution. They present a diverse class of objects in terms of age,
morphology and metal abundances, and are thought to be an important
site of particle acceleration in the universe. Their properties give
important insights into the progenitor evolution and explosion
mechanism that produced them.
A detailed analysis of the morphology in various wavebands has been
hindered by the lack of rigorous statistical techniques with which to
analyze them. With a combination of adapted and newly developed
mathematical methods it is now finally possible to capitalize on the
rich data set that current space and ground-based missions provide us
with, and draw conclusions about emission mechanisms and environmental
constraints that affect the morphology. In this talk, I will present
the techniques used as well as results from the analysis of supernova
remnants and pulsar-wind nebulae.

fields.title: The X-ray AGN Fraction and XRB-AGN Accretion Connections from Chandra and SDSS
fields.text: I will summarize two projects: (1) the field fraction of X-ray AGN (F_AGN) out to redshifts of z ~ 0.7, and (2) empirical connections between accretion in X-ray binaries and AGN. For the first, we employ a sample of >100,000 SDSS galaxies and ~1,600 Chandra X-ray detections, as well as detailed Chandra volume completeness maps, to investigate F_AGN as a function of host galaxy properties, including absolute magnitude, X-ray luminosity, redshift, and color/morphological type, for samples complete in redshift and i-band magnitude (Mi). Conservatively defining AGN via log Lx(0.5-8keV) > 42, and weighting by the optical galaxy luminosity function, we find that about 1 in 150 galaxies with -18 > Mi > -26 host an active nucleus. In the second study, we explore the recently-reported inflection in the relation between the X-ray photon index and the Eddington Ratio for ~600 nearby AGN with Chandra detections and SDSS spectroscopy. Strikingly similar trends for X-ray binaries suggest analogous accretion physics across 6-7 orders of magnitude in black hole mass, and provide a novel tool for investigating accretion in the ambiguous low luminosity AGN.

fields.title: Reconnection of Turbulent Magnetic Field and Particle Acceleration
fields.text: A new mechanism of magnetic reconnection that we proposed and successfully tested is able to convert a substantial part of energy stored in magnetic field into energetic particles. We discuss how the mechanism induces fast reconnection in the presence of weak turbulence, which is omnipresent in astrophysical environments. As reconnected magnetic field lines contract, this induces first order Fermi acceleration of particles. Numerical simulations confirm the efficiency of the acceleration process and demonstrate that the processes of acceleration (similar to the processes of reconnection) should be described in 3D. The proposed acceleration mechanism was applied to explain anomalous cosmic rays measured by Voyagers as well as the anisotropy of cosmic rays measured by the MILAGRO and ICECUBE collaborations. The relative role of the new reconnection acceleration and the traditional shock acceleration mechanisms is an interesting issue that still should be addressed.

fields.title: The stirring pulsar B0826-34
fields.text: I present results from high-quality simultaneous dual-frequency full-polarisation observations of the highly peculiar pulsar, B0826-34 made with 64-m Parkes radio telescope at 685 and 3094 MHz. This pulsar shows the phenomenon of drifting across its extremely average pulse profile. I confirm that at high frequencies the pulsar emits a weak emission during what was previously thought to be nulling. The resulting profile resembles the pulse shape observed at low frequencies. Using single-pulse data we study the pulsar’s subpulse drift pattern. Using the simultaneous full-polarisation observations we study the polarisation properties of PSR B0826-34. We find that the polarisation characteristics are quite complicated. The source exhibits unusual evolution of the position angle profiles at both frequencies and such differences go beyond of interpretation of purely geometrical origin.

fields.title: The Widefield ORT: A Large Scale Survey Instrument for Cosmological Investigations
fields.text:
The Ooty Radio Telescope (ORT) is undergoing a major upgrade involving digitization of every two-metre section of the half-kilometer feed array, and transport of this data over a fibre network to a programmable digital receiver. The upgrade is expected to increase the instantaneous Field of View by more than an order of magnitude. A 4X bandwidth, with an FX spectral correlator will result in enhanced sensitivity and spectral /temporal resolution.

The talk will provide an outline of the upgrade, focusing on the digital receiver, which is a hybrid of a hardware based high-speed routing and pre-processing system, and a software based full correlation receiver. In addition, the unique capabilities introduced by the on-going upgrade for large scale surveys in three different regions will be presented: (a) Solar wind studies for space weather watch, (b) Transient sources, and (c) HI mass fluctuations at redshifts close to 3, to look for signatures of Baryonic Acoustic Oscillations.

fields.title: Gamma ray astronomy and the origin of galactic cosmic rays
fields.text: Diffusive shock acceleration operating at expanding supernova remnant shells is by far the most popular model for the origin of galactic cosmic rays. Despite the general consensus received by the model, an unambiguous and conclusive proof of the supernova remnant hypothesis is still missing. In this context, the recent developments in gamma ray astronomy provide us with precious insights into the problem of the origin of galactic cosmic rays, since production of gamma rays is expected both during the acceleration of cosmic rays at supernova remnant shocks and during their subsequent propagation in the interstellar medium. In particular, the recent detection of a number of supernova remnants at TeV energies nicely fits with the model, but it still does not constitute a conclusive proof of it, mainly due to the difficulty of disentangling the hadronic and leptonic contributions to the observed gamma ray emission. The main goal of my research is to search for an unambiguous and conclusive observational test for proving (or disproving) the idea that supernova remnants are the sources of galactic cosmic rays with energies up to (at least) the cosmic-ray-knee (~ 4 x 10^15 eV). Our present comprehension of the mechanisms of particle acceleration at shocks and of the propagation of cosmic rays in turbulent magnetic fields encourages beliefs that such a conclusive test might come from future observations of supernova remnants  and of the Galaxy in the almost unexplored domain of multi-TeV gamma rays.

fields.title: Next generation of astronomical data
fields.text:
The size and complexity of astronomical data are growing at relentless rates. This increase is especially apparent in the radio community as evidenced by the data challenges faced by many of the SKA pathfinders and other major radio telescopes such as LOFAR, EVLA, ALMA, ASKAP, MeerKAT, MWA, LWA and eMERLIN. Enormous data rates are also becoming a challenge for large optical projects that are currently ramping up including Pan-Stars and LSST. As progress towards meeting these challenges, ASTRON and the LOFAR project are currently exploring the use of the Hierarchical Data Format, version 5 (HDF5) for LOFAR radio data encapsulation.
This activity is being paralleled by the effort to develop and formalize specifications for the individual standard data products, as expected to be generated by the various processing pipelines.

fields.title: Asymptotic Giant Branch stars and their circumstellar envelopes
fields.text:
The Asymptotic Giant Branch (AGB) is a region of the HR diagram populated by stars with low and intermediate mass (0.8 to 8.0 solar masses on the main sequence), at the end of their lives. They are luminous and "cold" objects and inject some of the nuclear burning ashes in the interstellar medium through strong winds (10-8 to 10-4 solar masses per year). They are considered to be the main source of dust to the interstellar medium and very important to galactic enrichment. In their circumstellar envelopes, a rich and complicate chemistry takes place and several different molecules can be detected through infrared and radio observations.

On this pizza lunch talk, I will go through the unsolved problems in this field that I want to address in my thesis and explain what I am working with at the moment.

fields.title: Final Open Time call for proposals (OT2) for the  Herschel Space Observatory
fields.text:
The second and final Open Time call for proposals (OT2) for the
Herschel Space Observatory will close on 15 September 2011.  
 
Accepted proposals will be scheduled from November 2011 until the end of
Herschel's life, nominally February 2013.  
 
I'll review the observatory's status, capabilities, and procedures.
 
Although this is the last AO, public data are increasingly
available through the Herschel Science Archive.
Whether you want to propose or download public data, registering as
a user at the Herschel Science Center is the first step.
 
As your national liaison to the Instrument Control Centers, I'm an

fields.title: How to Apply for Stuff
fields.text: This is the fourth semi-annual version of this seminar, aimed at masters and PhDs who are thinking about applying for the next step (PhD/postdoc). Although this is somewhat aimed at astronomers, most of it is pretty generic to anyone in the field of physics. In an informal, humorous manner, I will cover the various steps of the application process, and how to strategize for the best results. Even if you are not yet on the market this year, it can be good for thinking ahead, because particularly the strategy component should begin well before application season. This seminar will take longer than a "normal" lunch talk.
fields.speaker: Sera Markoff
fields.teaser_text: A special lunch talk + discussion aimed at de-mystifying the entire application process, for PhD and postdoc positions and fellowships.

fields.title: Two strange compact binaries: OJ287 & PSR J1903+0327
fields.text: Dynamics of compact binaries containing black holes or neutron stars can be described by corrections to Newtonian dynamics that arise from general relativity. We will explore applications of  post-Newtonian dynamics to describe electromagnetic observations of a special Blazar called OJ287 and a unique millisecond binary pulsar  PSR J1903+0327.
fields.speaker: Achamveedu Gopakumar
fields.teaser_text: We will explore applications of post-Newtonian dynamics to describe electromagnetic observations of a special Blazar called OJ287 and a unique millisecond binary pulsar  PSR J1903+0327.

fields.title: What four years of pizzas at API does to you (and something jet-related)
fields.text:
In the first part of this talk I focus on the evolution of the jet in broadband spectra of X-ray binaries. Various methods can be employed to attempt to isolate the jet component. The characteristic break between self-absorbed and optically thin synchrotron emission is identified in the jet spectrum of a few sources, which constrains both the total power of the jet and its contribution to the X-ray regime.
In the second part of the talk I review the consequences of weekly pizza consumption over a timespan of 4 years at the Anton Pannekoek Astronomical Institute. It is found that pizza digestion while watching lunchtime talks is not only beneficial, but actually essential to increase scientific productivity.
fields.speaker: Dave Russell
fields.teaser_text: In the first part of this talk I focus on the evolution of the jet in broadband spectra of X-ray binaries.  In the second part of the talk I review the consequences of weekly pizza consumption over a timespan of 4 years at the Anton Pannekoek Astronomical Institute.

fields.title: Save the Planet, eat an Apple!
fields.speaker: Samia Drappeau
fields.teaser_text: I will present how one can use Apple iGizmo in everyday research.

fields.title: A disk is a disk is a disk
fields.text:
The fundamental plane of black hole activity is a correlation between
observed luminosity and black hole mass, and indicates that disk
accretion is a scale free process that holds over several orders of
magnitude in black hole mass. I will show that accretion disks around
young stellar objects can also be described by scale-free physics, and
that this results in an observational correlation between the central
stars mass and its mid-infrared emission that holds over almost the
entire pre-main-sequence down to the brown dwarf regime.
fields.speaker: Gijs Mulders
fields.teaser_text:
