fields.speaker: Thijs Coenen

fields.title: Indicators of the Earliest Stages of Planet Formation
fields.text: How does a planet begin? Our current understanding of planet forming regions suggests that our universe is full of planets. However the evolution towards mature planetary systems involves many open questions, how do planets form out of disks, what kinds of planets, and where can we expect to see them? In this pizza talk I focus on the earliest stages of planet formation: I will demonstrate how we can recognize a planet inside a disk, and as a bonus I will show the potential of the dust crystal 'forsterite' as an indicator of the earliest stages of planet-formation.
fields.speaker: Koen Maaskant
fields.teaser_text: How does a planet begin? Our current understanding of planet forming regions suggests that our universe is full of planets. However the evolution towards mature planetary systems involves many open questions.

fields.title: The mass loss of low-metallicity massive stars
fields.text: The evolution and final fate of massive stars is greatly influenced by the amount of mass they lose during their lifetime through their intense stellar winds. As these winds are driven by radiation pressure on metallic ion lines, the theoretical prediction is that these winds get less strong with decreasing metallicity. This effect has been empirically verified in the VLT-FLAMES Survey of Massive Stars, for massive stars in the Galaxy and Magellanic clouds. In this talk I will present the first results at sub-SMC metallicities, based on X-Shooter observations of massive stars in the Local Group dwarf galaxies IC 1613, WLM and NGC 3109. Some of the stars in our sample show surprisingly strong winds, which do not agree with the theoretical predictions.
fields.speaker: Frank Tramper
fields.teaser_text: The evolution and final fate of massive stars is greatly influenced by the amount of mass they lose during their lifetime through their intense stellar winds. As these winds are driven by radiation pressure on metallic ion lines...

fields.title: Typography: a very graphic tale of colour, shape, math, and language
fields.text: Since astronomers are also expected to be graphic designers when it comes to creating a poster, I will give an overview of the mostly overlooked world of typography. This talk will show how colour, shape, and location can influence the precedence of elements on printed material, give some common examples of incorrect use of symbols in mathematics, explain the meaning of commonly misused characters, and hopefully convince you of why it all matters. Using favourites like "Which line is it anyway?" and "Left, circle, up, square: super status!" audience participation will be mandatory.
fields.speaker: Peter Polko
fields.teaser_text: Since astronomers are also expected to be graphic designers when it comes to creating a poster, I will give an overview of the mostly overlooked world of typography.

fields.title: Doing the Pulsar Limbo with LOFAR: How Low Can You Go (in Frequency)?
fields.text: I'll explain why LOFAR is unlike any previous or planned radio telescope and how this is giving us a unique view of radio pulsars.
fields.speaker: Jason Hessels
fields.teaser_text: I'll explain why LOFAR is unlike any previous or planned radio telescope and how this is giving us a unique view of radio pulsars.

fields.title: Goodbye life as we know it -- a lighthearted discussion about the 2012 apocalypse
fields.text: In my final API pizza talk it feels appropriate to discuss the 2012 apocalypse, which is hypothesized to end life as we know it. I will introduce the problem, give some observational analysis, possibly toss in some theoretical interpretation and wrap up with conclusions and an outlook.
fields.speaker: Nathalie Degenaar
fields.teaser_text: In my final API pizza talk it feels appropriate to discuss the 2012 apocalypse, which is hypothesized to end life as we know it.

fields.title: The Geodesic Deviation Method and Extreme Mass-ratio Systems
fields.text: The method of geodesic deviations provides analytic approximations to geodesics and forced motion in arbitrary background spacetimes and does so to a high degree of accuracy regardless of the strength of the gravitational field. As such, it is a useful tool in many practical situations, especially in the description of processes in close proximity of a compact object. In my talk I will explain the method and discuss the subtleties in the application of the method to the description of the EMRI-system; I will then use the found orbits to describe the fully relativistic propagation of gravitational waves emitted in a Schwarzschild spacetime and I will show that the results compare well with the purely numerical results found in the literature. Finally, I will discuss how our methods can be applied to sources of multimessenger signals.
fields.speaker: Gideon Koekoek
fields.teaser_text: The method of geodesic deviations provides analytic approximations to geodesics and forced motion in arbitrary background spacetimes and does so to a high degree of accuracy regardless of the strength of the gravitational field.

fields.title: Higgs in the Sky
fields.text: To understand the beginning of structure formation in the universe, cosmologists assume a phase of "inflation": a dramatic expansion of spacetime that should have taken place in the very early universe. To get this expansion one needs a scalar field rolling down an almost flat potential. In this informal talk I will discuss the basics of inflation and, if time permits, investigate the possibility that this "inflaton" scalar field could actually be our own down-to-earth Higgs field.
fields.speaker: Sander Mooij
fields.teaser_text: In this informal talk I will discuss the basics of inflation and, if time permits, investigate the possibility that this "inflaton" scalar field could actually be our own down-to-earth Higgs field.

fields.title: What can you do with GRB afterglow spectra?
fields.text: Obtaining spectra of transient events such as gamma-ray burst afterglows is a challenging business. But once we have them, they may tell us a lot about the environment of the event. I will discuss the case of GRB100901, where we saw a live reaction of the burst on its surrounding material, and where we actually exploited the transient nature of afterglows.
fields.speaker: Olga Hartoog
fields.teaser_text: Obtaining spectra of transient events such as gamma-ray burst afterglows is a challenging business. But once we have them, they may tell us a lot about the environment of the event.

fields.title: The Spin Evolution of Magnetic Stars
fields.text:
Some stars rotate quickly, others slowly. In particular, some Ap stars
(which have very strong magnetic fields) rotate with spin periods of
10 or 100 years, which suggests they have lost well over 99% of the
angular momentum they initially had. I will review the explanations
for how these stars can spin down so efficiently, and argue that the
interaction between the magnetic field and a residual circumstellar
disc might be responsible for their extraordinary spin-down.
fields.speaker: Caroline D'Angelo
fields.teaser_text: Some stars rotate quickly, others slowly.  In particular, some Ap stars (which have very strong magnetic fields) rotate with spin periods of 10 or 100 years, which suggests they have lost well over 99% of the angular momentum they initially had.

fields.title: Energy injection in Short GRBs and the role of magnetars
fields.text: A significant fraction of the Long Gamma-ray Bursts (LGRBs) in the Swift sample show a plateau phase which may be due to ongoing energy injection. Many Short Gamma-ray Bursts (SGRBs) detected by the Swift satellite show similar behaviour. This suggests that many SGRBs show evidence of ongoing energy injection from the central engine. The progenitors of the majority of SGRBs are thought to be the merger of two Neutron Stars (NS) or a NS and a black hole (BH). It has been predicted that the remnant of NS-NS mergers may not collapse immediately to a BH (or even collapse at all), forming instead an unstable millisecond pulsar (magnetar). The model predicts that there would be a plateau phase in the X-ray lightcurve followed by a shallow decay phase, if it does not collapse to a BH, or a steep decay if the remnant collapses to a BH. By fitting the magnetar model to all of the Swift SGRBs, with sufficient X-ray data, we find that ~41-74% are consistent with the formation of a magnetar.
fields.speaker: Antonia Rowlinson
fields.teaser_text: A significant fraction of the Long Gamma-ray Bursts (LGRBs) in the Swift sample show a plateau phase which may be due to ongoing energy injection.

fields.title: Numerical relativity simulations of binary neutron star mergers
fields.text:
I will report about results from recent numerical relativity simulations of the late inspiral - merger phase of neutron star binaries. The impact of truncation and finite extraction errors on the waveforms will be discussed, as well as other systematic source of uncertainties. The estimated uncertainties may be relevant in case numerical waveforms are employed for building template banks. I will present a comparison between quasi-circular inspiral and post-Newtonian waveforms obtained from nine orbits, and discuss the impact of tidal effects. Finally, I will present the first set of fully relativistic simulations of highly eccentric mergers.

The gravitational wave signal is characterized by tidal signatures due the the f-mode of the stars, and may be of interest in a future detection.

The result is in qualitative agreement with previous Newtonian studies both analytic and numerical.
fields.speaker: Sebastiano Bernuzzi
fields.teaser_text: I will report about results from recent numerical relativity simulations of the late inspiral - merger phase of neutron star binaries.

fields.title: Astronomy in a Developing Country
fields.text: In this talk I will give an overview of how Astronomy works in a country such as my homeland (Colombia). To start with, a short history will be introduced. Then, I will focus on how our educational system is based and finally on what a student should do if he or she is interested in taking a research career in Astronomy.
fields.speaker: Oscar Ramirez
fields.teaser_text: In this talk I will give an overview of how Astronomy works in a country such as my homeland (Colombia).

fields.title: Magnetar Bursts in the Fermi Era: Results from the Gamma-ray Burst Monitor
fields.text: The Fermi Gamma-ray Burst Monitor (GBM) has detected hundreds of bursts from magnetars in the first three and a half years of operations. Its very large field of view, high temporal resolution and broad energy coverage are well suited for detailed burst studies. I will give an overview of the results obtained with GBM in this field, also in synergy with other satellites like Swift, and in particular discuss the most actively bursting magnetar of the last years, SGR J1550-5418.
fields.speaker: Alexander van der Horst
fields.teaser_text: The Fermi Gamma-ray Burst Monitor (GBM) has detected hundreds of bursts from magnetars in the first three and a half years of operations. I will give an overview of the results obtained with GBM in this field.

fields.title: Principle Component Analysis of supernova remnants
fields.text: Principle component analysis (PCA) is a mathematical technique which can be used to reduce the dimensionality of a data set consisting of a large number of interrelated variables, while retaining as much of the variation present in this data set. It is used to find variations and correlations in large datasets which are otherwise difficult to handle. I will discuss the application of this technique to supernova remnants, and why this technique may be useful for you.
fields.speaker: Sjors Broersen
fields.teaser_text: I will discuss the application of Principal Component Analysis to supernova remnants, and why this technique may be useful for you.

fields.title: Multiwavelength Analysis as a Probe of Accretion and Radiative Processes in Low Ionization Nuclear Emission Regions (LINERs)
fields.text:
This talk focuses on the faint end of the active galactic nuclei (AGN) luminosity function in the nearby universe, mainly populated by Low Ionization Nuclear Emission-line Regions (LINERs). LINERs are characterized by nuclear optical spectra dominated by emission lines from low-ionized species (e.g., O I).  These LINERs exhibit bolometric luminosities at least two orders of magnitude lower than classical luminous AGN (Seyferts and quasars). The accretion mechanism and radiative processes responsible for the bulk of energy from radio to X-rays in LINERs remain a riddle. Three possibilities have been invoked as the dominant source of power in such sources; (1) a geometrically thin optically thick accretion disk, similar to the one believed to exist in AGN, (2) a radiatively inefficient accretion  flow (RIAF), and fi nally (3) a jet-only model.

I will tackle the problem of accretion and radiative processes in a well defined
optically selected sample of LINERs showing a definite detection of broad H($\alpha$) emission (LINER 1s). I will give the X-ray and multiwavelength properties of these LINER 1s and show how they compare to AGN and to there less massive counter-parts, galactic black-hole X-ray binaries.
fields.speaker: George Younes
fields.teaser_text: This talk focuses on the faint end of the active galactic nuclei (AGN) luminosity function in the nearby universe, mainly populated by Low Ionization Nuclear Emission-line Regions (LINERs).

fields.title: Ultraluminous X-ray sources painting the picture of extreme accretion
fields.text: Mass accretion rates at and above the Eddington limit are synonymous with extremely luminous systems and powerful radiatively driven outflows. Such rates are necessary to explain the rapid growth of high redshift quasars and the associated outflows must play a role in the structure of the host galaxy and beyond. The local analogue of such quasars, the narrow-line Seyfert 1 AGN, provide a look at accretion in this 'Eddington-regime'. However, the disc emission peaks in the unobservable UV and the timescales of the flow are too long to provide a practical diagnostic of the growth processes leading to the low redshift universe. I will present the best evidence suggesting that the population of ultra-luminous X-ray sources (ULXs) are stellar mass black hole binaries accreting in the Eddington regime. I will discuss the prospects for studying their emission as a means to probe extreme accretion and the potential for outflows to distort the variability.
fields.speaker: Matt Middleton
fields.teaser_text: Mass accretion rates at and above the Eddington limit are synonymous with extremely luminous systems and powerful radiatively driven outflows. Such rates are necessary to explain the rapid growth of high redshift quasars and the associated outflows must play a role in the structure of the host galaxy and beyond.

fields.title: Gamma-ray lines & Co. in indirect searches for dark matter
fields.text: Searches for signatures from dark matter annihilation or decay in the cosmic gamma-ray fluxes are plagued by the question of how to disentangle the astrophysical backgrounds from a potential dark matter signal. Fortunately, most dark matter models feature very sharp signatures in their gamma-ray energy spectrum, coming from monochromatic photons, final-state radiation or virtual internal bremsstrahlung. These features could appear above the continuous astrophysical backgrounds as clear smoking-gun signatures for dark matter. I will discuss how ongoing experiments like the Fermi Large Area Telescope (LAT), or future Air Cherenkov Telescopes like the CTA, have the potential to discover these signatures in the near future. In fact, we already find some indication for a line-like feature at ~130 GeV in the galactic-center observation of the Fermi LAT.
fields.speaker: Christoph Weniger
fields.teaser_text: Searches for signatures from dark matter annihilation or decay in the cosmic gamma-ray fluxes are plagued by the question of how to disentangle the astrophysical backgrounds from a potential dark matter signal.

fields.title: The Star Formation Show with your host, Sir Herschel!
fields.text: I'll provide a compact review of star formation from galactic to single-star scales, relying on the latest imaging and spectral data and emphasizing general physical principles where possible.
fields.speaker: Mihkel Kama
fields.teaser_text: I'll provide a compact review of star formation from galactic to single-star scales, relying on the latest imaging and spectral data and emphasizing general physical principles where possible.

fields.title: A Pulsar Double-Feature Presentation:  'Attack of the Gamma-Ray Spiders from Space' followed by 'How Do You Juggle 3 Stars?'
fields.text:
Feature 1: The Fermi Gamma-Ray Space Telescope has provided us with a treasure map for finding millisecond radio pulsars. Surprisingly, many of these new discoveries are in so-called 'black-widow' binary systems, in which the pulsar is slowly destroying its mate. I will discuss the recent explosion in the population of these gamma-ray-emitting 'spiders'.

...a brief intermission...

Feature 2: Pulsars in binary systems are famous as ultra-precise probes for measuring orbital parameters and their evolution due to dynamical and/or post-Keplerian effects. But what happens if you add a third star into the mix? Do you dare juggle 3 stars at once?
fields.speaker: Jason Hessels
fields.teaser_text:
Feature 1: I will discuss so-called 'black-widow' binary systems, in which the pulsar is slowly destroying its mate. Feature 2: Pulsars in binary systems are famous as ultra-precise probes for measuring orbital parameters and their evolution.
But what happens if you add a third star into the mix?

fields.title: How to Apply for Stuff
fields.text:
It's that time of year again! For those of you who don't know, every year I give what has evolved into a special lunch talk + discussion aimed at de-mystifying the entire application process, from PhD positions to postdoc positions/fellowships, to eventually faculty jobs, though the focus is mostly on PhD/postdoc positions. Thus this talk is aimed primarily at MSc students, PhDs, and early stage Postdocs.

I will cover many general principles about strategizing and planning for the process at all levels, as well as the application itself, including the CVs, letters of rec, interviews. Even though a few parts are astro-specific, it's pretty generic and would be useful for people in all branches of physics, and maybe even all hard sciences. Even if you are just starting your MSc, it is definitely not too early to find out about what is ahead of you, since half the battle is strategizing well and planning in advance, and just being ready for the procedure. For those of you "on the market" this coming Fall, it is definitely time to start thinking about your plans!!
fields.speaker: Sera Markoff
fields.teaser_text: I wil give a special lunch talk + discussion aimed at de-mystifying the entire application process, from PhD positions to postdoc positions/fellowships, to eventually faculty jobs, though the focus is mostly on PhD/postdoc positions.

fields.title: Quantum Pasta
fields.text:
I discuss a poorly known solution of the Maxwell equations that describe light rays with a "fusilli" like shape. It has been recently shown that photons acquire a new quantum number known as photon orbital angular momentum that can be used in principle in astrophysical observations -- black holes being a particularly intriguing target.

I will describe my currently ongoing efforts to build a small optical lab at the Anton Pannekoek Observatory to try to detect these space "fusilli" before I become unemployed.
fields.speaker: Alessandro Patruno
fields.teaser_text: I discuss a poorly known solution of the Maxwell equations that describe light rays with a "fusilli" like shape. I will describe my efforts to build a small optical lab at the Anton Pannekoek Observatory to try to detect these space "fusilli".

fields.title: Tau-Day 2012 - How Leonhard Euler missed a great chance to make things right in Mathematics
fields.text: I will try to argue that all the fuss about the magic of PI has been about a constant that never should have been famous. When Leonhard Euler popularized the use of pi as the circle constant in mathematics he made a mistake that still confuses school children and makes equations in math less beautiful that they could have been.
fields.speaker: Carsten Dominik
fields.teaser_text: I will try to argue that all the fuss about the magic of PI has been about a constant that never should have been famous.

fields.title: The Physics of Stringed Instruments
fields.text: The violin family (violin, viola, cello and contrabass) of musical instruments are the result of an impressive amount of precise engineering and artistry that gives them a range of volume, pitch, and tone unmatched by any other instrument. In this talk I will discuss the evolution of the violin, from the murky origins of bowed instruments (which exist in many different cultures) all the way up to the present day. I will then focus on the physics of sound production in the modern violin, starting with the mechanics of producing a sound with a bow (a driven harmonic oscillator, with complications), and exploring how the normal modes of resonance  (which produce "Chladni patterns") produce the characteristic "violin" sound. I will round out my talk with a discussion (with a live demonstration) of some of the different techniques used in playing a stringed instrument, and discuss how they affect the quality (pitch, timbre and volume) of the sound. Depending on interest and time, some audience members will get a chance to try out some of what they have learned on a real instrument.
fields.speaker: Caroline D'Angelo
fields.teaser_text: The violin family (violin, viola, cello and contrabass) of musical instruments are the result of an impressive amount of precise engineering and artistry that gives them a range of volume, pitch, and tone unmatched by any other instrument.

fields.title: Black Hole Unification Across the Mass Scale
fields.text: Radiative and mechanical outflows from accreting black holes (i.e., winds/jets) interact with their large-scale environments, with important implications for many fields of astrophysics. Fortunately, nature provides a very diverse set of black holes to study, from stellar mass black holes in binary systems to supermassive black holes driving Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN). In this talk I show how statistical studies comparing black holes across the entire mass scale can afford a more holistic view of black hole accretion. In particular, the fundamental plane of black hole activity -- a relation connecting hard state black holes and their supermassive analogs -- suggests that black holes regulate their output similarly across the entire mass scale. I will show how the fundamental plane can be exploited as an effective tool to answer the hotly debated question: what is the dominant X-ray emission process in weakly accreting black holes? Along the way I use low-luminosity blazars (i.e., BL Lacs) to highlight some important systematic challenges to fitting the fundamental plane. In particular, I demonstrate how the effects of synchrotron cooling of jet emission from the most massive black holes can bias fundamental plane regressions, perhaps leading to incorrect inferences on X-ray radiation mechanisms.
fields.speaker: Rich Plotkin
fields.teaser_text: In this talk I show how statistical studies comparing black holes across the entire mass scale can afford a more holistic view of black hole accretion.

fields.title: Unraveling the accretion history of a young stellar object
fields.text: Understanding the formation process of high-mass (> 8 Msun) stars is one of the key questions in astronomy. New theoretical results indicate that high-mass stars can form through disk accretion, like low-mass stars. However, this is rarely observed because of the obscuration and small number of young high-mass stars. Intermediate-mass (2 - 8 Msun) stars are a good probe of high-mass star formation: they test the limits of low-mass star formation theory, yet they are less embedded than the more massive objects. We have observed a sample of intermediate-mass Young Stellar Objects (YSO) with the new X-shooter spectrograph on the ESO Very Large Telescope, which covers the full optical to near-infrared wavelength range in one shot. The object 08576nr292 is an intermediate-mass YSO with a disk, driving a Herbig-Haro jet (HH 1042). Using spectroscopic diagnostics, both the kinematics of and physical conditions in the jet can be measured. The kinematics contain a fossil record of the episodic outflow (and accretion) history. This can be simulated by a simple model, resulting in a two-mode sinusoidal outflow rate. The associated timescales are explained by the episodic nature of the accretion and jet-launching process.
fields.speaker: Lucas Ellerbroek
fields.teaser_text: Understanding the formation process of high-mass (> 8 Msun) stars is one of the key questions in astronomy. New theoretical results indicate that high-mass stars can form through disk accretion, like low-mass stars.  However, this is rarely observed because of the obscuration and small number of young high-mass stars.

fields.title: What's New With ADS? - Introducing ADS Labs
fields.text:
The SAO/NASA Astrophysics Data System (ADS) has been heavily used by astronomers since its inception, almost 20 years ago. In the past seven years its use has expanded to include substantially more scientists than the world's approximately 10,000 research astronomers. Currently there are about 55,000 frequent users, and up to 10 million infrequent users per year.  Access by the general public now accounts for about half of all ADS use, demonstrating the vast reach of the content in our databases. Increased demand and running into limitations of our infrastructure prompted the ADS team to start thinking about to migrate to a more flexible, scalable service without compromising the high standards our users have come to expect of our service. That is why we introduced the ADS Labs platform (http://adslabs.org).

ADS Labs is a platform that ADS is introducing in order to test and receive feedback from the community on new technologies and prototype services. Currently, ADS Labs features a new interface for abstract searches, faceted filtering of results, visualization of co-authorship networks, article-level recommendations, and a full-text search service. In this presentation I'll highlight some of the unique aspects of ADS Labs.
fields.speaker: Edwin Henneken
fields.teaser_text: ADS Labs is a platform that ADS is introducing in order to test and receive feedback from the community on new technologies and prototype services. Currently, ADS Labs features a new interface for abstract searches, faceted filtering of results, visualization of co-authorship networks, article-level recommendations, and a full-text search service. In this presentation I'll highlight some of the unique aspects of ADS Labs.

fields.title: Coming soon to a future near you: the next industrial revolution
fields.text: Few generations are gifted with living through a technological revolution.  Ours will see at least two.  The first is the information revolution, already well underway.  Although these revolutions are often unpredictable and seemingly come out of nowhere, the next revolution is already visible on the horizon and it will be 'industrial'.  A combination of remarkable technologies, notably 3D printing and new developments in manufacturing, materials science and biotech, will radically reshape how people live and work, ending the era of mass-production and opening the floodgates of human creativity.
fields.speaker: Phil Uttley
fields.teaser_text: Few generations are gifted with living through a technological revolution.  Ours will see at least two.

fields.title: Scale-invariance afterglow dynamics and light curves
fields.text:
Gamma-ray bursts are the biggest explosions in the universe, launching strongly relativistic jets that can be observed across the spectrum from X-rays to radio. Recent work has revealed that scale invariance in the dynamics of gamma-ray burst afterglow blast waves can be exploited to scale the results of high-resolution two dimensional relativistic jet simulations to arbitrary burster energies and circumburst densities. This allows for a new approach to afterglow data fitting, where we have developed a code to directly fit simulations to broadband afterglow data. In addition, we have discovered similar scaling relations directly between afterglow light curves, implying only a single set of parameterizations is sufficient to describe the complete parameter space of afterglow light curves.

These findings allow us to address open issues in afterglow science such as the lack of observed jet breaks, the evolution of closure relations linking spectral and temporal evolution, jet decollimation and the transition from ultra-relativistic to transrelativistic flow. I will discuss our current research where we apply scale invariance and jet simulations to these issues.
fields.speaker: Hendrik van Eerten
fields.teaser_text: Gamma-ray bursts are the biggest explosions in the universe, launching strongly relativistic jets that can be observed across the spectrum from X-rays to radio. Recent work has revealed that scale invariance in the dynamics of gamma-ray burst afterglow blast waves can be exploited to scale the results of high-resolution two dimensional relativistic jet simulations to arbitrary burster energies and circumburst densities.

fields.title: Rotational velocities of the single O-type stars in the Tarantula Nebula
fields.text: Projected rotational velocities have been estimated for 216 presumably single O-type stars in the VLT-FLAMES Tarantula survey. This has been analyzed to infer the underlying rotational velocity distribution, which is critical for understanding the evolution of massive stars.
fields.speaker: Oscar Ramirez
fields.teaser_text: Projected rotational velocities have been estimated for 216 presumably single O-type stars in the VLT-FLAMES Tarantula survey. This has been analyzed to infer the underlying rotational velocity distribution.

fields.title: Non-thermal Emission in Galaxy Clusters: from Radio to Gamma-rays
fields.text: Clusters of galaxies are expected to contain substantial population of cosmic-rays that can yield to a significant radio and gamma-ray emission. Moreover, as they are dark matter dominated systems, they must be considered prime targets for indirect dark matter searches. I will briefly review the current knowledge on the non-thermal emission processes in galaxy clusters and report on our efforts in this field with particular emphasis on gamma-ray studies with the MAGIC telescopes.
fields.speaker: Fabio Zandanel
fields.teaser_text: I will briefly review the current knowledge on the non-thermal emission processes in galaxy clusters and report on our efforts in this field with particular emphasis on gamma-ray studies with the MAGIC telescopes.

fields.title: Cepheids in the history of Astronomy: It's not just about the distance scale
fields.text: After a brief presentation of their properties, I will illustrate the importance of Cepheids in the history of Astronomy, dating back to the late 19th century. As we will see, their contribution is not limited to the distance scale and the determination of the Hubble constant (but I will also say a few words about it).
fields.speaker: Bertrand Lemasle
fields.teaser_text: After a brief presentation of their properties, I will illustrate the importance of Cepheids in the history of Astronomy, dating back to the late 19th century. As we will see, their contribution is not limited to the distance scale and the determination of the Hubble constant.

fields.title: New predictions for X-ray binaries as Galactic gamma-ray, cosmic-ray and neutrino sources
fields.text: X-ray binaries (XRBs) are binary systems in which a compact object (neutron star or black hole) accretes matter from a companion star. The accretion processes onto a compact object emit strongly in the X-ray band, making XRBs the brightest sources of X-rays in our galaxy. Also associated with XRBs is radio emission from both discrete ejecta as well as collimated, compact jets. The jets are relativistic outflows launched from the vicinity of the compact object and are believed to be powerful particle accelerators. As a consequence of the intense studies of XRBs from the radio through X-ray bands over the past decades, we can characterize properties such as distinct accretion states, and the disk/jet connection via correlations such as that observed between the radio/IR and X-rays. In the last few years, the rapid development of gamma-ray observations has open a new window on these sources, with at least one solid detection so far. Associated with these gamma-rays are neutrino emission. In this talk we present a new lepto-hadronic model that is based on successful work fitting the lower energy, broadband spectra of XRBs in the compact jet-dominated state. Protons (and electrons) are accelerated throughout the jet and cool via radiation and inelastic collisions, and we calculate spectral energy distributions (SEDs) including both hadronic and leptonic induced processes. We present new predictions for the gamma-ray fluxes in the GeV-TeV range. Moreover we will discuss neutrino flux prediction from the model. This model can also be scaled to describe the SEDs of low-luminosity active galactic nuclei (LLAGN) such as our own Galactic Center black hole Sgr A*.
fields.speaker: Samia Drappeau
fields.teaser_text: X-ray binaries are binary systems in which a compact object accretes matter from a companion star. In the last few years, the rapid development of gamma-ray observations has open a new window on these sources, with at least one solid detection so far. Associated with these gamma-rays are neutrino emission.

fields.title: "An X-Raydio Switcheroo" followed by "An X-Raydio Switcheroo -- Behind the Music" How to prepare a good talk
fields.text:
We present high-sensitivity XMM/LOFAR observations that show for the first time that mode switching extends from radio to X-ray. In pulsar B0943+10, the known changes in radio profile and drift rate are confidently tied to simultaneous changes in X-ray emission.

In mode switching, seen in many pulsars, profile and subpulse-drift behavior change almost instantaneously. The mechanism for these drastic changes, or for the bi-stable emission behavior, is not understood; while even for the basic emission mechanism different families of theories exist.

To discriminate between such models, we carried out a campaign of 42 hours of simultaneous LOFAR/XMM-Newton observations on PSR B0943+10. Through LOFAR's unparalleled low-frequency sensitivity, mode changes were pinpointed to ~10-second accuracy. XMM X-ray photons were next separated by the two radio modes. We discovered large modal differences in the X-ray pulsations, flux, and spectral shapes: in the radio-bright mode, no X-ray pulsations are detected -- but in the radio-quiet mode, B0943+10 is strongly pulsating in X-ray.
fields.speaker: Joeri van Leeuwen
fields.teaser_text: We present high-sensitivity XMM/LOFAR observations that show for the first time that mode switching extends from radio to X-ray. In pulsar B0943+10, the known changes in radio profile and drift rate are confidently tied to simultaneous changes in X-ray emission.

fields.title: The exciting adventures of Dusty the Circumstellar Dust Grain
fields.text:
In this adventure we will follow Dusty, the brave little dust grain, on his great quest through a perilous debris disk. Starting in a distant parent belt together with many friends, Dusty will venture into the scorching innermost regions of the system. Will he survive this great ordeal?

Along the way, we will learn more about the role of sublimation in debris disks. In particular, we will see how the interplay of Poynting-Robertson drag and sublimation can lead to the pile-up of dust in the sublimation zone, and whether this might explain the near infrared emission emanating from very close to host stars.
fields.speaker: Rik van Lieshout
fields.teaser_text: In this adventure we will follow Dusty, the brave little dust grain, on his great quest through a perilous debris disk. Starting in a distant parent belt together with many friends, Dusty will venture into the scorching innermost regions of the system. Will he survive this great ordeal?

fields.title: Imaging with Radio Telescopes
fields.text: The development of Imaging using Radio Telescopes has a fascinating history, and this field has made spectacular improvements in a relatively short time. While providing an overview of Radio Imaging from the conceptual and historical perspective, I will highlight the role played by advances in algorithms and computing power in this field, as well as its impact on other areas. Finally, I will present some results from our ongoing work with LOFAR.
fields.speaker: Peeyush Prasad
fields.teaser_text: The development of Imaging using Radio Telescopes has a fascinating history, and this field has made spectacular improvements in a relatively short time. While providing an overview of Radio Imaging from the conceptual and historical perspective, I will highlight the role played by advances in algorithms and computing power in this field, as well as its impact on other areas.

fields.title: Exploring the Wind of W Hya
fields.text: The peculiar wind of W Hya, an oxygen-rich Asymptotic Giant Branch star, seems to be rather unique when compared to similar objects, as revealed by recent observations of both the dust continuum and molecular line emission. I will present a self-consistent model for the CO lines observed by Herschel and for the dust emission observed by the Infrared Space Observatory and also Herschel, which indeed confirms the peculiarity of W Hya's wind. The CO envelope is found to be much smaller than what is predicted by theory and seen in other objects and the dust shell shows extended emission that cannot be accounted for by a constant mass loss rate model.
fields.speaker: Theo Chousinho Khouri Silva
fields.teaser_text: The peculiar wind of W Hya, an oxygen-rich Asymptotic Giant Branch star, seems to be rather unique when compared to similar objects, as revealed by recent observations of both the dust continuum and molecular line emission. I will present a self-consistent model for the CO lines observed by Herschel and for the dust emission observed by the Infrared Space Observatory and also Herschel.

fields.title: Radio Pulsars: Electrical Generators in the Sky
fields.text: Radio pulsars are celestial electrical generators directly accelerating charged particles and producing abundant electron-positron plasma in their magnetospheres. They are fascinating astronomical sources shining over the whole electromagnetic spectrum, from radio to the highest energy gamma-rays. Although they belong to "classical old-fashioned" astronomical objects discovered a long time ago, there is still no quantitative theoretical model which could explain even the most fundamental of their observational properties. In this talk I will briefly overview the current state of pulsar models and recent progress in the field. I will argue that pulsars are much more complex objects than was assumed before.
fields.speaker: Andrey Timokhin
fields.teaser_text: Radio pulsars are celestial electrical generators directly accelerating charged particles and producing abundant electron-positron plasma in their magnetospheres.  They are fascinating astronomical sources shining over the whole electromagnetic spectrum, from radio to the highest energy gamma-rays.

fields.title: The Importance of Signal Distortion in Precision Pulsar Timing and Electric Guitar
fields.text: Precision pulsar timing and electric guitar have more in common than you'd expect… at least if you're an astronomer that loves to rock out. In both cases, the relatively clean signal emitted by the pulsar/guitar is distorted. In the case of pulsars, this distortion is imparted by the interstellar medium. Completely removing these time and frequency-dependent effects means perfecting Nature's near-perfect clocks. Ultimately, this could be a crucial step towards directly detecting gravitational waves using a "Pulsar Timing Array". In the case of electric guitar, a number of effects can be added to the raw waveform in order to create the characteristic sounds of, e.g., country, rock, and punk music.  In this API Pizza talk, I will share some thoughts on both of these topics and make links between them. Warning: there will be live guitar music.
fields.speaker: Jason Hessels
fields.teaser_text: Precision pulsar timing and electric guitar have more in common than you'd expect -- at least if you're an astronomer that loves to rock out.

fields.title: A physical model for the spectral timing properties of black hole binaries
fields.text: It has been known for over 20 years that the X-ray emission from black hole binaries displays quasi-periodic oscillations (QPOs) plus broad band variability. Although these power spectral features are very well studied, there is still no consensus in the literature as to their physical origin. I describe a model that associates the QPO with relativistic precession of the inner regions of the accretion flow and the broad band noise with propagating fluctuations in mass accretion rate. I describe how these two ingredients can be combined in order to fit the power spectrum of a black hole with a physical model for the first time.
fields.speaker: Adam Ingram
fields.teaser_text: I describe a model that associates quasi-periodic oscillations in black hole binaries with relativistic precession of the inner regions of the accretion flow and the broad band noise with propagating fluctuations in mass accretion rate.

fields.title: New Methods for Timing Analysis of Transient Events, Applied to Fermi GBM Magnetar Bursts
fields.text: In order to discern the physical nature of many gamma-ray sources in the sky, we must look not only in spectral and spatial dimensions, but also understand their temporal variability. However, timing analysis of sources with a highly transient nature, such as magnetar bursts, is difficult: standard Fourier techniques  developed for long-term variability generally observed, for example, from AGN often do not apply. Here, I present newly developed timing methods applicable to transient events of all kinds, and show its successful application to magnetar bursts observed with Fermi GBM. Magnetars are a prime subject for timing studies, thanks to the detection of quasi-periodicities in magnetar Giant Flares and their potential to help shed light on the structure of neutron stars. I will explain how we use modern statistical techniques to search for quasi-periodic oscillations (QPOs) in a sample of bursts observed with Fermi GBM and for the first time characterise broadband variability of magnetar bursts. I will highlight how this new information could provide us with another way to probe these mysterious objects.
fields.speaker: Daniela Huppenkothen
fields.teaser_text: I will explain how we use modern statistical techniques to search for quasi-periodic oscillations (QPOs) in a sample of bursts observed with Fermi GBM and for the first time characterise broadband variability of magnetar bursts.

fields.title: Relativistic precession around neutron stars
fields.text: Precession is a characteristic that distinguishes the behavior of orbits in general relativity from their behavior in Newtonian gravity. We have precession even in the simplest case, the Schwarzschild geometry, which is the analog of the Newtonian gravitational field of an isolated spherically symmetric mass that has perfect ellipsis for bound orbits. Adding rotation enriches the effects of precession as one can see from the orbits in the Kerr geometry. But as in the case of Newtonian gravity, where one can induce precession by adding a quadrupole deformation to the source of the field, having a geometry with a different structure than that of Kerr could result in interesting deviations of the properties of the orbits from the properties that the orbits have in the case of Kerr. This is what happens for spacetimes around rotating neutron stars and these differences will be the focus of my talk, after a short discussion on how one can obtain a geometry for the exterior of a neutron star.
fields.speaker: George Pappas
fields.teaser_text: Precession is a characteristic that distinguishes the behavior of orbits in general relativity from their behavior in Newtonian gravity. We have precession even in the simplest case, the Schwarzschild geometry, which is the analog of the Newtonian gravitational field of an isolated spherically symmetric mass that has perfect ellipsis for bound orbits.

fields.title: Radiative GRMHD simulations of accretion onto Sgr A: Are radiative losses important?
fields.text: We present general relativistic magnetohydrodynamic (GRMHD) numerical simulations of the accretion flow around the supermassive black hole in the Galactic centre, Sagittarius A* (Sgr A*). The simulations include for the first time radiative cooling processes (synchrotron, bremsstrahlung, and inverse Compton) self-consistently in the dynamics, allowing us to test the common simplification of ignoring all cooling losses in the modeling of Sgr A*. We confirm that for Sgr A*, neglecting the cooling losses is a reasonable approximation if the Galactic centre is accreting below ~10^{-8} Msun/yr i.e. Mdot < 10^{-7} Mdot_Edd. But above this limit, we show that radiative losses should be taken into account as significant differences appear in the dynamics and the resulting spectra when comparing simulations with and without cooling. This limit implies that most nearby low-luminosity active galactic nuclei are in the regime where cooling should be taken into account. We further make a parameter study of axisymmetric gas accretion around the supermassive black hole at the Galactic centre. This approach allows us to investigate the physics of gas accretion in general, while confronting our results with the well studied and observed source, Sgr A*, as a test case. We confirm that the nature of the accretion flow and outflow is strongly dependent on the initial geometry of the magnetic field. For example, we find it difficult, even with very high spins, to generate powerful outflows from discs threaded with multiple, separate poloidal field loops.
fields.speaker: Salome Dibi
fields.teaser_text: We present (GRMHD) numerical simulations of the accretion flow around Sagittarius A*. The simulations include for the first time radiative cooling processes (synchrotron, bremsstrahlung, and inverse Compton) self-consistently in the dynamics, allowing us to test the common simplification of ignoring all cooling losses in the modeling of Sgr A*.

fields.title: Beam me up! Astronomy communication on social media
fields.text: Astronomy is communicated to the general public because it enriches our culture, nourishes a scientific outlook in society and addresses important questions about humanity's place in the universe. Therefore, the communication of astronomy is an investment in the future as is described in the Washington Charter for communicating astronomy with the public. Thankfully, astronomy is one of the few beta sciences that appeals to almost anyone but it remains difficult to reach and engage with some target groups. One of these is the youth in the age 12 to 18. The youth is increasingly active social media, therefore, this may be suitable medium to effectively reach and engage with the youth. However, the question remains: how should the social media be used by the NOVA Information Center to reach and engage the 'hard to reach' youth in the age 12 to 18 in the Netherlands on astronomy? One of the better ways to answer this question is by asking the youth. This was done this in accordance with well known qualitative methods. We developed four scenarios which selected youngsters in the age 12 to 16 analyzed and discussed in focus group interviews that we successfully carried out on five high schools. We carried out a thematic content analysis to analyze the transcribed data. In this presentation we will present more background information on the problem, the details of these methods, the problems we faced and the important conclusions that relate to the research question.
fields.speaker: Franka Buurmeijer
fields.teaser_text: Astronomy is communicated to the general public because it enriches our culture, nourishes a scientific outlook in society and addresses important questions about humanity's place in the universe. Therefore, the communication of astronomy is an investment in the future as is described in the Washington Charter for communicating astronomy with the public.

fields.title: Dust in the wind - A direct measurement of accretion efficiency
fields.text: Since most astrophysical processes take place on timescales much longer than a human life, let alone a single PhD project, it is rarely feasible to directly probe their temporal evolution. For this reason, and in part because the phenomenon is just too daftly complex to even begin explaining it, accretion variability is quite a pristine research area within the star formation community. Until today. Measuring variability on timescales much longer than my scientific adolescence is made possible by the fossil record contained in my favorite pet objects: protostellar jets. In this talk, I will present my first attempt at a direct, quantitative measurement of accretion and simultaneous ejection in the young and famous Herbig star HD 163296. This measurement will constrain the jet launching efficiency parameter better than before, and rather unexpectedly, it may provide a solution for the long-standing mystery of the near-infrared excess emission of this particular class of objects, the Herbig stars.
fields.speaker: Lucas Ellerbroek
fields.teaser_text: Since most astrophysical processes take place on timescales much longer than a human life, it is rarely feasible to directly probe their temporal evolution. For this reason, and in part because the phenomenon is just too daftly complex, accretion variability is quite a pristine research area within the star formation community.

fields.title: Digging out cosmological information from CMB lensing in the Planck era
fields.text: The CMB lensing effect is the deflection of the trajectories of the CMB photons by the large-scale structure of the Universe. This effect leaves a distinctive feature on the observed CMB than can be used to efficiently extract information on the matter distribution at high redshift. Reconstruction of the lensing potential from the Planck temperature map requires the treatment of systematic effects inherent in the full-sky nature of the survey. In this seminar, I will present a simple, yet robust treatment of the portions of the sky that require masking, and apply it to Planck-like simulated data. I will also concentrate on the uses of the lensing potential in joint analysis with current and future galaxy surveys such as the Dark Energy Survey (DES) and Euclid.
fields.speaker: Aurélien Benoit-Lévy
fields.teaser_text: The CMB lensing effect is the deflection of the trajectories of the CMB photons by the large-scale structure of the Universe. This effect leaves a distinctive feature on the observed CMB than can be used to efficiently extract information on the matter distribution at high redshift.

fields.title: Rainbows on exoplanets covered by liquid and icy water clouds
fields.text: The detection of the first rocky exoplanets triggered the quest for signs of habitability. From observations of Solar System planets it is known that clouds play a crucial role on a planet's climate, which in turn is crucial for planetary habitability. Parameters like the cloud's particle microphysical properties, optical thickness and altitude have been shown to effect the observed cloud signatures and the cloud's affect on the planetary climate. Clearly, the detection and characterization of clouds on exoplanets would provide us with a wealth of information on the conditions in the atmosphere and on the planetary surface (if there is any). From Earth remote-sensing studies we know that the identification of liquid water clouds on exoplanets could be done via the detection of the rainbow in the degree of polarization of starlight that is reflected by the planet. The strength of the rainbow features will strongly depend on the cloud particle sizes and the variations therein across the planet and the percentage of cloud coverage. We have created an advanced numerical code with which we can calculate the flux and polarization signals of planets with atmospheres that are both vertically and horizontally inhomogeneous. Using a variety of test cases we study the appearance of the rainbow feature. As I will show, the polarized rainbow appears to be a robust signature of the presence of water clouds. Polarization measurements should thus be considered in future missions of characterization of exoplanets.
fields.speaker: Theodora Karalidi
fields.teaser_text: We have created an advanced numerical code with which we can calculate the flux and polarization signals of planets with atmospheres that are both vertically and horizontally inhomogeneous. Using a variety of test cases we study the appearance of the rainbow feature.  As I will show, the polarized rainbow appears to be a robust signature of the presence of water clouds.

fields.title: Identifying gaps in proto-planetary disks
fields.text: The evolution of proto-planetary disks towards mature planetary systems is expected to include the formation of 'gaps' in the disk possibly due to planet formation. We studied the disks of four key intermediate mass (Herbig Ae/Be) stars in order to understand the influence of gaps to their observational appearance. We investigate mid-infrared images and perform radiative transfer modeling to examine the radial distribution of dust and PAHs. Our solutions constrain the sizes of the gaps. For one particular object, HD 97048, this is the first detection of a disk gap. The large gaps deplete the entire population of silicate particles with temperatures suitable for prominent mid-infrared feature emission, while small carbonaceous grains and PAHs can still show prominent emission at mid-infrared wavelengths. The absence of silicate emission features is due to the presence of large gaps in the critical temperature regime. Our results suggest that many, if not all Herbig disks with weak or no silicate features in the spectrum are disks with large gaps and can be characterized as (pre-)transitional. We conclude that the evolution of Herbig stars follows two different paths. Competition between the timescales of inner versus outer disk evolution determine whether young proto-planetary disks evolve into transitional disks (due to planet formation in the inner disk) or into flat disks (due to the grain growth and dust settling in the outer disk).
fields.speaker: Koen Maaskant
fields.teaser_text: The evolution of proto-planetary disks towards mature planetary systems is expected to include the formation of 'gaps' in the disk possibly due to planet formation. We studied the disks of four key intermediate mass (Herbig Ae/Be) stars in order to understand the influence of gaps to their observational appearance.

fields.title: In the quest for a permanent job: a summary of things I was never told
fields.text: So the time came that I had to start looking for a permanent job and "Baboom!!!!",  What? when? why? how? .... Baboom!!!! and then I started to realize how many things I wish I had known long before and unfortunately nobody told me (or I never paid attention to it :-S). So in this talk, I will share my own experience, trying to summarize the most important things I have learned so far.
fields.speaker: Diego Altamirano
fields.teaser_text: So the time came that I had to start looking for a permanent job and "Baboom!!!!",  What? when? why? how? .... Baboom!!!!

fields.title: Mass accretion onto Dark Matter halos and their central galaxies: Smooth or clumpy? Hot or cold?
fields.text: In the LCDM model, both Dark Matter halos and the baryonic galaxies form hierarchically over time. I will start by describing the 'smooth' and 'merger' growth modes of Dark Matter halos as inferred from large cosmological N-body simulations, and emphasize the importance of minor mergers and smooth accretion. I will move on to the baryonic component, where large efforts in the past decade have concentrated on distinguishing between quasi-spherical 'hot mode' accretion and filamentary 'cold mode' accretion. To this end, I will discuss recent results obtained using the novel moving-mesh hydro code Arepo, which dramatically modify our understanding of gas accretion onto galaxies.
fields.speaker: Shy Genel
fields.teaser_text: In the LCDM model, both Dark Matter halos and the baryonic galaxies form hierarchically over time. I will discuss recent results obtained using the novel moving-mesh hydro code Arepo, which dramatically modify our understanding of gas accretion onto galaxies.

fields.title: Creating a mosaic from images using PCA and machine learning.
fields.text:
This talk is about a hobby project of mine, mixing math and art. The creation of a mosaic from several small images. Given an input image and a database of images we try to recreate the input image. Of course, there exist many mosaic programs already, but not like this one.

I will explain the various key parts in the algorithms, why it works better and show some of the pretty results obtained by this technique.

fields.title: Blasts from the past and their future
fields.text: Radio observations of gamma-ray bursts provide a unique way to probe the fastest ejecta in stellar explosions and their direct environment. I will discuss how the radio regime compliments the coverage of the broadband gamma-ray burst spectrum, and is crucial in determining their macro- and microphysical parameters. I will describe the possibilities which upgraded and new radio facilities like LOFAR, MeerKAT and AMI will offer in terms of spectral and temporal coverage, and how this will lead to a better understanding of these extreme phenomena.
fields.speaker: Alexander van der Horst
fields.teaser_text: Radio observations of gamma-ray bursts provide a unique way to probe the fastest ejecta in stellar explosions and their direct environment. I will discuss how the radio regime compliments the coverage of the broadband gamma-ray burst spectrum.

fields.title: R144 and DR1 - two extraordinary Wolf-Rayet stars
fields.text:
I will present recent results on two Wolf-Rayet stars, R144 in the LMC, and DR1 in IC1613. The first is the brightest Wolf-Rayet star in the LMC, and for that reason has long be suspected to be a binary, although radial velocity variations have not been observed in earlier research. Using multi-epoch X-Shooter observations, we have now identified R144 as a double-lined spectroscopic binary. Mass estimates based on its luminosity suggest a present day mass content of 200-300 solar masses, making it the most massive binary system known to date.

The second object, DR1, is one of the only eight known oxygen sequence Wolf-Rayet stars. These stars are usually seen as the successors of WC stars, where the high-excitation oxygen emission is the result of an enhanced surface abundance, as helium-burning products are being revealed by the strong stellar wind. Alternatively, the oxygen emission might be purely due to a higher stellar temperature. Modeling the spectrum of DR1 suggest that the latter is the case, as the surface abundances are not enhanced compared to WC stars.
fields.speaker: Frank Tramper
fields.teaser_text: I will present recent results on two Wolf-Rayet stars, R144 in the LMC, and DR1 in IC1613. The first is the brightest Wolf-Rayet star in the LMC, and for that reason has long be suspected to be a binary, although radial velocity variations have not been observed in earlier research. Using multi-epoch X-Shooter observations, we have now identified R144 as a double-lined spectroscopic binary.

fields.title: Power Colours: Power Spectral Classification without Fitting
fields.text: Low mass black hole binaries (LMXBs) are transient X-ray sources, going through several state transitions during an outburst. These states are classified using both the energy spectral and temporal properties within each observation, and are remarkably similar from source to source, despite differences in mass, inclination angle and binary separation. I will present a model independent method of characterising the variability properties throughout an outburst, by comparing ratios of temporal power over different frequency ranges. We can use this to demonstrate not only the similarities between all of the the LMXBs, but also the persistent High Mass X-ray binary Cygnus X-1. I'll then explain how this method could be used to both aid state classification for faint sources and help expand our understanding of power spectral components in well observed galactic objects.
fields.speaker: Lucy Heil
fields.teaser_text: I will present a model independent method of characterising the variability properties throughout an outburst, by comparing ratios of temporal power over different frequency ranges. We can use this to demonstrate not only the similarities between all of the the LMXBs, but also the persistent High Mass X-ray binary Cygnus X-1.

fields.title: Run!!
fields.text: In this talk I will discuss my favourite pastime: distance running. I will share some of the cutting-edge scientific research on distance running, as well as some of the knowledge I have personally obtained in 18 years of running with anyone from recreational joggers to 10-km-in-31-minutes diehards. Along the way, I will answer the three major questions that I have heard asked many times regarding distance running: 'Why would anyone want to run in the first place?', 'Why do the East-Africans always win?' and last but not least, 'How do I become faster than Martin in 5 easy steps?'.
fields.speaker: Thijs van Putten
fields.teaser_text: I will answer the three major questions that I have heard asked many times regarding distance running: 'Why would anyone want to run in the first place?', 'Why do the East-Africans always win?' and last but not least, 'How do I become faster than Martin in 5 easy steps?'.

fields.title: How to apply for stuff
fields.speaker: Sera Markoff

fields.title: The colour of planet forming disks - evidence for the initial steps
fields.text: Planet formation starts when the small, dust grains leftover from the interstellar medium, aggregate to form dust balls in protoplanetary disks. The efficiency of this process, and the structure of the resulting aggregates is a matter of debate. Yet, in the light of the recent discoveries from ALMA, we have to understand this in order to understand the dust dynamical which is observed. When we want to constrain this from observations we have to know how these large dust aggregates interact with radiation, which is computationally very challenging. I will discuss this, and present a case where we find evidence for aggregated structures in the surface layer of a protoplanetary disk.
fields.speaker: Michiel Min
fields.teaser_text: Planet formation starts when the small, dust grains leftover from the interstellar medium, aggregate to form dust balls in protoplanetary disks. The efficiency of this process, and the structure of the resulting aggregates is a matter of debate.

fields.title: An outflow-­dominated model for GX339-­4 and M81*
fields.text: Accreting black holes with the presence of jets are a common feature in different astrophysical objects, namely black hole X-ray Binaries (XRBs) and Low Luminosity Active Galactic Nuclei (LLAGN). From outflow-dominated models we can infer some kind of coupling between the accreting plasma and the jets. This is still under intensive research and the nature of this coupling remains a great unknown. Evidence for this relationship was found through simultaneous broadband observations. A correlation between the radio and the X-ray fluxes was determined and it seems to be applicable to all sources known with simultaneous radio and X-ray data regardless of the mass of the compact object. This fact stimulates intense research for a unified model for XRBs and LLAGNs, suggesting that different classes of AGN might be in fact temporal states of the accretion states observed in X-ray binaries. I will present the results from an outflow-dominated model for the XRB GX339-4 and for the LLAGN M81*. Furthermore, I will also present the results of a model including the dust emission and a stellar template for the case of M81* to investigate the contribution from the host galaxy in the spectrum.
fields.speaker: Catia de Jesus Silva
fields.teaser_text: Accreting black holes with the presence of jets are a common feature in different astrophysical objects, namely black hole X-ray Binaries  and Low Luminosity Active Galactic Nuclei. From outflow-dominated models we can infer some kind of coupling between the accreting plasma and the jets.

fields.title: I: A double Damped Lyman-alpha Absorber towards a z=5 gamma-ray burst
fields.text:
The spectrum of the afterglow of gamma-ray burst 111008A, a cosmic explosion at redshift z=5, reveals not only the host galaxy of this GRB, but also another foreground absorber at z=4.6. This system is, like the host, classified as a Damped Ly-alpha (DLA) system: because of the high neutral hydrogen column density, Lyman-alpha is detected as a very strong line with characteristic damping wings.

Intervening absorbers are very common in GRB afterglow spectra, but having one that is so strong, which forms a high-redshift pair with the host-galaxy DLA, is quite an unique situation. Furthermore, this spectrum is the most detailed we have for a GRB afterglow at this redshift, which allows us tell something about the chemical composition of a galaxy when the universe was only a few gigayears old. The host looks surprisingly like a present-day galaxy. But if iron-group elements are formed in Supernovae type Ia, where do they come from? The progenitors of these phenomena did not yet have enough time to die when the universe was so young.

The foreground z=4.6 appears to be very metal-rich for this redshift (about 20% solar). The broadband SED from the afterglow tells us that there is only little absorption in the line of sight, which must therefore all happen in the foreground object, because of its metals and expected dust content. This leaves essentially no extinction and thus no dust for the host galaxy, which gives interesting constraints to the metals-to-dust ratio as a function of redshift, and to the question how dust is formed in the early universe.
fields.speaker: Olga Hartoog
fields.teaser_text: The spectrum of the afterglow of gamma-ray burst 111008A reveals not only the host galaxy of this GRB,  but also another foreground absorber. This system is classified as a Damped Ly-alpha system: because of the high  neutral hydrogen column density, Lyman-alpha is detected as a very  strong line with characteristic damping wings.

fields.title: Binge and Purge - What can we learn from ULXs?
fields.text: Ultraluminous X-ray sources (ULXs) up to 1041 erg/s are likely to be associated with extreme rates of accretion onto stellar mass (up to ~100 Msun) black holes in other galaxies. Although direct confirmation of their mass (and by extension their mode of accretion) remains elusive, I will present the clearest evidence to date that those of lower (<1040 erg/s) luminosities harbour stellar mass black holes by virtue of the discovery of the first confirmed extragalactic micro-quasar. No such evidence exists for the brighter (and more contentious) ULXs but indirect evidence points towards large scale height winds lifted from the inner regions which impact our view of the spectra and variability. I will present the key evidence for this argument and discuss what we can potentially learn from further study of ULXs.
fields.speaker: Matt Middleton
fields.teaser_text: Ultraluminous X-ray sources (ULXs) up to 10^41 erg/s are likely to be associated with extreme rates of accretion onto stellar mass (up to ~100 M_sun) black holes in other galaxies. Although direct confirmation of their mass (and by extension their mode of accretion) remains elusive, I will present the clearest evidence to date that those of lower (<10^40 erg/s) luminosities harbour stellar mass black holes by virtue of the discovery of the first confirmed extragalactic micro-quasar.

fields.title: Stars above the waterline? NL astronomy until 2020
fields.text: NL astronomy has recently produced its decadal plan for the period until 2020, and presented it to the government. Part of it concerns the science we will do in this decade, and part of it deals with investments in observatories of the 2020s. I will discuss some main points of this plan, and where it will take us in the future.
fields.speaker: Ralph Wijers
fields.teaser_text: NL astronomy has recently produced its decadal plan for the period until 2020, and presented it to the government. I will discuss some main points of this plan, and where it will take us in the future.

fields.title: II: The Golden Ratio
fields.text:
In this talk I am going to discuss about the mathematical and artistic origin of the Golden Ratio. According to classical standards that is the most beautiful proportion you can find and it has a mathematical definition!

There will be a test to see if that is still applicable today according to what we are now used to.

However the test goes, I will also highlight the connections of that magical number to the physical world we live in,  astronomy included, so to convince the heretics to change their mind
fields.speaker: Yuri Cavecchi
fields.teaser_text: In this talk I am going to discuss about the mathematical and artistic origin of the Golden Ratio. According to classical standards that is the most beautiful proportion you can find and it has a mathematical definition!

fields.title: I: New constraints on the giant lobe physics and turbulence-driven UHECR acceleration in Centaurus A
fields.text: Giant lobes of radio galaxies are potential sources of ultra-high energy cosmic rays (UHECRs) detected by large cosmic-ray experiments. Knowledge of the physical conditions -- the energetics, particle content and turbulent state -- in the lobes is vital for understanding high-energy particle acceleration and UHECR production in full. Synthesising the available observational constraints on the physical conditions and particle content in the jets, inner lobes and giant lobes of Centaurus A, we evaluate the feasibility of this object as an UHECR source. We propose a self-consistent model in which hadrons ingested by jets via external entrainment from hot gas and internal entrainment from jet-contained stars contribute to pressure in the giant lobes, and I will show that, to meet the pressure requirements for the lobes, the hadrons must be outstandingly hot. The same 'very hot' temperatures that allow self-consistency between the entrainment calculations and the missing pressure also allow stochastic UHECR acceleration models to work.
fields.speaker: Sarka Wykes
fields.teaser_text: Giant lobes of radio galaxies are potential sources of ultra-high energy cosmic rays detected by large cosmic-ray experiments. Knowledge of the physical conditions -- the energetics, particle content and turbulent state -- in the lobes is vital for understanding high-energy particle acceleration in full.

fields.title: II: Revealing the Nature of the Ultraluminous X-ray sources in NGC 4861
fields.text:
ULXs are defined as off-nuclear X-ray sources with isotropic luminosities much higher than the Eddington limit for a solar mass black hole (Lx~1.3e38 erg/s). Typical X-ray luminosities of ULXs are in between 10^39 and 10^41 erg/s. The physical nature of ULXs has been an enigma because of their high energy output. Some ULXs show strong variability suggesting that they are accreting compact objects. Assuming the emission is isotropic, some of the very bright ULXs may harbor intermediate-mass black holes. Some ULXs may just be stellar mass black holes with radiation pressure-dominated or slim accretion disks that cause super-Eddington luminosities. Alternatively, some ULXs may be young X-ray luminous supernova remnants in a high density medium, or hypernova remnants.

Optical counterparts of some ULXs are found to be consistent with high mass stars with sometimes evidence for variability and blue spectra possibly indicative of an accretion disc. In addition, a large fraction of ULXs appear to be associated with extended nebulae; supershells hundreds of parsecs in diameter. These large supershells are found to be powered by photoionization and/ or shock-excitation from the ULXs.

In this talk, I will present our new results of ULXs in the metal-deficit blue compact dwarf galaxy NGC 4861. Previous studies reveal two ULXs (both ~10^40 erg/s) in this galaxy. From our INT H-alpha and [SII] images, we find that both sources are in the proximity of regions of diffuse nebulosity, which may be powered by the ULXs. Moreover, ULX-1 is found to be associated with a bright H-alpha point source with a [SII] counterpart. Our new Chandra observation together with several archival HST images confirm the association, which will shed light on understanding the nature of these objects.
fields.speaker: Yi-Jung Yang
fields.teaser_text: ULXs are defined as off-nuclear X-ray sources with isotropic luminosities much higher than the Eddington limit for a solar mass black hole. The physical nature of ULXs has been an enigma because of their high energy output. I will present our new results of ULXs in the metal-deficit blue compact dwarf galaxy NGC 4861.

fields.title: Newborn magnetars as sources of energy injection in GRBs
fields.text: The launch of the Swift Satellite led to the discovery of plateau phases in the X-ray afterglows of many long Gamma-ray Bursts (GRBs), signifying prolonged energy injection that is often explained as ongoing accretion onto a black hole central engine. It has now been shown that many short GRBs also have plateau phases which are comparable to those observed in long GRBs. However, this challenges the typical short GRB progenitor model as all significant accretion onto the black hole is expected to occur during the prompt emission phase. The recent discovery of massive neutron stars lends support to an alternative central engine model, a magnetar formed via the merger of 2 neutron stars. In this scenario, a plateau phase followed by a shallow decay phase is predicted due dipole radiation from the magnetar. In some cases the magnetar may be unstable and collapses to form a black hole within a few hundred seconds, giving a characteristic steep decay phase as the energy injection rapidly turns off. Additionally, magnetars can be formed via the collapse of a massive star and, therefore, could also be the central engines of many LGRBs. This would explain the similarities between the plateaus observed in both long and short GRBs.
fields.speaker: Antonia Rowlinson
fields.teaser_text: The launch of the Swift Satellite led to the discovery of plateau phases in the X-ray afterglows of many long Gamma-ray Bursts (GRBs), signifying prolonged energy injection that is often explained as ongoing accretion onto a black hole central engine.

fields.title: Getting close to black holes: my adventures with hypothetical X-ray observatories
fields.text: For much of the past 6 years I have been thinking about how to use X-ray variability together with spectral information to map the regions close to black holes: so-called 'X-ray reverberation mapping'.  Much of this work has been motivated by thinking about what we will be able to do with future X-ray observatories.  Along the way there have been disappointments, as various mission proposals have bitten the dust. But the pay-off has also been big:  by pushing what we can do with existing data we have discovered that these X-ray reverberation signatures really exist, and given new life to existing mission concepts.  In my talk I will give an introduction to X-ray reverberation and the discoveries that have been made, while also giving my side of the story of how new observatories are born (and how most of them die) and why it is worthwhile to spend time working on these 'castles in the sky'.
fields.speaker: Phil Uttley
fields.teaser_text: For much of the past 6 years I have been thinking about how to use X-ray variability together with spectral information to map the regions close to black holes: so-called 'X-ray reverberation mapping'.

fields.title: Sonic Gesture
fields.text:
Sonic Gesture is a Computer Vision based software project where learned hand poses are translated into corresponding commands with the aim of generating sound. In other words this software makes it possible to create and manipulating sound without physical interaction with a computer. This has been my graduation project for my MSc Artificial Intelligence in 2011.
