fields.speaker: Gijs Molenaar
fields.teaser_text: Sonic Gesture is a Computer Vision based software project where learned hand poses are translated into corresponding commands with the aim of generating sound. This has been my graduation project for my MSc Artificial Intelligence in 2011.

fields.title: Satellite Astrometry via Radio Interferometry
fields.text: Radio interferometry has a wide variety of applications in applied science, engineering and astronomy. In this talk, I will motivate and describe the method and some of its unique applications. I will then present a novel project carried out by us at the Raman Research Institute, India, for the astrometric parameterization of a geosynchronous satellite's orbit. This method results in the estimation of the satellite's line of sight velocity with mm/sec accuracy, and has important implications for Very Long Baseline Interferometry (VLBI) and satellite ranging.
fields.speaker: Peeyush Prasad
fields.teaser_text: Radio interferometry has a wide variety of applications in applied science, engineering and astronomy. In this talk, I will motivate and describe the method and some of its unique applications. I will then present a novel project for the astrometric parameterization of a geosynchronous satellite's orbit.

fields.title: Cherenkov Telescopes and CTA
fields.text: VHE gamma-ray astronomy probes the local universe at the very highest energies. Low fluxes prevent space-based detection on meaningful timescales so ground-based Imaging Atmospheric Cherenkov Telescopes (IACT or simply Cherenkov telescopes) are currently our best window on this energy regime. In this talk, I will outline the operating principle of Cherenkov telescopes, as well as some of the technical challenges involved in the detection of VHE gamma-rays. I will then give a brief overview of the next generation instrument, the Cherenkov Telescope Array.
fields.speaker: Mark Bryan
fields.teaser_text: VHE gamma-ray astronomy probes the local universe at the very highest energies. Low fluxes prevent space-based detection on meaningful timescales so ground-based Imaging Atmospheric Cherenkov Telescopes are currently our best window on this energy regime.

fields.title: A Modified RFI flagger for transient radio signals
fields.text: One of the greatest issues for any radio telescope is its radio frequency interference (RFI), terrestrial radiation which can overwhelm astronomical signals. Traditionally done by hand, RFI flagging is increasingly done with algorithms that will automatically flag RFI. Special consideration is required for flagging data which may contain transient signals in particular, as these transient signals can be mistaken as RFI in an attempt to flag all the RFI in the data set. In this talk I will discuss the issues behind RFI flagging and the strategies currently used, and introduce a modified flagging strategy for transient signals.
fields.speaker: Yvette Cendes
fields.teaser_text: One of the greatest issues for any radio telescope is its radio frequency interference (RFI), terrestrial radiation which can overwhelm astronomical signals. I will discuss the issues behind RFI flagging and the strategies currently used, and introduce a modified flagging strategy for transient signals.

fields.title: Transient Luminous Events: Lightning in the Upper Atmosphere
fields.text: Since the serendipitous discovery of a Transient Luminous Event (TLE) in Earth's upper atmosphere by researchers at the University of Minnesota in 1989, a considerable effort has been directed towards attempting to classify these phenomena and to understand their origin and their connection with the Earth climate. Now there are various names given to these phenomena, such as Sprites, Elves, and Blue Jets, and there may well be many more different kinds of transient phenomena as yet undetected. More recently it has become apparent that thunderstorms are very closely coupled with Earth's Global Electric Circuit (GEC) and may be a useful probe of the evolution of it's climate. I will discuss what we know about how thunderstorms and the associated phenomena develop (with an emphasis on Sprites), and what researchers working in this field are doing to learn more about it.
fields.speaker: Riley Connors
fields.teaser_text: Since the serendipitous discovery of a Transient Luminous Event in Earth's upper atmosphere by researchers, a considerable effort has been directed towards attempting to classify these phenomena and to understand their origin and their connection with the Earth climate. I will discuss what we know about how thunderstorms and the associated phenomena develop.

fields.title: Source extraction for radio transients detection
fields.text: Source extraction is one of the key steps in reducing astronomical data. It is meant to derive the positions and fluxes of all the sources in an image. Several sourcefinder software packages tools have been created to do this, using different approaches and looking at it from different points of view. In the LOFAR community two sourcefinder tools have been developed: PyBDSM and PySE. The latter has been designed within the Transient Key Project, in particular to detect point sources. In this talk I am presenting this tool, different tests that have been performed to estimate the best parameters that should be used for source extraction, and how PySE is implemented in the current version of the LOFAR Transient Pipeline.
fields.speaker: Dario Carbone
fields.teaser_text: Source extraction is one of the key steps in reducing astronomical data. It is meant to derive the positions and fluxes of all the sources in an image. In this talk I am presenting PySE, a sourcefinder for the Transient Key Project.

fields.title: A broadband view of the shortest orbital period black-hole X-ray binary
fields.text: MAXI J1659-152 was discovered on 2010 September 25 as a new X-ray transient, initially identified as a gamma-ray burst, but was later shown to be a new X-ray binary with a black hole as the most likely compact object. Dips in the X-ray light curves have revealed that this source is the shortest period black hole binary candidate identified to date. I will present the results of a large observing campaign across the electromagnetic spectrum, including Very Long Baseline Interferometry at radio wavelengths, and the broadband spectral modeling we have performed. This modeling demonstrates the presence of a spectral break at radio frequencies and a relationship between the radio spectrum and X-ray states. We have also determined physical parameters of the accretion disk and put them into context with respect to the other parameters of the binary system. Finally, we have investigated correlations between the luminosities in the various wavelength regimes up to 3 years after the outburst onset to examine the link between the jet and the accretion disk, confirming our broadband picture of the evolution of the outburst.
fields.speaker: Alexander van der Horst
fields.teaser_text: MAXI J1659-152 was discovered on 2010 September 25 as a new X-ray transient, initially identified as a gamma-ray burst, but was later shown to be a new X-ray binary with a black hole as the most likely compact object. Dips in the X-ray light curves have revealed that this source is the shortest period black hole binary candidate identified to date.

fields.title: Do innate talents exist?
fields.text: Last week Magnus Carlsen became the new world champion in Chess by beating Viswanathan Anand. Magnus Carlsen is only 22 years old. Chess is only one example, but in general when young people excel at some skill, people often attribute this to the person ‘having talent'. Talent is difficult to define precisely, but what is usually meant is that it is something people are born with, an innate ability which allows them to perform expertly in a particular skill. Interestingly, the consensus in the scientific community doing research on this subject is that innate talents do not exist. I will speak about some of the arguments for this and also about the importance of deliberate practice in acquiring excellence in a skill.
fields.speaker: Sjors Broersen
fields.teaser_text: Talent is difficult to define precisely, but what is usually meant is that it is something people are born with, an innate ability which allows them to perform expertly in a particular skill. Interestingly, the consensus in the scientific community doing research on this subject is that innate talents do not exist. I will speak about some of the arguments for this.

fields.title: The nature and origin of filaments in Centaurus A
fields.text: From studies of both high- and low-power radio galaxies over the past three decades, considerable observational evidence has emerged for inhomogeneous, filamentary lobes, with the bulk of the observations being conducted with the VLA in the GHz regime. I will present results from sub-GHz GMRT observations of the filamentary structure in the FRI source Centaurus A, and discuss constraints on the filament nature and origin. I will show that the most likely interpretation of the origin of the vertex and vortex filaments in the southern giant lobe is in terms of weak shocks from either transonic MHD turbulence or from a moderately recent enhanced jet activity. I will also review the development of various plasma instabilities in the lobes and how this fits with either scenario.
fields.speaker: Sarka Wykes
fields.teaser_text: From studies of radio galaxies over the past three decades, considerable observational evidence has emerged for inhomogeneous, filamentary lobes. I will present results from radio observations of the filamentary structure in the source Centaurus A.

fields.title: X-ray, optical and UV constraints on SNIa progenitors
fields.speaker: Marat Gilfanov

fields.title: What (Not) To Do With Time Series Data
fields.text:
Time domain astronomy - the study of how astrophysical objects change with time - is becoming an increasingly important field of study, with new instruments like Gaia and LSST on the horizon monitoring the sky near-continuously at high cadences.

Robust methods are crucial to take advantage of this data; consequently, time series analysis is a very active field of study both in astronomy as well as other, related disciplines. In this talk, I aim to give an (non-complete, somewhat biased) overview of some of the methods one can use to make sense of time series data of all kinds from various different kinds of sources and to answer questions about the physical nature of the underlying sources. I’ll also highlight some of the pitfalls commonly encountered and how to avoid them.
fields.speaker: Daniela Huppenkothen
fields.teaser_text: Time domain astronomy - the study of how astrophysical objects change with time - is becoming an increasingly important field of study. In this talk, I aim to give an (non-complete, somewhat biased) overview of some of the methods one can use to make sense of time series data of all kinds from various different kinds of sources.

fields.title: Magnetic Phenomena on the Solar Surface
fields.text: Realistic solar surface models provide a unique opportunity to enlarge our understanding of different aspects of solar surface magnetism, which are not easily accessible via observations. One of them is the study of the processes involved in the disappearance of magnetic flux between regions of opposite polarity on the solar surface and how it is influenced by its initial magnetic field strength and the magnetic fields behavior in deeper layers. Another aspect which has been studied is the net effect of the small scale magnetic field on the Sun's (bolometric) brightness. The direct effect of brightening within the magnetic field itself is consistent with measurements in high-resolution observations. The high `photometric accuracy' of the simulations, however, reveal the existence of compensating brightness effects that are hard to detect observationally. The influence of magnetic concentrations on the surrounding non-magnetic convective flows (a `proximity effect') reduces the brightness by an amount exceeding the brightening by the magnetic concentrations themselves. In the third project it has been investigated if small scale dynamo action, which has been suggested to be the origin of the solar weak magnetic field component, can be reproduced in simulations and how much its existence depends on the magnetic Prandl-parameter.
fields.speaker: Irina Thaler
fields.teaser_text: Realistic solar surface models provide a unique opportunity to enlarge our understanding of different aspects of solar surface magnetism. One of them is the study of the processes involved in the disappearance of magnetic flux between regions of opposite polarity on the solar surface. Another aspect which has been studied is the net effect of the small scale magnetic field on the Sun's brightness.

fields.title: Magneto-thermal evolution and the internal properties of isolated Neutron Stars
fields.text: The evolution of magnetic and temperature in neutron stars has a direct imprint on their observed timing and spectral properties. The different manifestations of isolated neutron stars can be unified under an evolutionary scenario where the magnetic field plays a key role. X-ray data help to study the physics of the neutron star crust, constraining in particular the magnetic configuration and the microscopic properties of matter.
fields.speaker: Daniele Vigano
fields.teaser_text: The evolution of magnetic and temperature in neutron stars has a direct imprint on their observed timing and spectral properties. X-ray data help to study the physics of the neutron star crust, constraining in particular the magnetic configuration and the microscopic properties of matter.

fields.title: New views on X-ray bursts from the Rapid Burster
fields.text: Almost 40 years after the discovery of the Rapid Burster, the accretion behaviour of this NS-LMXB, which is responsible for its fast-recurring X-ray bursts, remains unexplained. I will review what we have learned looking at the entire RXTE dataset for this source: the Rapid Burster might harbor an unusually slow-rotating NS; and changes in the accretion geometry between different states of an outburst directly affect the bursts' shape and could point to the presence of two different accretion channels, one polar and one equatorial. Finally, upcoming Chandra observations might yield a measurement of the NS mass over radius (M/R).
fields.speaker: Tullio Bagnoli
fields.teaser_text: Almost 40 years after the discovery of the Rapid Burster, the accretion behaviour of this NS-LMXB, which is responsible for its fast-recurring X-ray bursts, remains unexplained. I will review what we have learned looking at the entire RXTE dataset for this source.

fields.title: From Bruno to Borucki: the dreams and deeds of planet hunters
fields.text: Some folks on the high-energy end of the spectrum would "rather see something exciting like a white dwarf binary, instead of an earth-sized dust grain following Kepler's law". However, scientific agendas are determined by taste, rather than intrinsic importance. Planets are a flavor which has emerged over the past 20 years and can hardly be ignored anymore. In this talk, I will attempt to squeeze 400 years of exoplanet visions and, eventually, results, into a talk that lasts two slices of pizza. Prepare yourself for fact, folly, fata morganae, fantasy, fame and maybe a little fanatism.
fields.speaker: Lucas Ellerbroek
fields.teaser_text: Planets are a flavor which has emerged over the past 20 years and can hardly be ignored anymore. In this talk, I will attempt to squeeze 400 years of exoplanet visions and, eventually, results, into a talk that lasts two slices of pizza. Prepare yourself for fact, folly, fata morganae, fantasy, fame and maybe a little fanatism.

fields.title: Looking for substructure with Gaia
fields.text: One of the central tenets of CDM is hierarchal structure formation which implies the existence of DM sub halos at all scales down to a minimum cut off. Many of these sub halos must be dark to resolve the missing satellite problem. A subhalo passing through the disk of the MilkyWay can leave a ripple in the Disk. Gaia potentially can detect such a ripple, from a sub-halo devoid of any stars.
fields.speaker: Doug Spolyar
fields.teaser_text: One of the central tenets of CDM is hierarchal structure formation which implies the existence of DM sub halos at all scales down to a minimum cut off. A subhalo passing through the disk of the MilkyWay can leave a ripple in the Disk.

fields.title: Flaring in SAX J1808.4-3658
fields.text: The X-ray binary SAX J1808.4-3658 was the first discovered millisecond X-ray pulsar. Since that discovery, this source has been the target of a 14 year long monitoring campaign with RXTE. During this time SAX J1808 showed 6 outbursts, with a wealth of variability features. In this talk I will discuss one of these features, namely a violent 3 Hz flaring. I will discuss what makes this flaring so strange and how it might be explained.
fields.speaker: Peter Bult
fields.teaser_text: The X-ray binary SAX J1808.4-3658 shows a wealth of variability features. In this talk I will discuss one of these features, namely a violent 3 Hz flaring.

fields.title: Astronomy in Bulgaria
fields.text: I will present how astronomy works in Bulgaria from school to research level. In Bulgaria one usually gets heavily involved in astronomy still as a high school student. I will present the institutions involved in that and their activities. I will also share some experience from the national and international astronomy olympiad. At the end, I will talk about the research institutions in Bulgaria and try to show how astronomy scales to other sciences and countries.
fields.speaker: Georgi Kokotanekov
fields.teaser_text: I will present how astronomy works in Bulgaria from school to research level. In Bulgaria one usually gets heavily involved in astronomy still as a high school student. I will present the institutions involved in that and their activities.

fields.title: A new light on 21 cm intensity fluctuations from the dark ages
fields.text: Fluctuations of the 21 cm brightness temperature before the formation of the first stars hold the promise of becoming a high-precision cosmological probe in the future. The growth of overdensities is very well described by perturbation theory at that epoch and the signal can in principle be predicted to arbitrary accuracy for given cosmological parameters. Recently, Tseliakhovich and Hirata pointed out a previously neglected and important physical effect, due to the fact that baryons and cold dark matter (CDM) have supersonic relative velocities after recombination. Here I will show the effect of the relative velocity on 21 cm brightness temperature fluctuations from redshifts z ≥ 30. I will show that the 21 cm power spectrum is affected on most scales. On small scales, the signal is typically suppressed several tens of percent, except for extremely small scales (k > 2000 Mpc−1) for which the fluctuations are boosted by resonant excitation of acoustic waves. On large scales, 21 cm fluctuations are enhanced due to the non-linear dependence of the brightness temperature on the underlying gas density and temperature. The enhancement of the 21 cm power spectrum is of a few percent at k ∼ 0.1 Mpc−1 and up to tens of percent at k ~ 0.005 Mpc−1, for standard ΛCDM cosmology. More interestingly, in principle this effect allows to probe the small-scale matter power spectrum not only through a measurement of small angular scales but also through its effect on large angular scales. This could be relevant for the science case of proposed experiments such as DEX, since this would allow one to probe scales beyond the Silk damping scale, through a measurement on large scales. I will briefly discuss the prospect of this possibility.
fields.speaker: Daan Meerburg
fields.teaser_text: Fluctuations of the 21 cm brightness temperature before the formation of the first stars hold the promise of becoming a high-precision cosmological probe in the future. The growth of overdensities is very well described by perturbation theory at that epoch and the signal can in principle be predicted to arbitrary accuracy for given cosmological parameters.

fields.title: The physics of classical harmony (a short introduction told by Mr. Fourier)
fields.text: In every kind of music it is possible to distinguish between two dimensions: an horizontal (melody) and a vertical one (harmony). Like a grammar, harmony is a collection of practical rules about chords, their construction, and how to connect one chord to another. From age to age, most famous composers applied these rules (mostly ignoring physical principles behind them) introducing, from time to time, new elements and changes for the next generation of composers. In this talk I will focus on classical harmony exploring the physical motivations of the harmony rules. What is the difference between consonance and dissonance? Why certain chord progressions are always used in classical music? What is the role of our physiology and education in listening music? Thanks to Fourier analysis, I will explore, with practical examples, these and other questions linking music to physics.
fields.speaker: Stefano Rapisarda
fields.teaser_text: In every kind of music it is possible to distinguish between two dimensions: an horizontal (melody) and a vertical one (harmony). Like a grammar, harmony is a collection of practical rules about chords, their construction, and how to connect one chord to another.

fields.title: The fundamental constants of nature
fields.text: Absorption-line systems detected in spectra obtained towards distant quasars can be used to compare the value of dimensionless fundamental constants (e.g., the fine-structure constant, alpha, and the proton-to-electron mass ratio, mu = mp/me), determined in remote regions of the Universe to their value today on Earth. In recent years, some evidence has emerged of small temporal and also spatial variations in alpha and mu on cosmological scales which may reach a fractional level of 10 ppm. A possible variation in the value of alpha and/or mu would have fundamental implications.
fields.speaker: Lex Kaper
fields.teaser_text: Absorption-line systems detected in spectra obtained towards distant quasars can be used to compare the value of dimensionless fundamental constants (e.g., the fine-structure constant and the proton-to-electron mass ratio), determined in remote regions of the Universe to their value today on Earth.

fields.title: Philosophy of Language: The meaning of meaning
fields.text: At the end of the nineteenth century a new branch of philosophy originated from the works of the logician Gottlob Frege, called 'analytic philosophy'. This tradition aims to clarify philosophical conundrums like "What is the meaning of a symbol/word/sentence?", "What is truth?", "What are the criteria for (non)sense?", and "What is the connection between language and reality?" by taking a closer look at language. Over the years many philosophers have constructed elaborate (purely) logical frameworks or have studied our everyday language, to try and come up with a satisfactory theory of meaning or deny its very possibility. I will briefly discuss the workings of a handful of prominent thinkers and thereby address some significant aspects of the philosophy of language.
fields.speaker: Chris Elenbaas
fields.teaser_text: At the end of the nineteenth century a new branch of philosophy originated from the works of the logician Gottlob Frege, called 'analytic philosophy'. I will briefly discuss the workings of a handful of prominent thinkers and thereby address some significant aspects of the philosophy of language.

fields.title: Magnetars are everywhere!
fields.text: I will review recent theoretical and observational results on strongly magnetic neutron stars. I will then focus in particular on the neutron star 'grand unification' theory, and its consequence of the Galactic neutron star population. These news results might have important consequences also on other research fields such as GRBs, massive stars, and gravitational waves.
fields.speaker: Nanda Rea
fields.teaser_text: I will review recent theoretical and observational results on strongly magnetic neutron stars. I will then focus in particular on the neutron star 'grand unification' theory, and its consequence of the Galactic neutron star population. These news results might have important consequences also on other research fields such as GRBs, massive stars, and gravitational waves.

fields.title: Some fun with black holes
fields.text: Why do 2 merging black holes, a gamma-ray burst, and the whole universe all have about the same luminosity? What is the luminosity of merging black holes? And if adding black holes, is 1+1=2, or more, or less? And is it the same each time? Some of these things you may know, some may surprise you a bit, and some may weird you out. I will tell you what I think about each one, or you may tell me.
fields.speaker: Ralph Wijers
fields.teaser_text: Why do 2 merging black holes, a gamma-ray burst, and the whole universe all have about the same luminosity? What is the luminosity of merging black holes? And if adding black holes, is 1+1=2, or more, or less?

fields.title: Modelling the atmosphere of a magnetar during a burst
fields.text: Magnetars regularly exhibit bursts with luminosity well above the classical Eddington luminosity for a neutron star. While the magnetic field raises this limit, it will still be reached in many SGR bursts, and definitely in the rare giant flares. I am working on the implications of this for the atmosphere of a magnetar during an SGR burst. I will briefly discuss the possibility of Photospheric Radius Expansion bursts in magnetars, and why this turns out to be an impossibility. I will then show some results from my Monte Carlo radiative transfer models in magnetar atmospheres, as the radiative transfer turns out to be the key issue in these systems. Finally I will discuss radiation driven magnetar winds, which I am in the process of modelling, and discuss why we should be looking for them.

fields.title: Improving the astronomy software landscape
fields.text:
Modern astronomy is getting more and more software oriented. Current radio astronomical results couldn't be accomplished without the aid of big computers and complex software. The complexity and size of many scientific software project has become of a size beyond the comprehension of an untrained PhD student. Still many scientist employ poor software engineer techniques, which will hurt themselves and the field as a whole in the long run.

In my talk I explore methods and techniques for improving software quality, development practises and end user experience. I'll cover starting points for new software writing scientists, but also more advanced techniques from preparing software for machine type and environment independent deployment. The latter is part of the work and research I did and will do in South Africa (SKA).
fields.speaker: Gijs Molenaar
fields.teaser_text: Modern astronomy is getting more and more software oriented. Current radio astronomical results couldn't be accomplished without the aid of big computers and complex software. In my talk I explore methods and techniques for improving software quality, development practises and end user experience.

fields.title: The Life and Times of a Science Writer
fields.text: In March 2013, I was fortunate enough to be the author of the Astronomy magazine cover article on cosmic rays and the Pierre Auger Observatory. In this talk I will tell the story of how this was the culmination of several years of work, spanning from the Argentinian pampas to the astronomy observatories of California, involving a lot of planning, interviewing, and pestering slow editors. Along the way I will also briefly explain how science journalism works, from the similarities and differences to the technical articles scientists write to how to get something published yourself.

fields.title: Looking for fast radio transients with LOFAR
fields.text: The LOFAR Tied-Array All-Sky Survey (LOTAAS) is an ongoing survey for pulsars and fast radio transients. LOTAAS exploits the low observing frequencies and wide field-of-view offered by LOFAR. I will focus on the software and techniques that I'm developing during my PhD to search the data for individual radio bursts. We are overcoming the involved challenges, identifying astrophysical signals, and hope to soon be able to look for the rare but bright radio bursts, such as the potentially cosmological signal recently termed "fast radio bursts".
fields.speaker: Daniele Michilli
fields.teaser_text: The LOFAR Tied-Array All-Sky Survey is an ongoing survey for pulsars and fast radio transients. I will focus on the software and techniques that I'm developing during my PhD to search the data for individual radio bursts.

fields.title: Exploring Jet Physics Across the Black Hole Mass Scale
fields.text: The advent of the 21st century saw the discovery of scaling relations between the radio/X-ray luminosities and masses of accreting black holes at low luminosities. The relation, referred to as the Fundamental Plane of Black Hole Accretion (FP), poses interesting questions in regard to the physics of the inflow(accretion)/outflow(jet/corona) connection of black holes. It should be possible to utilise the relation between these sources to test the predictions of scale-invariant models, in particular jet models that can reproduce the broadband spectra of low luminosity sources. I discuss the multiwavelength spectral fitting we are currently conducting. Using a semi-analytical model for a jet propagating from a black hole, we simultaneously fit our model to the broadband spectra of two black holes; the supermassive black hole Sgr A*, and Galactic black hole A0620-00. I will also discuss what we hope to learn from this fitting technique, and why it is a useful tool to split the model degeneracy when fitting to spectral data.

fields.title: New methods to constrain the radio transient rate: results from a survey of four fields with LOFAR
fields.text: Radio transient detection is one of the main goals of the new generation radio interferometers. We report on the results of a search for radio transients between 115 and 190 MHz with the LOw-Frequency ARray (LOFAR). Four different fields have been monitored with observational cadences between 15 minutes and several months. A total of 15 observing runs were performed giving a total survey area of 2275 deg2. No credible transient candidate has been detected in our survey; however, it enables us to set upper limits on the surface density of transient sources. To do this we used two new statistical methods. One is free of assumptions on the flux distribution of the sources, while the other assumes a power-law distribution in flux and sets more stringent constraints on the snapshot surface density. We also analysed the snapshot surface density as a function of the time separation between different observations, providing insight into how this changes for different transient time-scales.
